text: Amazing presentation.  Five star treatment from the staff.  Not all the food tasted the best and it certainly isn't about the portions here.  But the environment and experience was incredible.

I went for diner with my husband two weeks ago to celebrate my birthday , we were looking to dine in Alinea since we moved to Chicago , we both working in the industry we couldn't wait to try one of the best restaurants in Chicago and in the world .   Our reservation was for 8:30pm and when we got there at 8:30pm we were told to have a seat and wait until our table was ready , it may have been 15 min wait, we were so exited .... when we got to the table the tasting menu started right away , we were not doing wine pairing so we ordered a bottle of wine , the wine didn't arrive until we were in the middle of the dinner, we thought they couldn't find it and we were about to cancel it by the time it got to the table , the food was great, a couple of weak dishes but I guess that is very subjective, service was not what you expect for a 3 Michelin star restaurant, we felt rushed , the plates kept being taken very fast when one of us finished not considering that the other person was still eating the same course of the menu, it happened in most of the courses and just like that our experience was over ,  it last 1hr , probably 1hr and 30min considering the waiting time and the time that took us to finish our wine, we were left with almost half bottle of wine because as I said it came in the middle of the dinner , we felt like we were trying to make longer the experience  by ourselves, as I said it was my birthday and wanted it to be special , that's why we chose Alinea for that day, we probably went the wrong day , felt like everybody was in a rush to start closing the restaurant when there was still plenty of people, the service was not engaging, we felt like a number ...,I'm giving 2 starts for the overall experience because food was great but the experience was ruined by the service .

Guys. This one breaks my heart. I had such high hopes and maybe too high of hopes. Also the price demands that this is life changing. It didn't help that I had just gone to another Chef's Table restaurant, Pujol in Mexico City, and was blown away for a fraction of the price. Everything at Alinea was delicious. BUT it was over hyped in my opinion and overpriced. I think with the TV specials and and the attention on this place, its reputation has just blown up to standards that can't be met. Idk. I have to go meditate on this. Painful to review.

If you like mediocre food and rude service in a plain gray 60° (meat locker) room for an outrageous price then this is the place for you..... read all the reviews before you book, I didn't and I paid the price.  Rude, rude, rude service and they turn the tables lightning fast, you definitely will leave feeling rushed.  Food is gimmick at best, sea bass was chewy, poor food quality (some of it not even edible). Oh and the dessert.. bubble gum... really!   If this is their interpretation of Avant-garde they missed the mark big time.  Don't waste your money go somewhere else.  Want to read more?..... OK After quickly checking out the reviews and seeing a few pics, this place looks amazing right?.... WRONG.... had high expectation that all dissipated at table..... - Booking: the best marketing scam out there. They limit the tables offered so you feel lucky to get a table then when we got there the room was half empty. - Ambiance: plain, dull gray wall and cold (60 degrees cold) room. Honestly the bathroom was better decorated.  - Staff: rude and they look beaten / disinterested kitchen staff. Not once we were asked if we enjoying our food. The sommelier can't even pour the correct measure, paid $26 for 1.5oz glass of wine. - Food: oooh the food.......you will be greeted by a peace of lettuce wedged on top of a lime (was sitting on the table for god knows how long). And the giant bowl of orange w the dry ice..... Then it seems as they ran out of plates so the waiter present a tasteless micro pancake on a stick...... and so on...then the sea bass (they can't leave good enough alone, no harmony in the combinations) over cooked, chewy and more inedible compensation of "stuff" in the bowl.... Oh, oh and the poor attempt from the waiter to cook a potato (that was buried in salt) on our table....come on..... The plates looked good enough for pics for Instagram but lacked harmony between ingredients and cohesion between the dishes.  It's more gamic food and downhill experience from there. I sat there course after course in disbelieve "is that it" "that's the best they can come up with" "the chef will redeem himself at the next course"........wrong    - Price: outrageous.....that's why you have to prepay because if they present you with that outrageous bill at the end of that highly disappointing experience you will never pay it.  I guarantee you I wouldn't.  - Management: guilt ridden, very defensive and set in their own ways. Don't bother complaining to Quincy, Nick or even Grant. They have no problem taken you money and never explained the poor food quality or the rude service.... They will blame everyone one else before they look in the mirror.      Finally...if I ever feel the urge to have that experience again I'll go ahead and schedule my colonoscopy as I'm sure Ill get the same level of satisfaction.

I mean...what could this review tell you that countless other reviews, best-of lists, documentaries, books, and three little non-Yelp stars couldn't? Sure, the restaurant has changed in the past couple years, but I don't think I missed out on too much. I placed my reservations in late May of '16 for two for an early June reservation - I got lucky as it had just reopened and I don't think you'll be able to get a table only two and a half weeks out anymore. I went with the Salon with standard pairings. My fiancee and I are not wine connoisseurs, but we weren't about to pass up paired drinks. Service is similar to what I've experienced at other Achatz places.  Yes, this is the finest of fine dining, but our servers were smart enough to realize we were a young couple out for a fun night. They answered all of our questions, made sure we were taken care of, and never once did I feel out of place. I even overheard a server try his best at translating a dish description to guest who only spoke Spanish. It's hard to type out a description of everything we had, especially with it being 11 courses and most of them having wine (or mezcal) with it. There was dehydrated scallops in a corn soup. Smoky chicken thigh dressed as the Mexican flag. A "yellow" dish of curry, pork, and yellow chopsticks. And of course, we finished off with the signature helium filled candy balloon. Oh, and rather than their former famous dessert painted on the table, ours was painted on...a painting. Each dish was perfectly balanced, and by that I mean balanced between "WTF are they serving us" and "WTF are these flavors in my mouth". It's a fun time and a unique experience. Is this deserving of the praise of being not only one of the best countries in the city, but also the world? I mean, it's close, but until my lola (grandma) starts accepting reservations, you'll be ok coming to Alinea.

It seems futile or arrogant to review Alinea, but of course we'll attempt it anyway. We had tried for a couple months to get a reservation to the gallery, and when we finally did, we built the rest of our trip to Chicago around it. It's absurd how much money dinner for two costs, but we knew that this was a 'once-in-a-lifetime' experience. We liked that yesterday evening started with a communal table and we were fortunate to be seated near folks who were friendly and easy to converse with. We didn't particularly enjoy any of the crazy starter "flower" courses, and even though it was gimmicky, it was still pretty awesome when the flower pots started smoking. The shaker and spear course in the kitchen was one of our favorites; both the drink and the amuse were delicious, and while we thoroughly enjoyed being in the action back there, you could tell some of the BOH folks were less than thrilled about it. The rest of the meal at individual tables had some highs and lows. We didn't like the "glass" course, and while the "fire and ice" course was entertaining, none of the components tasted like they belonged together. On the other hand, the truffle course was amazing--who knew that a sous vide potato could be so delicious? While it was served colder with way too much of the dairy than we would prefer, we loved it, and we especially loved the truffle toast. Dessert: the candy bar dessert was OK, but the grape balloon was fun and certainly more nostalgic. Playing LCD Soundsystem during the paint performance? A+ We liked our servers for the most part. They were fun and cool. We have two major complaints:  1) For $900, the fact that our only major protein was a tiny ass piece of veal cheek kinda pissed us off. Yes yes, we're paying for Grant et al's ingenuity and vision, but still.  2) Once we were sat back down at the individual tables after the kitchen, everything felt extremely rushed. One course came out right after another, plates were cleared quickly (even after only one of us had finished--that's amateur hour service), and just as we were starting to settle in, it was time for dessert. All told, we're happy we went, and we had a wonderful night, but we still can only give Alinea four stars. Like most things in life, as when we saw Hamilton for almost the same price two nights before, Alinea just wasn't worth the money. We've spent a lot less on fine dining (i.e. Eleven Madison Park, Per Se, Streireck), where we feel that every penny was well-spent. Did we see smoking flower pots there, or chefs smashing frozen white chocolate down on a tray that came from the ceiling? Of course not. There's no denying that this was the most unique dining experience that we've ever had, but a day later, the feeling gnaws at us that on food alone Alinea sacrifices substance for style.

We were charged about $700 for two people with taxes and 20% service charge. This amount is too little if you are in the 1% and too much if you are in the 99%, aspiring for a taste of the life of 1%.  Upon arrival, we were greeted by the hostess. An usher walked us to our seats. Once seated, a server greeted us and all of the guests with the same script after being seated. He was jaded and his performance was insincere. His role in the "experience" is to elegantly inquire if you are high worth guest i.e. if you will shell out $100+/person for a wine tasting.  There was an amuse bouche resting on the table before we were seated. Out of four servers on the floor, none bothered to inform us what it was. When the meal begins at such a high note it has only one place to go from there i.e. downwards. The courses were presented by disinterested kitchen staff, who mumbled while describing the dishes and were offended when asked to repeat. The dishes were not memorable and lacked flavor and seasoning. All of the accolades have numbed the taste buds of the chef and his staff. The dishes are good for Instagram. The meal ended with two desserts both of which were lackluster.    One of the dishes was presented with a bed of salt. None of the staff bothered to clean the salt on the table for the rest of the evening. If the diner has been coerced to pay 20% service charge, then the diner can not ask for his/her money back, if the service isn't good. I would ask Grant to let the diner decide if the service they received was worth 20% tip.  During the two hour experience, the staff sarcastically asked us about our opinions on some of the dishes. Buddy, if you are not excited about your own food, then it makes me look like a fool paying high prices for a meal you don't believe in.  Temper your expectations, since both people and food are gimmicky here.  It's a great marketing tactic to create a sense of scarcity by making the reservation hard to come by. The media/PR has hyped up the place. The chef is focused on expanding his restaurant empire by opening more restaurants in Chicago and other cities rather than offering a good experience to the diners at Alinea. If you decide to dine here, then know that you are not paying for the food, service, or ambiance you are paying for one thing and one thing only i.e. the brand Grant Achatz.

Anything I say won't be able to do our experience justice. Everything was flat out amazing, the staff, the food, the experience - I'm still blown away thinking about it. You guys know what Alinea is. It is of course expensive, and we paid an additional price for the wine pairings, but what you get in return is completely worth it. It's not like you're going here every other weekend for a quick bite. As much as all of you enjoyed Hamilton (or insert any other musical you prefer), you didn't go see it again the next weekend. That's kind of what I would compare this to - an amazing theater or vacation experience. I won't be back any time soon, but that's of course just because I can't afford to have my mind blown every weekend. I hope to be back in the near future to celebrate another special occasion.

This was truly a dining experience.  The food and wine were great.  Each course was innovative and flavorful.  The service was excellent. The waiters explained each course and the wine pairings were perfect.  The funnest part was dessert.  The only downside to the experience was the price.  Overall, this is a good place for special occasions or entertaining that special client.

It's intimidating to walk up to the front door of Alinea, knowing you're going to be served some of the best (and most expensive) food of your life, but once I walked inside the experience was amazing. While it definitely is classy and formal inside, it was never too hoity toity and the servers (a whole team of them!) made us feel very comfortable. Every dish was fantastic in terms of inventiveness and presentation. Sure, there were some flavors that I didn't like, but I could at least appreciate the effort that went into each one.   Everything about the experience was above and beyond everything I expected. For me, this is one of those once-in-a-lifetime experiences that is definitely worth it.

Below you will find a picture of our menu, it's way too long to type out.  I will say I've been meaning to go here for quite some time, and finally a friend gave me an extra ticket.  I'm not sure if I would have gone if I paid for it.  The sensory overload begins immediately when you walk in.  From the sights to the sounds, to the smells, they create an amazing experience. The flower was served with smoke coming from the plant in the middle of the table.  It was interesting, not a ton of flavor.  Then they brought us in the kitchen for a cocktail.  The shaker and spear were excellent.  After returning to the table the flower was gone and we were served the crunch, and a host of other tiny bites.  All were very interesting, but nothing stood out.  Then came the ink, which was very cool, and actually quite good.  The corn soup I did not enjoy.  Then came the Thai inspired dishes which were my favorite.  The Thai wings and curry soup were great.  The pork belly was ok, nothing spectacular.  I did not care for the blueberry.  The spuds with truffles were amazing, fresh truffles on top of whipped potatoes.  The bean and tenderloin were again good, but not the best I've ever had.  The rest of the desserts were pretty standard except the balloon and candy bars.  So neat, I won't ruin it for you but the presentation is second to none.  Last was the finale, the paint show, again I won't divulge too much, but was amazing to witness. Overall I really thought the food was good, but not out of this world. I really wanted to be loan away given the fact it's too 20 in the world, not to mention we paid $265 each for the chef's table.  If you want he wine pairing that's another $125-$375 depending on what you choose.  I would definitely say go at least once if you can to experience.  I will also mention my friend has been over 5x and he said this was the most disappointing experience he has had.  He did not enjoy the food so maybe I got an off menu.

Throughout human history, mankind has always sought the divine through means of exploration and pilgrimage. Many in the Jewish faith have made the journey to Jerusalem to walk the sacred streets and touch the wall of the temple; Muslim's have the hajj to go and worship at Mecca. Alinea is that destination for all of mankind. Come and experience food in a way that will make you question what food is and why food is. You will be treated to the finest freshest food and service that human beings are capable of delivering. The vision that chef Achatz has executed here with his team will leave you spreading the gospel of good food.  Come and eat

Meh.  I've experienced better. Alinea earned its 3 Michelin stars by putting on a fantastic show.  However subtract the sleight-of-hand & what's left is just the actual food... which is mediocre.  I enjoyed half the courses served to me, and did Not enjoy the other half of courses served to me.  That's a poor percentage. For $300 I expect better.  In fact I HAVE experienced better (at Per Se, French Laundry, Joel Robuchon, Gordon Ramsay, et cetera).  For me it's all about the food, and the actual food was disappointing.

Took my husband for his Birthday here in 2015. It was spectacular. You're not just buying a meal but an experience. Everything had a smooth transition into the next plate. Food was high quality. One of my favorite parts was the green apple flavored balloon that was filled with helium. Definitely made our meal lighthearted and fun! The chef knows what he's doing and we are planning to go again due to their new menu.

How do I give this 10 Stars? This place is constantly ranked in the top 5 restaurants around the entire world year after year! I was lucky enough to have worked for a gentleman with super Deep Pockets for about 4 years of my life and he took us here one time. I have to tell you.... the tastes are something that took my taste buds around many different galaxies and back! This would be the most erect you can possibly get and using it all night long. I really don't know how else to explain it in Chubb standards. I would say this is probably even better than sex. They bring you out like 10 or 11 courses of the most exotic s*** you can dream up and imagine, this should be on yours and everyone who is a Foodies bucket list. It is a must try, it is a must have, don't cringe over the price, it will be a memory you will never forget. I promise you that. Final rating, two boners and erect for 24 hours straight with a 5 foot money shot

Good food, would return. Drinks not cheap, but food is pretty good. Heard this place was featured on TV so I had to check it out. Liked what I saw for the most part. Like I said. . . NOT CHEAP. BE WARNED. That said, you can tell the dishes are prepared with utmost expertise. I do applaud the chef!

After seeing an episode of Chef's Table on Netflix, my wife and I knew we had to eat at Alinea some day.  We were able to make it to Chicago for a mini vacation and were able to get reservations for Alinea.  It was not an easy reservation to get! The experience we'd hoped to get was literally sold out within seconds of being available.  That said, we were ecstatic to have gotten any seat at all. The experience itself was absolutely amazing.  They really push the limits of gastronomy with every course and stimulate all your senses.  The meal goes far beyond taste alone.  Truly dinner theater where the food is the focus.  Hands down the most amazing dining experience we've ever had.  We hope to go back and talk some friends into doing the Chef's Table with us next time.

Let me begin with the caveat that this review is for the SALON seating (10-12 courses) and not the Kitchen Table experience (16-18 courses).  We tried to get tickets for Kitchen the morning they were released 1 1/2 months in advance but couldn't secure them.  Anyone planning a visit, use multiple computers/browsers and target different times (and days if possible).   My review has nothing to do with the mechanism for getting seating here though -- the 2-stars reflect our disappointment from the actual dining experience. 1.  For a 3-Michelin star meal compromising of "10-14 courses" AND with wine pairings, I don't expect to finish my meal in 75 minutes.  But we did.  Fastest Michelin star (1, 2 or 3 stars) meal ever.  And yes, that is because the service was super-rushed.  It was ridiculous.  Not sure if it was because we had the last seating at 9 pm, but that is no one excuse.  After our meal I went back and read some recent reviews and apparently others have felt the same.  Hardly any time between courses to transition.  As an example, they gave us 3 desserts, the last which was their famous helium balloon.  They brought out the balloon within 3 minutes of the prior dish coming out and while we were still eating it.   2.  As for the food, there were definitely some unique dishes and presentation.  For example, what they do with the bowl of oranges and the potato buried in the fire that is later used for a truffle potato dish was impressive.  But the overall quality of food was underwhelming.  Some of the dishes sounded or looked very interesting, but the flavors did not come together -- there was depth, but not in a good way.  We ate at Oriole (2-Michelin star) a few nights earlier and the food was much better.   The savory portions here also ended abruptly.  Perhaps due to feeling rushed or that we only had the Salon experience.  But I expected more than the final savory course to be a small piece of veal cheek. 3.  The dessert in my opinion was terrible.  The bubblegum dish was disgusting and one of the worst desserts I've ever had, borderline unedible.  Perhaps there is a segment of people who really like bubblegum flavor and wouldn't mind eating it in multiple forms/textures -- but we did not enjoy it.   The helium filled edible balloon was a neat twist and one of the few positives to the meal.  But overall, when dessert counts for 3 of 10 courses, I expected more. 4.  The wine pairing was a disappointment.  We probably had 7-8 different drinks.  Small/average pours at best.  Quality just OK.  For dessert, they gave us a single pour of a cider.  The cider was decent, but you'd expect to get a dessert wine, port, or something more unique and more than one drink for 3 desserts.  More notably, our server didn't pour my wife her wine pairing for the veal cheek dish (last savory course) and he poured mine into the same glass as my prior pairing (that was empty, hers was not).  It was very strange and we expected him to come back and perhaps pour when she was done with the glass in front of her but he never did. We have heard great things about Alinea from others and perhaps this was just an off-night.  We really wanted to come back another time and try the Kitchen Table experience, but may not after such a terrible showing.   The only reason for not giving one-star is that some of the theatrics and presentation were truly unique and I understand why these at one time helped Alinea earn its 3 Michelin stars.  But as many of written, this place has gone downhill and no longer lives up to the rating. If you are in Chicago and looking for an exceptional Michelin-star experience, I recommend Oriole.  I think they recently earned a second star.  We ate there 3 nights earlier.  Where I'd give Alinea Salon a D, Oriole gets an A+.  And that grading is independent of fact that Oriole was less expensive.

It's been a week since I went to Alinea, and I can't stop thinking about it! As he said on Chef's Table, Grant truly pushes the limits of what your taste buds can handle and despite every entree having at least 10 ingredients, each ingredient's flavour gracefully blends and enhances one another. The chefs sweep you away in a delectable masquerade where each ingredient pretends to be something else and each dish is tantalizingly unmasked.   Each course was unforgettably mouthwatering and my hesitation to grant it 5-star status stems from the soothing, but bland restaurant decor and the fact that some of my senses felt a little left out of the party. The upstairs decor was dimly lit with grey and white accents. Perhaps Grant intended this to be a blank canvas that would allow him to paint his gorgeous food against?  My senses of taste and sight were satisfyingly fulfilled on the culinary journey, but I felt as if  touch, hearing and smell had been asked to stay at home. Touch was sort of involved when one dish was presented in a silicone bowl which we held in our hands while eating and smell was tingled when liquid was added to the centerpiece to give life to the lemon, lime and orange scents.  Truly, every dish was prepared with thoughtfulness and inspiration. My faves were the dishes that involved multiple senses, such as the coconut bowl with sea bass, coconut meat, and peppery flowers nestled upon a mountain of salt and bathed in the warm glow of a fire (hiding a slow cooking Yukon potato) and the nostalgic dessert based on bubble yum, banana and cake flavours and served with a grape helium balloon tied by an apple string. Unforgettable...

Alinea is truly a once in a lifetime experience. My husband and I couldn't go on a vacation this year, so we decided to go to Alinea instead. It was incredible.  The service was impeccable. We had one server who was a little condescending, but the rest were down to earth and professional.  I can't even describe each of the courses, but my favorite part was when we arrived, we were seated at one huge table for a course, the next course was in the kitchen, and when we came back the room had been rearranged completely into individual tables.  All courses were delicious. I especially loved the toast points, wagyu beef, Thai soup, and edible grape balloons.  The food was truly delicious, the presentation of each dish was masterful, and the experience was meticulously thought out.

I have wanted to dine at Alinea for...ever? Finally my time came. My friend got us a table in the salon for my birthday and it was certainly everything I had hoped it would be. I will preface by saying most find me to be picky, in the sense that I am typically very skeptical when it comes to highly rated places. I've been duped far too many times. But Alinea is the real deal.  We arrived on a rainy Friday evening and the hostess pushed back the doors. It was like being led into some culinary fantasy. Every detail was meticulously planned and I cannot choose a favorite course. The savory "oreo" was pure sin, black truffle, pumpernickel, and guyere cheese. The caviar "taco" was genius. The short rib was so smoky and sweet. And of course dessert was terribly whimsical and fun.  Our waiter was delightful and the atmosphere was not stuffy in the least. The other couples in the salon were interactive and we had a lot of fun. I will say, if you are not much of a drinker, you will be drunk when you leave based on the wine pairing. They are definitely generous. I also felt that there could have been a bit more time between courses but I understand they want to accommodate as many patrons as they can. Overall, it was wonderful!

Incredible! My SO and I went here for a birthday celebration and I was honestly afraid it wouldn't live up to the hype. I was wrong! The food was so incredibly inventive, playful, and most importantly delicious! The atmosphere is more laid back than I expected. People typically dress well, jackets for men, dresses for women, but the waiters joke around with guests and it never felt stuffy. In terms of the actual food, the portions are small, it's a 14 course tasting menu, but each plate is incredibly flavorful and completely different from the last. Since all of the flavors are bold, it's not uncommon to not completely fall in love with each and every dish, but even though there were 2 dishes that weren't my taste, I still loved them for how beautiful they were and how inventive the play on ingredients was. That being said, 12 of the dishes were real rockstars, some of the most delicious food I've ever eaten, and without a doubt, the most impressively and playfully served food I've ever had. I'd describe Alinea as more dinner theater than a restaurant. I don't want to spoil the individual courses for anyone, and since they change constantly there's little point providing a description of each dish, but overall I highly recommend trying out Alinea! It's worth making a trip to Chicago specifically to go to this restaurant. You won't be disappointed!

Alinea was a culinary experience we looked forward to for a long time. Given our high expectations, we disagreed a bit on our ultimate rating. The food was certainly interesting, creative, and delicious. We did the tasting menu, shared one wine pairing, and one non-alcohol pairing. The experience of the food was a bit dampened by the fact that as a later seating time, we were surrounded by people who all received the same dishes before us and overhead and saw everything that was yet to come. The service, although friendly and attentive, did not live up to expectations as our server tried to be cool and do a trick while pouring our drinks and ended up spilling on our clothes-  a definite no-no at this upscale, everyone-dresses-up, slightly stuffy dining environment. The non-alcoholic pairing was also a a bit of a disappointment and consisted of all sugary juices. (Although the sage infused cider was one of the best things of the night). Overall, made for an uneven experience, particularly at the price point.

The service, presentation, food and fun atmosphere make for a memorable dining experience. The innovation reminds me of Espai Sucre in Barcelona but with a broader medium. The only dining experience that I find on the same level (within my budget) of Alinea is the Inn at Little Washington. Thank you for a truly memorable experience!
The best dining experience I've ever had. Period. Along with the food being amazing, the overall experience is something you'll remember for the rest of your life.

The ultimate culinary experience! We had dinner at Alinea and were thoroughly impressed. It's not only taste, but they stimulate your other senses of smell, touch, etc to allow you to really experience your meal.  We dined in the Salon and the service was excellent- borderline intense but 2 of our 4 servers were light hearted and helped lighten up the mood and answer all our questions about the menu items (Alex and Rizki).  Alinea was able to accommodate our vegetarian diet and even asked for specifics such as if animal derived products (broths, gelatin, etc) would be ok.  Reservations are somewhat difficult to get, but if you plan ahead you can get exactly what you want. They release reservations 2 months in advance, on the 15th of the month at 11am central time. The earlier in the evening your dinner is, the less expensive the meal price is. You also have the option of purchasing a wine pairing, but this can be added on before your meal begins (or they have wine by the glass).

This was truly an unforgettable evening. This was the most unique, creative meal I've ever had. Every detail, every bite and flavor was exquisite. The chef is truly a genius. So delicious would love to go back one day.

Alinea is not about food.  It is about an journey which stimulates all five senses.  So much thought is put into every aspect of the diner's experience; the scents walking in, the crossword puzzle menu, the colour palette within each dish, the impeccable service.  The food combinations were creative yet balanced; the flavours sophisticated and vibrant.  Every course evoked a new and invigorating sensory response.

Alinea blew our minds. From the food to the wine to the excellent, yet unpretentious, service- literally everything was perfect. Knowing that it's ranked as one of the best restaurants in the world, we were afraid that the food might be too conceptual and the atmosphere too stuffy- we could not have been more wrong.  The food is wildly innovative, yet totally accessible. We had the wine pairing, and each wine was perfectly matched for each course, and whether it was rosé, white, red, or even sake (I normally hate sake!), each drink was delicious. The servers were professional and knowledgable and offered an explanation of each dish and how to eat it; they even gave us permission to lick the plate for one of the dishes. They were able to answer every question we asked- about everything from the wine to the flatware, but they also joked with us and made us feel right at home. It was a truly unique and unbelievably enjoyable experience from start to finish!

First time dining at Alinea since remodel, second time dining here overall.  First experience was as perfect as a fine dining experience could possibly be - mind blowing even - dinner a couple of nights ago however was incredibly disappointing.  Evenings at restaurants of this caliber are often likened to a night at the theater: every dish and glass of wine is served with its own story; every move of the wait staff appears to be precisely choreographed; the sheer visual artistry of each course; exciting, unique textures and flavors. It only makes sense that establishments such as these would forego a typical reservation scheme in favor of a ticketing system... it is worth noting, however, that service (aka tip) is included in ticket price up front.  The attitudes of the wait staff were very clearly either unhappy to be there or simply indifferent.  Plates were brought out to each member of our party somewhat haphazardly - some of the nicer restaurants at casinos in Detroit manage to coordinate this better.  For several courses we were told nothing about the wine pairings.  For several courses our water glasses were empty.  The cuisine was remarkably underwhelming - the first course ("Spear") tasted like Windex.  Constituent portions of subsequent courses were variously frozen, puréed and/or smoked; this certainly added to theatrics but didn't necessarily add anything positive to the dishes themselves.  After edible balloons were brought out copies of the word jumble/menu were placed on the table then we were ignored until we guessed it was time to leave.  The meal was an entirely unsatisfying procession of what seemed to be poorly executed gimmicks, each more disheartening than the last.  I have to think that our experience here was affected by the fact that Chef Achatz was in New York working on other projects, but admittedly this is mere conjecture.  Regardless we coordinated a trip across country and dropped $2,488.68 on dinner for four (plus two cookbooks) and it just was not good.  A year ago we had a similarly disappointing experience in Yountville but I couldn't bear to write that review.  No surprise then to see these restaurants continue to slip further down the World's Best list.  Think I'm going to finally give up on fine dining for good now.

As someone who along with their wifey has truly been able to take advantage of all the outstanding restaurants during our time living in Chicago, I was very much looking forward to dining at Alinea. That said, I have to say given that it regarded as "the best in Chicago" and "among the best in the world", I was thoroughly disappointed. When we have done tasting menu experiences previously, we have never felt rushed. The courses come well spaced. Both cannot be said about Alinea. Sure, the food was good, but I definitely felt that the service was rushed and the courses were not properly split up to give a break in consumption.  Now to the wine pairing. We selected the intermediate one, which cost $195 per person. One would have thought for that price that I would be stumbling out of the place or at the very least feel like I was satisfied. Both were not the case. Two others in our party - who are much more oenophiles than me - felt completely ripped off. The pours were incredibly modest. For 3x$195 we might as well have ordered directly from the wine list itself as we would have likely been much more satisfied. I am glad I finally dined at Alinea, but I do not feel a need to go back. It is a shame because two other people had two similar dining experiences to us in the last couple years.

This is some fancy shit. One could come casual, but be warned as the food will be better dressed than you. My boyfriend and I are love, but he stared at this quail dish longer than he's ever stared at me. The service is borderline stalker, I like that a lot. Like others have posted, the Chef frequently makes the rounds throughout the dining room. We were not as fortunate but this gives yet another reason to make a return visit.

We were totally hyped up for this restaurant based on the chef's table episode highlighting Grant's work. But honestly, I felt that the staff was too informal for a "3 Michelin star restaurant". I was let down by this whole experience & in retrospect I regret having made that reservation months in advance. I do agree with the other critics on this yelp page. Don't say 10-14 courses if you're going to deliver the minimum number of courses.  And yes, the food was fine and there were some oddball flavor combos but I wouldn't say I HAVE to have that dish again. Most of the time I thought, wow this is different.

This place is so absurdly good that I can't even write a review for it. I'm lucky enough to have dined there twice; once in 2011 and again after the overhaul in 2017. The experiences and menus were totally different. For being one of the world's best restaurants, the staff is approachable and knowledgeable, and not the stuffy and cold stereotype of fine dining. Everything has been thought through and to end a meal literally laughing out loud is a pleasure that I don't think you expect going in. Was every dish a home run? Not exactly. But every dish made you reconsider your ideas about the ingredient presented.

*** 200th Review *** There was a lot of hype leading up to the reservation.  Shari V has watched the Chef's Table episode on Alinea thrice.  She is slightly obsessed with Chef Grant Achatz.  I'm glad he wasn't there there.  Her head would have exploded. We got tickets (aka reservations) to the Salon.  Gallery was booked up.  It took about 20 seconds for all the Gallery seating to be gobbled up on tocktix.  Beggars cannot be choosers.  We were just happy to get in.  The food was excellent.  Fantastic flavors with interesting displays, presentations, color combinations.  Because Shari V had researched so much about Alinea, I was not mind blown with the dishes.  We were expecting the helium desert balloons.  I thought these were fantastic.  For me, the lack of surprise did not take away from the dining experience.  I thought the food was delicious.  The atmosphere was slightly more casual than some of the other high end places we have dined.  Shari V and I both agreed the slightly more relaxed atmosphere was a welcome change of pace.   In short, our expectations were high.  Alinea delivered.  The put together a fantastic dinner.  We will repeat if we have the chance.  The reservations are pretty tough to secure.  We had to build our trip around the dinner reservation. #truefoodie

I think it's best to not read reviews, articles or watch any documentaries on Alinea or Chef Grant Achatz if you plan on attending this place. I knew enough but didn't want to research anymore because a place like this with all the accolades can set up really high expectations.  - Michelin Guide - 3 Stars - #15 in the World's 50 Best Restaurants - 2016 - Outstanding Restaurant in The United States, James Beard Foundation - 2016 This place is unique for sure and focuses on presentation and "the show" as it tries to confuse your senses and give you an experience.  They typically release bookings on the 15th of the month, two months in advance. Bookings are released at 11 AM Central Time. For our early June trip, my husband tried for a while to get reservations and ended up booking about 2 months ahead in The Salon @ Alinea. It's like buying a concert ticket for this place - you prepay for the experience and hope to god that you're feeling well and can make the trip there (if you're not from Chicago). There are 10-14 courses and the price is anywhere from $175-$255 per person. price includes food, service charge and taxes. In our very expensive Canadian $ conversion, that came to $640 CAD for two people. When you order a bottle of wine the night that you are dining, that is extra which of course is then another few hundred. So for Canadians if you order wine, expect that your total experience could be $400-$500 per person. Yes it is pricey. If you cancel ahead of time, your tickets are transferable to another visit but it's making the reservation that's the tough part. The dining room is quite surprisingly formal compared to the service and food. The servers are friendly and quite anal with service. While placing chopsticks for one course onto the chopstick rest, one stick fell off onto the table (not the floor) and the server took the set of chopsticks away and replaced the entire thing. LOL quite the overkill. Anyways, we enjoyed the sommelier, she was very knowledgeable and provided options that had a wide price range and didn't just push certain items. The meal lasted just over 2 hours with 10 courses so each course was roughly $32 CAD excluding the wine. Some items were better than others but overall I did enjoy my experience and it is something (if you are able to do) should try. The helium balloon was extremely fun, nostalgic and magical. We were to view the kitchen when we were leaving and man there are a ton of staff who work there and of course the serving staff. It's quite the operation that made for a fun and unique experience.

ALINEA! Alinea. A li nea.  What is there to say that hasn't already been said by the countless others who've also been blown away by their experience at this 3-star establishment?  Alinea is extra. AF. And I love it. The detail to which distinct aspects of your dining experience here is thought out is astounding. I'm one who's thrilled by restaurant service that caters to the diner down to the most minute detail, and needless to say, I left Alinea that night a very happy girl. From the twists and turns in the presentation, and unexpected flavors at every turn, Alinea provided me with an unprecedented and incredibly memorable dining experience. Many of my friends have asked me "was it worth it?". While nothing on this earth is worth the h e f t y ~$400 per person price tag in my opinion, it was nevertheless the best and most memorable dinner experience I've had. I loved 99.999% of the courses, but one that stood out to me the MOST(est) was the Thai Curry. HOLY MOLY. It brought back so many memories associated with my 4-year stay in Bangkok. Tip: If you failed to snag a reservation during their monthly releases, be sure to keep tabs on their Facebook posts! They often announce last minute availabilities--that was how I snagged a spot at the Gallery for 2, 5pm the very same day.  I'd say I'll be back! But then I'd have to go and find myself a sponsor.
If you have more money and pretension than taste and common sense, you'll fit right in.
Our entire meal was exquisite, and the artistry involved in both the crafting and presentation of the Gallery experience was phenomenal!

Definitely worth going to at least once in your life especially if you are a foodie. Every dish was delicious and meticulous made for you. It was really a wonderful experience that I recommend it to everyone. We didn't pair with wines because it was super expensive but we enjoyed every moment of it anyways!

Our visit to Alinea was extremely disappointing. This was the first ~$400pp meal we've had where we felt cheated and duped. There were a few high points but many, many more low points, and the lowest of lows included food that we could not even stomach to swallow. All the magic/whimsy and the immersive dining experience that Alinea is known for was missing. First of all, the ticketing system is pretty stressful. Pro tip if you decide to go against my advice and go to Alinea: look ahead at the two seating times and prices (which vary day to day), so you know exactly what you want when the ticketing system opens. The slots fill quickly. We bought tickets for a few hours after our flight arrived and stressed out about possibly missing our reservation. Onto the evening we ate at Alinea: it began with a lot of promise. We were led to a communal dining room with leaves on the floor and a delicious array of seafood items. One of the staff spoke to us as a group, but he was basically yelling at us for his voice to be able to reach to the other end of the long table. We were then led into the kitchen for a cooking demonstration and another course, which was interesting and tasty, and when we were taken back to the dining room, it had been transformed into tables and chairs. That was cool, and was followed by an amaaaazing corn soup with scallop noodles. But it went downhill from there. The next two courses triggered our gag reflexes, and I could not bear to finish mine. They were a sour coconut soup and an array of molecular gastronomy foods, including a jamon iberico foam and some soup of sorts with weird jellies in it. The texture and the tastes were disgusting and it got to the point where I feared bursting the jellies in my mouth lest they taste sour like vomit - sadly, that was what happened with almost every bite. Remembering that the meal cost ~$400, I begrudgingly forced myself to eat as much as I could. The next few courses were fish grilled over rosemary, short rib, and some other meat-based dishes that were good but sort of standard and not worth the price we paid for the meal. The desserts were more what we had expected (cherry flavored glass, banana helium balloons, the freeze dried ice cream), but it was still a bit lame. For example, there was a part where they turned off most of the lights and had loud music over the stereo while the staff took decorations off the wall to use as a plate, but you could see the stereo speakers all over the room.  The wine pairings were good but nothing too remarkable. All four of us were so disenchanted and let down by our experience. This was one of the main reasons we came to Chicago, and we felt bad that we made our friends who live in Chicago go there, although they would have gone at some point anyway.

Every course was a punch, surprise, interesting, beautiful, and delicious. Lots of Asian elements, i.e. Thai, China, Japan. It worth to plan a  trip to Chicago. Suggestion to the Management: You may want to consider increasing the light strength a little bit, and use some high frequency lighting sources. There is strong flicker effect (dark horizontal lines) for my camera. It also shows in other Yelper's post:)

So yes, I walked away saying:  "Jeez, I just spent $300 to eat foam".  But what foam it was.  The most creative, tasty, inventive and exciting place to eat.  The tasting menu with paired wine was fantastic.  The ambience was nice and the service was very very pleasant.  Not stuffy at all.  Some little bite came on a fork (or a spoon, I can't recall) and my date picked it up a little to aggressively to look at it, and the bite of food went flying across the room.  We all laughed hysterically, not at all uptight, and voila!, another bite of food quickly arrived.  Each tasting is small, but it's paced and when you leave, you feel sated and like a king.  Go.  Spend.  Enjoy.

Achatz and Bagale have created a masterpiece. Twice. Alinea's Kitchen Table experience isn't just food; it's visual art, it's theater, it's music. It's Mozart, it's Miles Davis, it's rock 'n' f**king roll. A group of us celebrated a variety of milestones at the Kitchen Table, which has an unbelievable view of (obviously) the kitchen. The food is magnificent, but I won't preview the experience by telling you what they'll serve or how they'll serve it. Alinea is more suspenseful and full of misdirection than a Christopher Nolan film, so it would be a crime to spoil it. Everyone who took part in the production was kind and welcoming. Our main server and sommelier were delightful. Chef Bagale was generous with his time. I'll be thinking about this meal for years.

I was really excited for this and waited months for these reservations. My husband and I were celebrating his culinary graduation, and we couldn't wait to eat here. Let me start by saying, that we tried to do the chef's table but it was sold out. So we opted for the 10-14 courses option.  The service was impeccable and the staff was super friendly. The servers were very informative and knowledgeable. The ambiance was pretty, we sat in a quiet room upstairs. It was simple, and nothing extravagant.  Now the food. After watching Alinea's episode on Chef's Table, watching online videos, browsing through their galleries...I had really high hopes. My expectations were high, but Alinea built those up for me. So course after course, as I was tasting each dish, I was disappointed. Many of the items I couldn't swallow down. There was no wow factor. Everything was so simple. One of the courses was just a simple broth. I understand that the techniques and preparations aren't simple, and time demanding - but this isn't what I came here for. Where is the wow factor? What Alinea presented on Chef's Table, and what we experienced, wasn't the same restaurant.  I really didn't like anything until the desserts. The dessert were delicious, but no wow factor. For one of the desserts, the restaurant used bubblegum Dippin' Dots. How is that fresh or life changing? You don't pay a few hundred dollars per person for Dippin' Dots. Safe to say, I was so disappointed. The only wow factor was the balloon. And that was it.  As I was browsing through their reviews, it seems like many people are saying the same thing. I'm sure when the chef was working for his stars a few years ago, the food was out of this world and so was the presentation. Since winning his stars, and beginning new projects - it seems like there is no passion left here. I'm leaving two stars here - one for the service and one for the desserts.

My wife and I emailed back in Nov 2016 about purchasing tickets in May 2017. Katie informed us they do not have those dates to sell yet. She informed us when those dates would go on sale and I marked it on my calendar. When the time came I went to purchase tickets for the gallery experience and they were already sold out. I copied and pasted past communication last with Katie and emails Alinea again to explain the situation and we followed instructions to book our tickets and they are already sold out. They contacted me back and said only the salon dinner was available and that's 10-14 courses.  We figured it was better than nothing at all and bought our tickets.. Alinea contacted us asking for food allergies and if we were celebrating anything in particular. We informed them we are celebrating something special and we are driving down from Michigan just for this dinner.  I have been following Grants work long before chefs table episode and his stars... This dinner was such a big deal for me as I have always looked up to his work that I have read about. Equipment like roto-vaps, and other uses of techniques I have admired.  Upon arriving at Alinea, I told my wife jokingly, I hope they don't give us the bare minimum of courses, but guess what, you did give us the bare minimum...  10 courses, They were as followed:  Ice, crunch, contrast, thai coconut, yellow, glass, bean, toast, rock, nostalgia. Why advertise 10-14 course when you already know you're going to give us the minimum. It's a marketing ploy that's why.  The only "experimental moment" we had received was when our server poured water into dry ice for our apple parm ice course.  I asked our captain if I could meet Grant and he said "he's at Next tonight for his Hollywood themed dinner, but if he was here, he doesn't meet with customers" Such a huge disappointment...  Before we left, I asked our captain if I could see downstairs before we left. He took us downstairs and made my wife and I stand flat up against the wall as to not get in anyone's way. We were not even in the door way of the kitchen, rather just before it.. I see Mike B. and he stops and stairs at us. He's standing there with his legs spread apart arms crossed just staring at us as if he wanted to destroy us.. My wife asked "why is he standing there like that?" "To lighten the mood I whispered to my wife "probably to leave room for his huge Schlong to get some air".. The captain then ushered us to the front door and said "he's really not as bad as you think once you get to know him".  For the love of everything Holy Mike, say hello. We were fans not enemies.  We drove all the way from Michigan to see you guys and enjoy your creations. We went back to our hotel feeling so down about the entire dinner.  I have studied Grants flavor bouncing techniques so I won't speak on specifics of flavor profiles in some of the dishes as taste is subjective.. I respect all he has accomplished, but that doesn't change the fact of what took place that night.  If there was one word to describe our experience at Alinea, that would be "cheated". We felt so cheated..  No one went the extra mile, everything was standard and bare minimum.  With travel, food, hotel and parking, I spent close to 1500 just to come to Chicago and dine with you.  I had brought my Alinea book thinking Grant would sign it, but he doesn't meet with customers or fans.  I left the book in my hotel room in Chicago. Maybe someone else will enjoy it.  I know I'm not wrong with the way I feel about this. I have read other reviews on Yelp that are pretty much the way I feel as of late. It's clear Grant has moved on from Alinea and is focused on other projects.. Which explains the experience we had. Alinea is obviously a cash cow that's being run on Auto pilot more or less.  As for me, this is a lasting impression I will forever have. This entire experience hurt me way more than this review will hurt them.

Stalking chefs is my new pastime. New as in several years new, but rarely do I succeed. This time perseverance and (a small) fortune made fate smile upon me. Was able to secure reservations with some friends while in town for the weekend, and it was a fantastic experience.  Had I wanted all you can eat chicken wings or expected "my money's worth," perhaps I would have been disappointed. But going in with an open mind, and just enjoying the experience made it worth every dime. The FOH staff is a well choreographed dance, and I appreciated the humor, dry wit and knowledge of their product. Our sommelier was amazing...I want to be her when I grow up. I'd love to come back and do the Kitchen Table experience! Ps... Accommodation for food aversions and allergies (all seafood in my case) was respected and equivalently addressed to a similar standard of my dinner mates.
Overrated. I did not love it as much as I was hoping. Grace was a far better experience.

I have wanted to dine at Alinea ever since I saw the Netflix Chef's Table episode on Grant Achatz.  Quite the story!   Unfortunately I was unable to get a table on the main floor for the full experience so we dined in the 'Salon'.  The depth and complexity of the flavors in each dish was amazing.  The presentation was unique and entertaining.    The pace of the meal was appropriate - never felt rushed but didn't drag either.

My boyfriend and I had dinner at Alinea on July 18th, 2015. I just wanted to write to express my disappointment. I had been looking forward to this meal for months. I made my boyfriend buy tickets the second they went on sale, anticipating the best dining experience I would enjoy in this lifetime. I expected the food to be innovative and interesting. I also expected that I would not necessarily enjoy everything, but I didn't expect what happened. The meal didn't start out well. I ordered a glass of wine and my boyfriend ordered a beer. I understand beer may not be the drink of choice for such a meal, but he brews beer and it is what he enjoys drinking. The sommelier overturned the beer into the glass and poured an entire glass of foam. If you don't want to serve beer, do not put it on the menu, but what happened was unacceptable at any restaurant, never-mind one of this caliber.  I should have prefaced this by saying that my parents had dined at Alinea less than a year before and raved about it. We all eat out quite a bit and are what you could consider "food snobs." Since my parents had excellent things to say, I thought the meal would be worth the price. However, we were fed course after course of disappointing food.  I have to say that we were served mostly vegetables. There was very little food of substance and I left the restaurant slightly hungry, which I would have thought inconceivable for the amount of money we paid.  The only food of substance was a piece of pork belly (90% of which was fat). I understand this is a fatty food by nature, but I have had much better pork belly at many restaurants across the country. There was also rabbit that was hard to identify as such.  There were some notably horrible moments. We were served the hot potato/cold potato dish, which was served in a wax bowl. The fragility and material of the bowl was not well explained and my boyfriend ended up ingesting a large piece of wax. To say that it did not pair well with hot and cold potatoes would be an understatement. The server was not particularly contrite about this incident.  The helium balloon was also another sour moment. The first balloon that was brought to my boyfriend had a large hole in it that was clearly visible so it deflated immediately. The waiter insisted that he had simply not eaten it quickly enough and grudgingly brought another.  There was also one course that included pieces of hamachi next to a "campfire." I have to say that it wasn't even close to the best piece of yellowtail I've ever had. I expected everything to be the best of the best.  We ate at Joe's Steak and Stone Crab later in our vacation and everything we ate during that meal was better than one single thing we ate during the course of our meal at Alinea. That does not add up to me. Joe's is fantastic but I thought Alinea would be the best meal of my life.  I felt as though we were being punked or had checked the vegan option by mistake, that was how poor the meal was. When I look back on the money we spent, I am horrified and saddened.  I have to say that I would never recommend this restaurant to another human being and that upon hearing of our experience, my parents said they will never go back. At the price, it is not worth the risk of a horrible meal.

Wow, wow, wow.  Loved every second of this experience.  The service is beyond impeccable, it is surprisingly intimate and friendly, and most of all fun.  Every interaction with every staff member was fabulous, absolutely fantastic.  Did I mention fun?  It is so weirdly tailored to each table and the respective guests,, the staff are experts and they made it an individual and wonderful experience. The atmosphere, decor, and ambience, also just wonderful.  Now, on to the food.  We did the salon, so 10 courses, plus the standard wine pairing.  I expected a presentation, and art, and interesting combinations of ingredients, and it's what we got.  But what blew my mind were the flavors.  I was blown away at how tasty every dish was.  I had a constant shocked, happy look on my face. I felt like a 1 year old eating her first bite of birthday cake.  Beside the flavor, each dish was gorgeous and fun to eat.  The balloon at the end, a definite happy, perfectly celebratory way to end the meal.   We had 10 courses, and we were all stuffed, plus a little tipsy from the generous wine and sake pairings.  Was it worth the cost on a Saturday night... yes, yes, yes.  I loved it.  What an incredible experience for us.

This was quite possibly the most magical experience I've ever had. From the moment we were seated, it was nothing less than a performance, not a typical meal. I mean, how many places serve food with dry ice and lavender? No detail was out of place. I was worried my eating stamina would run out as the journey continued, but everything was so wonderful that I had to try it all! Of course, the famous sugar balloons were the highlight!  The hospitality team was incredible. I was worried about accessibility for my mobility issues, but they were attentive to my needs and made sure nothing hindered my enjoyment. Only regret: not wearing sweatpants to accommodate for the massive amounts of food I consumed. Worth every dollar!!!

Wow! The new Alinea rocks. Totally different than the old one! I found the new version to be a great meal, as well as really cool and interesting. Great service, great dinner - not just an "in" restaurant but truly a great dinner. Some classics, some stuff that was "out there" but i left feeling like i had a great, great dinner!

Chefs table Netflix!? Sure!! For my birthday?? Double yes please! Kitchen table of all kitchen table. This was one of a kind!! And I have been to other incredible spots in US with 3 Michelin stars! I've been to 8 of them! This was my 9th in the states! ( we don't have that many!) And by far, the most unique experience.  Made a trip, flew here just for the meal at their kitchen table for my birthday last month! I would've came alone if needed be but found 5 other girlfriends who are willing to spend money on food! Girls rule! Boys drool! Ok ok boys can eat too, if they can get in :D I mean! Got into their super popular ( Thanks, Netflix's Chefs table), super long wait, super hard to get into kitchens table in an hour! Paid for our reservations within 30 minutes ( $500+ per person) and flights! We were excited!  The experience itself was over the top! Their champagne/ rose run around $295 and up per bottle. You can also try their cocktails! But the walk into this place itself was magic!  Our table settings and chandeliers changed many times through out our meal. The stunning display of ice, smoke, fire, tree, barks were all over the top! Unheard of! Kissing that helium balloon was definitely oh so fun! Oh yea, you can eat it too!! Being able to see the entire kitchen through our meal?! Yes! Got invited into the kitchen for their super special cocktail made from slushy machine! Yummm! Got some selfies! Wooot! Saw the magic up close! Yey! Caviar, chilled shrimp, coconut lime curry, foie gras! Hamachi on a bed of rosemary! And that amazing matcha dessert!! The finale is exactly how the whole meal feels like. EXPLOSION! The chandelier became the table, explosion of cakes, colors, sauces! With every single chef from the kitchen at your table!! What!! It was was 3 hours plurs of sensory explosion! And I got to do it all for my birthday!!! Thanks, girls for coming! And thanks Chef Grant and team for this magical birthday meal!!

First time dining at a molecular gastronomy place and I have to say I was surprised by many of the dishes (like who could thought a pinch of powder is actually made from ham and tasted just like the original source). It is like experience a science lab using your tongue! Each dish has a theme and you can find it on the puzzle they give you at the beginning of the meal. Especially loved the dessert, which is a balloon made from grapes and with helium gas inside, so that your voice becomes funny when you are trying to eat it, the string that is tie to it is sweet too. The service is really good, I accidentally had my balloon stuck to the artwork on the wall, they are very understanding and gave me a new balloon. Overall, I think the taste are ok, but I just really liked the concept and fascinated by the process the original source went through.

Truly a marvelous experience - be ready to be dazzled. As a sort of grand farewell to one of my favorite cities in the world, I decided to bring a couple of my closest friends to an evening at the legendary Alinea. I walked in the inconspicuous front door, expecting the same quiet intimacy that other restaurants of this caliber seemed to provide. Not so - the chatter and buzz was lively and guests enjoyed their shared memories of the unique experience. The layout of the restaurant is modern. My party ascended the stairs up to the Salon area, arriving at the seats that we had to book months in advance. The staff approached and provided fun conversation similar to how a grand performance has an MC. Except this was much more intimate. I won't spoil the dinner but I will say that you should be prepared to be dazzled, surprised, and enlightened. My particular tasting menu had an Asian spin on it, but the elements of sci-fi definitely shown through. Not all dishes were coherent to the theme and some seemed to be a little too gimmicky, but the meal came together and definitely left us satisfied.  Give Alinea a shot - you won't regret it.

I was so so excited to go when I learned about Alinea. I had tried some smaller tasting menus in Chicago and this was the real deal. I got my boyfriend and I tickets as a celebration of him getting a really great new job offer. We went to the aviary for drinks before hand, I had my makeup professionally done, and spent nearly half a paycheck on 1 dress because this was going to be the fanciest dinner of my 24 year old life. I was very disappointed with the drink options, it was pretty much buy the wine add on for another couple hundred, or drink water, and since neither of us enjoy wine, we went with water. I felt like the food tried so hard to push boundaries that it lost sight of actually tasting good. I'm pretty adventurous with food and will eat anything except cole slaw, so when I say the two of the courses were straight up nasty, I mean it. One was this little cube of what I can only assume was jellofied sardine oil. It was awful. Another one was just one bite but it was so overwhelming it left me with like feeling that I had eaten an entire bag of lays potato chips in one bite. Not to mention, we left alinea and ordered a pappa Johns pizza on the taxi ride home because we were both still so hungry. The dessert course was the only part of the whole experience that I truly enjoyed

Update:  The manager sent a personal email to us with sincere apologies. We were disappointed about the hair but are very happy about their after service. The personal email showed that the restaurant does care about their customers afterwords. It was nice of them. Modified my star back to 5 -------------- I would give it 5 stars but I had to give it 3 because... It was a very great experience! However, there was a little bit of hiccup during our experience. There's a hair in my wife's dessert . It was very nice that the manager came out to apologize and our waiter gave my wife a candle to blow as a special treat. But still.... Alinea was one of the only two Michelin stars restaurant in Chicago, and it was rated top 10 best restaurants in the world by TripAdvisor. There shouldn't be a hair in my wife's plate... the experience was great but the hair on her plate kinda ruin her mood. I just glad that it happened at the end, not at the beginning of the course.

I've never worked so hard to get a reservation in my life but well worth it.  This was of course before the move to the ticketing system.  Overall as expected everything was great.  What stood out was the dessert preparation and presentation.  They literally create art in front of you and then you have to eat it.  I absolutely loved the experience.

When asked "if the food was even good?", the only appropriate response is "it wasn't immediately satisfying like eating a burger or slice of pizza, but it was nuanced and intellectual; it was like eating a book".   Was the Kitchen Table worth it? HELL YES!  If it is within your means I would highly recommend springing for Alinea's most personal experience.  I booked the Kitchen Table on a whim for our cousins reunion, and, honestly, was blown away.  There's a reason why Alinea's accolades and reputation precedes it.  The meal was an entire experience from beginning to end; watching the almost meditative zen of the kitchen prep; chef Achatz in action (we even got a photo of our group with him...sorry for being those people); the super cool and down to earth wait staff; and no detail was spared to customize our own unique dining experience.  One of my favorite moments was when they plated the famous "paint" dessert.  Our server pulled out a ladder and took down a piece of the art hanging from the ceiling that would serve as our dessert plate.  Chef Achatz came and finished everything off by crushing the last liquid nitro concoction into a million pieces for the finale.  That was awesome and amazing, but it was the littlest details that truly made it special; the fact that they turned off ALL of the lights in the kitchen during dessert plating leaving everyone working in the dark and played an amped up song about cousins to highlight our "cousins reunion" that I'd included in our reservation notes.   It was an experience that will not be soon forgotten. Bravo Alinea!

This was an incredible dining experience. The staff was incredibly accommodating and kind, the chef was wonderful in handling my dietary restrictions, and the food and drinks themselves were impeccable. Going to Alinea is like going to an art gallery, every course placed in front of me was an exquisite work of art that was beautifully presented.

Simply outstanding! Truly deserves a top 10 spot in the world. Presentation, experience and quality if food is excellent. Attention to detail is fantastic.  They make it look all so easy. Makes you wonder why other restaurants can't emulate it. It really is not as easy as it looks. A lot of planning, prep and practice has most likely gone into it. Very clearly a class apart. The second course was served in the kitchen. Kitchen was squeeky clean. The reconfigured the seating area in the meantime. The last desert course just capped the night off perfectly. Good tea selection as well. Great attitude from the staff. Professional, always around, yet not too intrusive or uptight either. Just the right level of friendliness. Overall a great great experience. Must do once, especially if you live in Chicago. We made the reservations 3 months in advance for a party of 4. If you are 6, then definitely do the chef's table.

What happened here? I expected an experience of a lifetime, just like my first visit, but this meal fell short. This meal lacked passion and excitement.  First of all, appearance wise, the renovations were beautiful but I miss walking in to sights of the kitchen! The energy and brightness were palpable in 2012.  Service was OK. My servers were very knowledgeable. One of them was dicking around a tad too much for a Michelin starred restaurant. My sommelier was swift and knowledgeable but I loved my sommelier from five years ago.  As for the food.... I remember being served food on pillows of fragranced air, eating without utensils, and using more of my senses. This time around I actually felt like I was at a restaurant. Eating a meal. I paid for an experience! A show! My server even agreed with me that my first experience was more of an art show and this was a meal. Anyway, the flavors were alright. For some reason they did not meld well with me. The Thai inspired dish was pretty delicious. The langoustine noodles were also delicious. Bubble yum dessert was less than satisfying but I'm not a bubble gum fan. I feel like every course that I tried in 2012 was out of this world. This time around I left food on the plate.  Lastly, I wanted to experience an elegant dinner. I looked around and I saw a man and woman in casual street clothes CHOMPING DOWN on their food. It was disgusting. I don't pay hundreds of dollars to sit next to a guy in a hoodie and sneakers slurping on an overpriced noodle.  Agh, Alinea. You've lost your charm. Maybe I'll be back when you step up your game.

This restaurant delivered to me the finest meal I have ever experienced. We had saw this restaurant on Netflix Chef Table and have been itching to go there ever since! As we were led to the newly renovated restaurant we were curious and anxious about the meal to come. We were definitely not disappointed! We were given attic char roe paired with tropical fruit in these different powders and gels. Then we got our favorite dish of the night- puréed dehydrated langoustine which is kinda like a shrimp kinda like a lobster floating in saffron broth. Holy crap it was to die for! This was followed by melt in your mouth short ribs, crispy sushi rice with bone marrow and much much more. Another great touch was the fantastic tea selection and the sugar balloon filled with helium that makes the whole dining room laugh along with you. Another point is that when you walk in it seems kind of stuffy and quiet and it is as if by magic that the atmosphere starts to loosen up and you can really have the dinner of a lifetime. We were disappointed that Grant was not there but his visions and his dishes and his creativity and his presence could really be felt in the food and I think that that is the most important part. In all my years as a yelper and as a human, this was my best meal, by far!

Great experience, but not the level of professionalism I was expecting. My husband and myself flew to Chicago for the purpose of having dinner at Alinea to celebrate a friend passing a pretty major exam. The four of us were excited for our reservation, and the creativity Grant Achatz is so famous for. He definitely did not disappoint. I feel like it would be a disservice to describe each dish in detail, as part of the experience was the surprise each course brought. Just know that the meal serves generous portions, a true 5-senses experience, and they DO still have the taffy balloons! The disappointment in our experience came from one of the runners (dressed in all black uniform). Maybe it was because Grant Achatz was out of town... maybe he is always this way... but his particular brand of insult humor was a bit off-putting. Fortunately, the rest of the staff were wonderful and even gave us recommendations for our remaining day (Sun Wah was awesome, thank you!). Lastly, I had emailed ahead of time to let them know that we were celebrating. Alinea responded saying that they couldn't guarantee the capacity, but would be sure to acknowledge the occasion in some way. Unfortunately nothing was said or done. The guest of honor didn't know that we had emailed ahead, so she wasn't disappointed, but it was frustrating that they couldn't at least give her a congratulations.

This is definitely a restaurant that requires you to bring good company because you are going to be here for a while. The presentation of the food is outstanding and the taste matches the presentation. Everything's the waiter brought to the table was enticing to the palette. The multi-course meal will definitely have you chatting about the chef's skills and leave you wanting to return for a repeat experience.

Alinea has been on the top of my list ever since I watched the Chef's Table series on Netflix. The accumulated awards over the years can only side-prove its excellence and uniqueness, you need to be here and experience it. As a friend described, it's beyond the "a delicious meal" category, it is more of an experience that would have won Tony awards. Flawless preparation and creative presentation (wow moments), easy and personal interactions with all the staff, and the most unique part is the unlimited imaginations inspired by the dishes -- all above were my impression of the night. The low key entrance and a long corridor bring guests to the magical world of Chef Grant Achatz just like the closet to Narnia. The whole space is painted in sedated airy white and grey with a few artistic paintings and statues as decorations, and a curvy staircase connecting the first and second floors.  Aside from the fun and cool helium balloon, I also deeply enjoyed nostalgia! The fruity and slightly artificial smell is just the same smell of the bubble gums I used to love as a kid. It is like a time-travel train that brings me back to all those good old memories just like many other dishes here that can transcend the concrete dishes to memories/inspirations.  Our waiter was also kind enough to offer us a short kitchen tour after the meal and let us watch chefs putting together the final table dessert from the staircase. Thanks again for hosting us! Food as a medium at Chef Grant's master hands, serves an unforgettable experience at Alinea. Note: Reservation took decent effort (secure a booking online plus coordinate back and forth), so many thanks to my dear friend E who made this trip happen!
Was fortunate enough to eat at the Chef's table. I became upset near the end of the meal because it slowly began to dawn upon me that I will likely never have a better dining experience in my life.
The ambiance, the service, the food, the experience, everything is amazing. We went to celebrate an occasion and couldn't have been happier with our choice. It's worth every penny!

I went here because of the hype I have heard about this place. VERY VERY Pricey, but REALLY good food. I can't wait to save up my pennies to go back for the new remodel that's been done to the place. My only complaint was that my husband left feeling a little hungry. Besides that, excellent staff and a excellent experience.

Top avant-garde dining experience. 21 in the world (World's 50 best, 2017). We made our reservation 2-3 months in advance for the Gallery. After spending a small fortune ahead of time, we were more than intrigued to see if Alinea would live up to the hype and/or compare to other Michelin restaurants of this caliber.  Pros: -Newly renovated interior, still intimate yet simple. -Elements of surprise/show. -Staff: Brad, Miguel, everyone was amazing.  -Attentive to allergies. -Experiencing the Alinea kitchen: very smart idea. -Drink pairings not mandatory for the whole table if one person opts for it. - The iconic taffy "helium balloon" and grand finale dessert were everything we had anticipated, and more.  Seriously mind-blown.  -The number of desserts in the tasting menu--perfect for me as it is my favorite course.  -Thai inspired dish: outstanding. My one point of contention:  We had the 9:30 pm seating. I personally felt as though the pace of the courses after the second one went very fast and by the end of the savory courses, I felt overwhelmed as the food is quite decadent (ie. black truffle mousse, caviar, lobster, more black truffle sandwich, wagyu beef, bone marrow, mushroom).  I'm surprised to read that anyone would leave Alinea hungry because this to me seems impossible.  The staff, however, were very gracious and we stayed for as long as we wanted.

Exquisite. I know that sounds douchey, but it is. It's also worth every penny. Lastly, don't be an asshole and dress up for this occasion.  It will feel like an event and you should treat it as one because it's evident that thoughtfulness and creativity are driving values here.

One of the most amazing experience I've ever had. The service is amazing and the food is something that I've never had before such as molecular food!
