We had wine paired to each dish and the pairing was well done.  Even if the experience is VERY expensive I really recommend going as a once in a lifetime event. Take the wine pairing offering since it will take your dinner to the next level.

Ever since I have watched Chef's table, I started to count down days till I could actually sit inside chef Grant Achatz's flagship and have my taste bud dancing with his ingredients. It was certainly not an easy task to nail a reservation; however everything was well worth all the efforts once sitting inside the fairy, where all my dreams started. My most memorable experience was the moment when a balloon was brought to us, exactly the way as shown in the episode. Carefully grabbed, and sip a hole in the center, deep breath, and speak! Yes, hearing myself in a different voice was indeed fascinating. Grant was just a genius! My favorite dish, on the other hand, was that seared bone marrow - sitting nicely on a small rice cracker, the bone marrow was not at all greasy while somehow maintained its own softness. Such a delightful bite! I guess started from today, I have officially updated my favorite place for bone marrow (used to be Casa Mono). Food always came secondary, once you realized how difficult Grant has come through his recovery from the cancer, and that was precisely the reason I loved Alinea so much. It was a tough job to bring a restaurant to Michelin three-star; it was an impossible one to bring himself to a next level.  I felt blessed being able to have a little taste of what Grant and his team has been through, and I cannot wait to come back and try their true Gallery experience.

Wish I could give them more stars. No words can express how much I enjoyed this restaurant. An experience unlike anything else, Alinea serves highly creative and equally delicious food. From the edible balloon filled with helium to eating dessert off the table, I was happily entertained from beginning to end (and so was my stomach). My friend and I did the wine pairing with our meal and thoroughly enjoyed it, but would probably not do the wine pairing next time around (it got me more tipsy than I would have liked to be). Would come back here in a heartbeat! Yes it was a pricey meal but well worth it. An experience here is priceless.
Awesome courses. Dining experience was amazing but I did leave slightly hungry. Other than that, it's a must try.

I had the 10 course meal for $270 here. This was definitely one of the top, if not THE top dining experiences I've ever had. Grant Aschatz menu and dishes brought out tastes and sensations I didn't know was possible. The food was superb, except for one close miss on the Wagyu short rib. My favorite was definitely the helium balloon candies and the fish with mango curry. The experience was enhanced by all the waiters, who interacted with teh guests and had the same 'false serious' sense of humor that provided lots of laughs for us. I would definitely keep coming back, and vegetarians, don't despair! They can do substitutions.  Will definitely try to come back if I'm ever in Chicago again.
interesting dishes.  servings were too large for the 12-13 courses we had (each paired with wine), i was stuffed and felt sick by the end.

We loved "it" - So much has been said - the fame is well deserved and for all the right reasons - Alinea is a unique and exciting experience (the experience is the "it") - the service it top notch, and nothing is overlooked.  The food is as unique and clever, almost on ther verge of something fantastic.  Though not as exciting or in hindsight as tantalizing as the experience in total - including the real magic of the evening afforded by the careful planning of the staff - the thought behind the story unfolding as your dinner goes is obvious and deserving of the five stars.   The planning and excitement for the evening were justified, though, now that it's been experienced the enduring memory is and will continue to wane.

This is the best dining experience I've ever been treated too. Unlike most 2 to 3 Michelin star restaurants you are not entangled in the hoity toity atmosphere that other restaurants make you feel. It's still incredibly classy but the wait staff has an ability to make you feel comfortable and helps you get ready for the food experience of a lifetime. We went on a Sunday night for Alinea 2.0 in the Saloon and were in for a treat from the wait staff knowing my girlfriend was left handed to learning i was from Portland, OR and the head barista bringing me some very interesting coffees at the end of the night. My expectation for the food was incredibly high and was hoping that everything would be experiential while not losing the food. I wasn't disappointed at any of the 10+ courses we had. The evening culminated with a dish called Nostalgia that gave me an interaction with food that i never had in that it immediately transported me back to little league baseball and bubble gum without making it feel like a gimmick. Although, ever dish had it's own highlights i was really hoping that we would get to try the famous sugar balloons and luckily on this night we were treated with a banana helium taffy balloon which in and of it's self is a special dish. If you ever get the opportunity to try this fantastic restaurant know that the price tag doesn't just include your food but an experience with food like no other.

I came to Alinea with the boo on a double date. I had been looking forward to coming here for I don't know how long so I was super pumped the day of our reservation. I was expecting to have an dining experience unlike any other. Unfortunately, I left Alinea feeling underwhelmed.  Upon walking in we were greeted by a host and hostess who made small talk with us while we waited for our friends to arrive. Once our friends got there we were escorted to our table on the second floor. I was blown away by the decor of this place. Top notch for sure! Our service during our entire experience was exceptional.  Food wise I was meh. Some courses were good, ok and forgettable. Only one or two courses made me feel like I my taste buds were experiencing something special. While the decor and service were 5 stars, I came here and paid for the food which gets 3 stars. Personally, I think there are better tasting menus out there in Chicago. Just my opinion.

I could go on and on about our experience at this restaurant but it would not do it justice. We sat in the gallery and the evening was more than magical. Chef Grant has created something that we will talk about forever. This was well worth our trip to Chicago for the weekend. The food and sensory experience was amazing and although describing it further would probably not diminish anyone's awe over it, I won't do so. I'm sure others have already. If you can get in, take the opportunity and just go. I will take a sentence or two to state that I don't drink and they concocted several incredibly delicious non-alcoholic cocktails just for me.

It was a great experience, but some of there food (especially the dessert of tropical fruit) had flat notes in flavor and were mediocre. But the plating and design was great! The service was the best I have experienced. I'd like to compliment the great manners and positive attitude that the servers had. It was a great experience!
This place is meant to be experienced. Reserve many hours of your evening to indulge and bask in the genius of Grant Achatz's molecular gastronomic creations.

I went in October of 2015 for my bday, so some time ago and before the remodel. Excellent and personable service, with the professionalism you would expect but also with a personality. Ideal for my taste as a twenty something. Highlights were the one bite truffle explosion, leaf three kinds of duck course, the taffy balloon and the special dessert course where Chef plates it himself! Hoping to return maybe this year.
A phenomenal experience! The service, food, and atmosphere are amazing. Every little detail is thought out. I'd definitely go to the Gallery if you can. My sister and I loved it!

We went to Alinea with extremely high expectations, and they were far exceeded. Their molecular gastronomy menu was simply outstanding. All of the 18 entrees had something peculiar, a flavor that I have never experienced  before. The wine pairings,  along with the desserts were simply out of this world.

How can I not give these fine folks five stars?  This was simply the most outrageous and over-the-top dining experience ever in my life.  The levels of presentation and production are unlike anything I could have expected, no matter how many times I've watched their Netflix special. I don't want to spoil the experience by taking readers here through every step of the meal.  Just know that if you select the intermediate experience known as "The Gallery," you've got between 16 and 18 of the most diverse and wonderfully crafted courses that a restaurant will put in front of you.  And buckle up, because they keep you flush with nourishment for the better part of three hours. I did select the standard wine pairing and was beyond satisfied.  Everything we drank was excellent, specifically the Bollinger champagne to start the night off, and the Jamsheed Syrah later in the meal.   As for the food, every course is meticulously assembled and presented in very unique ways.  Fire, fog, and art pieces integrated throughout the meal are just some of the inventive methods used to augment each element of the culinary experience.  It is all tastefully and seamlessly integrated into the evening.  And the flavors?  You can't help but be absolutely blown away. If I had any criticism, it would be in the last third of the meal.  We were presented with a short rib dish that was the most intensely flavored food I have ever encountered personally.  It was very good, but I felt absolutely washed over with the taste.  Again, not bad; just intense.  From there, the desserts started to flow in and things became almost saccharine sweet.  It was just too much to digest and was mostly paired with an equally sweet Moscato d'Asti.  If you saw the final dessert dish, you'd understand why we could barely make a dent in it even if we wanted to.  Still, it was all top quality; just not how I would have preferred to finish things off.  I could have stopped three to five courses from the end and still been completely satisfied. There was, however, one other element that arguably trumps the food.  That's the staff. These men and women are absolutely first-class.  There were so many players throughout the night, that I probably can't account for all of them.  Forgive me on any spelling errors, but I must recognize Kalen, Devin, Michael (sommelier), Bronson, Quincy, John, Tim (the original host with wild hair), Yuweh, and Brian.  These kind people made our experience so great!  They were all so personable and took absolutely great care of not just us, but also everyone in the room. What I would recommend is playing back a little with the staff.  I'm not talking about being disruptive, just show them a little character and humor.  They're super down to earth.  Imagine some of the stodgy characters they must come up against in this joint.  Trust me, the more candor and good humor you show them, the more they'll play back and help you enjoy this most exquisite experience. Is it expensive?  No question.  Is it worth it?  Absolutely.  Zero regrets. Pony up the cash, strap in, and get ready for a dining experience that only a select few people on this earth will ever encounter.  What Chef Achatz and his remarkable team have created here is nothing short of astounding.  I meant what I said when I described it as "the most outrageous and over-the-top dining experience ever in my life."  It is just that.  But my God is it cool.   It's no wonder many pundits in the culinary industry consider Alinea to be among the finest restaurants in the entire world.  There's nothing else quite like it. Bon appétit!

Alinea has been one of my holy grail restaurants to try and after finally getting the chance to dine here, I am indoctrinated to the Achatz empire.  Reservations were fairly easy to get, there wasn't a clear understanding of when they would be releasing the next batch of dates but it was okay.  I'll say it once...it's not just dinner, it's an entire experience. From the moment you come into the restaurant to as you're putting your jacket on to leave, the staff are attentive and gracious. The decor is clean and refined. The entire restaurant doesn't have a whiff of snobbery. The food taps into old memories and senses while still pushing forward. There were a few dishes that weren't up my alley but you can still appreciate them (and they're still pretty yummy). Our dinner at Alinea is a very fond memory that I'll treasure.

It's beyond expectations, it delivers on a heavenly level.  Every detail is a reflection of the culture and care Chef Grant has created for an unbelievable experience.  The food is incredible, but it's beyond about that.  It elevates you to a unique food experience that pushes you to a place of giddiness and delight.  Our server Bo guided us elegantly and entertainingly through the 4 hour journey.  We had the standard wine pairing as we didn't go with wine snobs and the pairing was so complimentary.  Makes me want to go back and try it with the reserve.  Beyond recommended, it does not disappoint!

The hype is real, Alinea is amazing. Classy without being pretentious, entertaining without being cheesy, and most importantly the best food I've ever had. If you've seen chef's table on Netflix with Grant you'll understand how thoughtful and focused he is as a chef. It's very apparent in the food, as each course is not only an awesome congregation of ingredients and flavors but each own individual experience. I'm not spoiling any of the content because being surprised by each course is half the fun. The space has a great ambiance, the kitchen is bright and immaculate, and the staff works like a fine tuned machine. From the chefs to the waiters there is a synchronicity and order that's super impressive to watch, but they are also all very lighthearted and easy going at the same time. Except Grant, that's a look of focus a true professional and artist has when taking their craft so seriously. No doubt he's an easy going guy, but in the kitchen dude's lasered in.

The experience cannot be replicated, our party of 6 flew in from NYC and we had the best seats in the house. A truly once in a life time dining experience, I would not however be a repeat diner at this establishment. As with other restaurants of this caliber it's more about the all in experience and how the food was prepared rather than the flavors, a lot of the flavors just mesh together and don't differentiate themselves. Alinea is a must try for foodies but know what you are getting yourself into as it was the most expensive meal I have ever experienced.

This is the finest restaurant in America period! Any moron who gives this magnificent restaurant less than five stars deserves to burn in hell! I've dined in NYC, San Francisco, and LA and frankly all those cities had a laughable representation of what "Fine Dining" is....... Alinea challenges the cliches and would fit in quite well in Europe and unlike most of you pretentious yelpers I've actually dined in Paris, Madrid, and Berlin! How many have you done that?  I know what the hell i'm talking about so visit this restaurant if you can actually afford it and enjoy!! James........

This is not dinner, this is an experience. This is not food, this is art. This is 3 hours of a multi-sensory event.  My husband and I have had Alinea on our wish list for 3 years. When we were finally able to get a table for 2 in the Gallery, I couldn't believe it. We dined there Sunday night at the 5p.m seating. Like everyone else says, from the moment you walk in until the moment you leave you feel like you're in another world. The atmosphere and the ambiance is chic and calm. The waitstaff is professional, charming, and funny. It's not at all stuffy or uncomfortable. All the food is fresh, the absolute highest of quality, and combines flavors and senses that you never thought possible. Spoiler alert, for the second course you get the privilege and honor of going IN the kitchen, what an absolute treat to see the behind the scenes work! I will say what I appreciated most was the pace of the evening. We've done other tasting dinners that have lasted 5, almost 6 hours. All of the courses at Alinea were perfectly timed, and they gave us plenty of time at the end to sit and enjoy a cup of tea. We left around 8:15, and didn't feel overly stuffed. All the courses are so memorable, it's almost impossible to pick a favorite. In terms of the flavors and presentation I may say that dessert was my favorite, so be sure to save room!  I hope to be able to dine at Alinea again some day. Although the cost is about as much as a vacation when you add a bottle of wine in, the memories will stay with us forever. Thank you to all the staff, and the mastermind Chef Grant Achatz!

My friends and I had the good fortune to reserve the Kitchen Table for dinner on a Sunday evening. We all chose the mid-level wine tier for pairing, which was the one thing I think I was disappointed in. The choices were wonderful, high-quality producers and varietals, but I personally am not a fan of sherry or sake, so a few of the offerings were just lost on me. We are all well-versed in wine and felt that choosing bottles over a tiered tasting would have been better, but it would have been tough to appropriately pair the wines without knowing the menu and flavor profiles in advance.  As for dinner...I don't even know where to start, lol. Everything was amazing, from the moment we arrived to the moment we departed. The service was attentive and relaxed- far from the pretentious impression I was given by some of the other reviews I read. The staff joked with us, took the time to explain what we were trying, and what made each dish unique.  I don't even want to spoil the surprise and fun by going into more depth regarding the food, lol. Only one item was unanimously disliked, the rest were well above expectation. Chef Achatz was kind enough to take a moment to greet us and have a photo taken with our group- many thanks to him! His staff is clearly as well-trained, creative and detail-oriented as he is. Tips? No need to dress to the nines...we chose "business casual" and were quite comfortable. I'm not sure the Kitchen Table experience warranted the additional cost, as the other diners seemed to receive the same items and attentive service, but being able to let loose without worrying about disturbing other diners was a nice touch. If you have a rowdy group, it might be worth the expenditure. I was a bit intimidated by the prospect of spending almost $2k per couple on a dinner, but I have to say that it was worth it. Next on the bucket list: French Laundry!!

A night at Alinea is more than just about the food. It truly is an experience, from the moment you step in the door to the moment you leave. As soon as we stepped inside, we were greeted by 3-4 people who took our coats and brought us to the table. The decor is modern and clean. Throughout the whole night, we had 3-4 waiters roaming around at our service. They were all entertaining in their own way and one guy in particular was quite a hoot. They all looked like they loved their job which definitely helps enhance the dining experience. It was a 11 course meal and while I'm not going to describe all of them, I can tell you that all of them were amazing in their own way (with the exception of one but probably because I don't like cheese in general). Every course is innovative and exceptional in both presentation and flavor. Every dish is different and exciting in their own way, some which you can't even figure out how to eat without a description from the waiter. Some of the highlights of the evening included condensed strawberry desert with bubble gum ice cream and cherry "glass" which was a perfect end to the evening with an ice cold desert prepared likely with liquid nitrogen. The other dessert themed around chocolate and "rocks" was almost as good and even prettier to look at. The Thai-inspired coconut shellfish broth with pompano was probably the best dish of the night and one of the best I've ever had even though I don't typically like coconut flavors. Just stunning. The wagyu short rib with bitter cocoa sauce was incredible. As with a lot of the dishes, it truly is tough to put the flavor into words. This is one of those you have to try for yourself to really understand the flavors. The prettiest plate of the night (perhaps in a tie with the "rocks" dessert) was the maitake mushroom dish with a duo of sauces made based around blueberry and lapsang souchong (a Chinese black tea). The best smelling dish of the night goes to the corn soup with scallop "paper" which had an aroma to die for. They dehydrated scallops into papers which were re-hydrated into noodles when the hot corn soup was poured over it, amazing! It's definitely expensive (the most expensive meal I've ever had) but it's worth every last penny with the overall experience that's provided. This is obviously only for a special occasion for the vast majority of people, but I highly recommend it.

We absolutely hated it.  I'm giving two stars because of the ambiance I guess.  I wrote the below email to Alinea customer service. They wrote me back to tell me that they take complaints "very seriously" then never responded back months later. Don't waste your money. To whom it may concern, On December 7th, 2016, my girlfriend and I visited the Alinea Gallery for a much anticipated experience.  We had seen Grant Achatz on Chef's Table, Spinning Plates and several interviews; needless to say, we were very excited.  They initially sat us at a group table for the first course.  For an $800 tab I expected a private, secluded table with private service.  The first course was terrible.  The egg souffle was bland, the pickled lobster and truffles were just not our preference.   They then moved us to the kitchen for the second course.  Again, same complaint, we didn't need to see the kitchen and it seemed tacky.  Next, we ordered a Cabernet, they served us a Bordeaux without asking us if that was ok; it tasted nothing like a Cab. They then sat us down at a private table for the third course.  From this point on, we were extremely disappointed.  I'm afraid to say, without exaggerating, that neither of us like one bite one of course.  It was all overwhelmed with, what we think was, sassafras.  It was a sort of pungent licorice taste.  We tasted this strange flavor in almost every dish.  It was all odd and off-putting. We also expected more elaborate gastronomy experimenting.  We've seen the balloon in documentaries, which was an odd fake banana flavor, and the ice cream, which tasted like freezer burned dip-n-dots (no offense intended, that's the only parallel I can draw). I don't like to write reviews and I certainly don't mean to offend.  But, our disappointment in this experience bordered on depressing.  We were dumbfounded.  I just felt compelled to provide you with some feedback.
A night at Alinea is more than just about the food. It is truly an unforgettable experience from the moment you arrive till the moment you leave.

Nothing will ever compare to this magical place. I have no words yo describe the wonder and surprise. Every taste touches every sense. A masterpiece amongst the finest restaurants in the world. Prepare yourself for an unforgettable experience

A visit to Chicago in the beginning of January can be brutal. It's cold, but then the wind makes it brutally cold...Or maybe I'm just a wimp when it comes to cold weather. A visit to Chicago that includes a trip to Alinea, eventhough its in January though...that makes it all worth it. I came here this last month. It was my second visit, five years removed from the first visit. The inside changed a little bit because of the renovation. I mostly remembered that it used to be a little brighter. But no complaints either way. The service, as everyone mentions is fantastic. The service staff that helped us that night was great and very, very fun. When people ask me what my favorite restaurant experience anywhere is, I always say Alinea because it is "fun". I was reminded that this was because of the great staff. The food is *exceptional*. Everything looks beautiful. On the "menu" card each course is described by a single word. It's then presented and carefully explained. The courses are also playful. They asked me not to cheat and look at other tables to peek and see what is coming ahead. But then of course the couple to my right would look over from time to time when food was brought to my table. They were several courses ahead, and wanted photos of the courses being served...and the magic that happens. We'd chat about what courses I would expect to see next, etc. I felt like a kid filled with anticipation...and they were giddy watching others experience what they had discovered only minutes before as well. Like I said, it is a lot of fun. The staff called and took note of my allergies several days before the visit. The menu was slightly adjusted to meet my constraints. I didn't feel like I experienced anything drastically different from anyone else in the restaurant. That made it pretty nice. Obviously the menu had changed since my last visit. There's no point in my going into specific dishes because I think others will want to experience for themselves, but also because the items might be different by the time they visit the restaurant  themselves. The helium filled candied balloon that you're supposed to make out with is still on the menu **phew**. The dessert/art created on the table was not.  Can't wait until I come back in another 5 years!

Dining at Alinea really is an experience. It's fun, unexpected and, of course, absolutely delicious. I don't even think delicious accurately describes how amazing the food was. It kinda makes you think about food in a different way. You would never expect to taste certain flavors together or for familiar foods to be presented with an entirely different texture. The food was just so interesting and innovative. I had an amazing time. I think I went with the "2nd tier experience" with the wine pairing (which really added to the experience).

It's hard to pull together all the adjectives necessary to describe what a great experience this was. It began with a 3 course starter and cocktail at the communal table. Next, we were ushered it to the kitchen to observe the chefs preparing the feast for the night and given an "old school" cocktail shaker demonstration. Afterwards, back to our seats in the original room, but divided in to parties again and with our friends who attended. Now it was on to the 10-12 additional courses that were between bite size and 2 - 3 bite size. We did received a menu for the evening, but the course names would not tell you much about what we actually ate. There were some amazing bites and presentations. Without giving it all away - two that stick in my head are an amazing pork belly dish that was two bites (and about 8 bites short of what I wanted) and a corn soup that started from thinly shaven gel (I know sounds weird, but it was amazing) that was rehydrated with corn stock. All the other bites in between were all equally amazing and I definitely left full. Trust me, I am a big guy and was very skeptical after the first course. You will pay handsomely for this experience, but if you are a true "foodie" you will not be disappointed.

BF took me here last summer when I was in Chicago. Was absolutely mind blown by the creative concept and the quality of food. Fave course was hands down the scallop soup and the helium balloon. It was so fun to be able to talk in a ridiculously high voice. We also got to chat with Mike, the executive chef, after the dinner and took a look at the kitchen. Only bummer is that the head chef, Grant (dude who was on chefs table), was down the street at another restaurant that night so we didn't meet him.  Great restaurant deserving the three Michelin stars, and definitely planning to come back in the future. :)

What can I say that hasn't already been said?  The service here is top-notch from the moment you walk in the door all the way until you leave. In fact, the host even walked us next door to Boka where my friend and I had some post-Alinea cocktails. That was a special touch.  Back to the food and dining experience, though. One thing that I appreciated was how Alinea was able to accommodate a strict vegetarian diet. It's rare to find a place that is conscientious of gelatin, etc. This is all to say that the kitchen here is incredibly accommodating and will work with you to address your specific dietary needs. It's not like they just took out the meat, either. The substitutions made it such that my dining partner and I were able to experience similar flavors and textures throughout the meal.  Speaking of flavors, I have never experienced some of those tastes before. I don't even know how to describe some of the dishes to my friends because the combinations were that unique. My absolute favorite was the nostalgia dish at the end of the meal that's accompanied by the famous edible balloon. Spoiler alert: our flavor was banana, not green apple as they've had in the past.  My friend and I were joking that we should come here every weekend. Even if that were feasible, I'd probably still want to keep this as a special-occasion restaurant. It's so rare to find a dining experience that feels this unique nowadays - especially when you're used to eating out frequently. 100% recommend.

Five stars for the service and presentation. The food? Meh. I have a difficult time tasting the difference between a good $10 wine and a good $100 wine, so I am probably not the target customer for Alinea. The flavor combos were very unique and, again, presentation was amazing. But, for the price, none of the 14 courses or wine pairings I received really wowed me. Having said all this, my friend who is a huge foodie loved the food, so to each their own. I'm glad I went as it was a cool and unique experience. But I would much rather spend this kind of money on an upscale steakhouse.

How does someone with no culinary background review a restaurant of this caliber?  I don't even know where and how to start.  I mean, I really only know the difference between yum and yuck.  With that said, did I give Alinea 5 Yelp stars because I fell into the hype?  Truthfully, the 5 stars is given to match the 3 Michelin stars.  Those are experts after all.  3 Michelin stars is no easy feat!  Have you seen BURNT with Bradley Cooper?!  Or CHEF with Jon Favreau?!  3 stars is hard work!  So, people shouldn't give this place less than 5 Yelp stars because they don't understand the food, because...hey girl...can you make that at home?!  I'm guessing no. Getting reservations was pretty easy because I didn't have a specific date and I was willing to wait.  Dining slots fill up quickly so make your reservations months in advance if you have a special date in mind and especially if you're coming from out of town.  Dining options are broken down to 3 tiers, THE SALON ($175-$225), THE GALLERY ($295-$345), THE KITCHEN TABLE ($385).  The sliding scale prices correlate with popular times and days.  You make your booking online and by booking I mean buy your non refundable but transferable tickets.  We made a reservation for 4 at the least popular day and time and we paid $980 - this is for the salon meal, tax, and tip.  We decided while we were at the restaurant to do the wine pairing, again we chose the lowest tier for $115.  Total with tax and tip for the wine pairing was about $620.  All in all, this was a $400 per person dinner.  And when you're paying that much money you expect the place to stuffy and snobby.  But no, the staff were all friendly, personable, knowledgeable, and some were even funny. I'm not going to break down the 14 courses and explain each dish in detail.  Ain't nobody got time for that.  What I will say is that I was thoroughly impressed.  The food was so creative and innovative.  Out with your conventional perception of what food should look and taste like.   This is an experience.  An art show.  No detail too small.

I am going to agree with most of the other reviewers here, and let you guys know this place is so. Good. If you don't like surprises, I guess I can say that I am not surprised that you might not like this place.  However, I love trying new and unexpected food.  If you come into this meal knowing that, you will be satisfied.  We opted for "The Salon" option, as that was all that was available for a 2-top.  We would love to try the other option "The Gallery" sometime if we have the chance!  We also had the base level wine pairings which I absolutely recommend.  There were a few dishes that were enhanced so much by the wine. Out of all our courses, there was only one that we didn't like (contrast/españa).  My favorites were ice (tropical flavors topped with trout roe), crunch/paper (sea scallop paper with corn broth), and bone (crunchy bone marrow puffed rice with wagyu beef).   If you have the chance to get here, do it!
Delicious amazing and the absolute best service. Although I did not have wine my date appreciated the wine list.

Amazing dining experience. The courses started out very strong with very complex yet complimentary flavors and textures.  The wine pairing was spot on for each course.  Only the last few courses were hit or miss. More hits than misses.  The staff was extremely accommodating and the service was impeccable.  Would definitely return to see what the menu is line when it changes.

Mind blowing and sensational. My favorite dining experience I've ever encountered. Everything, absolutely everything was breathe taking. Saw an episode of chefs table and Chef Grant was just so inspiring I had to go. I can't tell in detail each course, would write a 2 page essay on that. Just go. Enjoy your fabulous meal. Soak in the incredible service. Take in the scenery of the restaurant and compare to your dish how colorful and contrasting it is to the room your dining in. Try something different. And then go have cocktails at the Aviary. Everything I could recommend .

I could write about Alinea for pages and pages, but it doesn't mean I should. To be straight to the point: this place is phenomenal, the best restaurant I've ever been to, and it deserves each of its Michelin stars. The only other restaurants I've been to that come even remotely close are Gary Danko and State Bird Provisions in San Francisco. Each course was unique and truly delectable. The service was beyond attentive and pleasant. The restaurant is gorgeous. I'm still looking for a place where I can buy another bottle of the wine I had. It really comes down to this: if you can afford to, go. I was fortunate that I was invited to go there, otherwise I wouldn't have been able to justify the cost. Now that I've been, I'm eager to go back with my wife on a (very, very, very) special occasion. Caveats: like others have said, if you're a picky eater, this won't be a good option. None of the ingredients were "crazy," especially if you've been to similar "high-end" restaurants. But since you don't get to pick your food, you have to be willing to go with the flow. But that's a big part of what makes it so great!

The best dining experience I've ever had. Every course had a really fun element, every bite had something of a surprise. A couple of the pairings created an amazing third flavor beyond the food and wine. The service was fantastic although only slightly faster than o wanted it to be. We had the least expensive option of 11 tasting portions and the pairings.

So...I've always wanted to eat here but it was just so hard to get a reservation . After watching the Netflix documentary Chef's table, it just furthured my desire to dine here. The stars must have aligned for me because I was able to get tickets....on my birthday.  I could go on detail about the ticketing/reservation process etc....but I must say it is an experience!  1) service: The staff there is AMAZING. As soon as you walk in, they are there to grab your coat, lead you to your table, lead you to the bathroom etc. They are so knowledgeable for all the tiny details of the 13+ courses you are about to eat. They are all so friendly and witty. I found them fricking hilarious. I'm pretty sure I told them that too.  2) ambience- It's actually pretty cozy and super chill. I didnt feel like this was some stuffy,boring restaurant. The staff also added to that 3) Food- wow. You read the reviews, see pictures. It just doesnt do the experience justice. Also, even though the portions are on the smaller side because there are 13+ of them, you leave stuffed. The details,tastes, and the aromas from the dishes that Chef Achatz and his staff create are mindblowing. They are very accomodating to food allergies and dietary restrictions. One of my friends had a seafood allergy and she didnt feel like she missed out at all. This restaurant is $$$ but worth every penny in my opinion.  My only issue was finding the door...:) it can be a little difficult to find in the dark.  Can't wait to find out what Chef Achatz and team are whipping up at Next!

I don't know what is happening with Michelin rated restaurants in Chicago. Maybe the rating is going to their heads, but I'm starting to feel it's not worth the money nor time. I do expect outstanding service, but was disappointed by our meal. I've eaten at all Michelin restaurants in Paris. I wasn't impressed by their tasting menu at all and not a single dish included caviar which is a sin in my book. I didn't find any food items to be very memorable in flavoring. A whole lotta hype and not enough substance is my opinion. North Pond is my favorite Michelin restaurant in Chicago and never disappoints.

I was a little skeptical at first to write this review because I really didn't want to write negative comments about such a known restaurant. But I definitely have a need to give my 2 cents on this experience.  First off, the service is exceptional. They take your coat upon arrival and provide you with a 100% cashmere pashmina if you'd like. You feel like royalty that's for sure! 5 stars on service.  The reason why I decided to give this place 2 stars is because, the food is very very different. Not in a good way. How can I explain this? The menu is a surprise, so the description for each course is just one word. Like: Yellow, or Crunchy. The idea is to keep you guessing through out the night as to what you're going to get. One thing, if you are a picky eater this place is NOT for you. If you don't like surprises, this place is NOT for you. When the waiters would bring the dishes and explained what was in them, I barely understand 1/4th of what it was. These are things I had never tried before or heard of before for that matter.    I love food, so does my husband. But I can tell you that I honestly think this was a waste of my money. It's extremely expensive just for food, and wine pairings will cost you just as much as the food itself. The presentations are unlike anything I've ever seen before. Amazing presentation and the scents on some of these things really got you into the theme of what you were eating. But the food itself was just too weird. To each their own and I'm sure there are multiple people who extremely love it. But my husband and I weren't part of that group, unfortunately. It's a huge mix of different types of foods, which can be a little detrimental to your stomach lol.  Wine pairing: exquisite wines. They give you three options on wine pairings and we chose the Middle option which was the reserved wines. I did notice a lot of people around us didn't really opt for that option though, but I do think the wines were amazing. With the exception of a Sake we had at one point which felt like I was drinking 100% rubbing alcohol.  Over all, it's definitely an experience. But it's an experience I could live without. It takes MONTHS to get a reservation here and of course we were both so excited to have gotten one, but we left extremely disappointed. I wish I would've gone to Giordano's pizza instead and maybe have saved all that money. This was definitely not a place for me. :(  Side note: the place has no sign with a name so it's going to be a little hard to find. I suggest you google how it looks outside so you recognize it when you arrive.

My first Michelin rated restaurant! (A 3-star one at that too!) I have first heard about Alinea because of pictures of their unique food presentations plus their famous edible balloons. I was a bit worried that their  renovations in 2016 would mean big changes to the food, but don't worry, the balloons are still there! I decided to go with the Salon which is their lowest tier with 10-14 courses since  this would be our first 3-star restaurant, and not sure if we would be acclimated to the food of that tier. Street parking in the area seemed okay (beware some locations require permits), but otherwise valet is available for $14. You could easily walk past the restaurant without knowing it since the building is  nondescript with only a minimal sign on the sidewalk. Once you past the front door, the front desk is very accommodating, including taking care of coats (think they are stored in heated closets) and any transportation needs. At the start of the meal, one of the servers will place a placard outlining the courses so you can follow along. Alinea is known for their deconstruction of food that follows simple themes like ice, stone, bone, etc. I think the best example is the 'nostalgia' theme where they took a cake and separated flavors that you would associate with your childhood apart like strawberry, banana, etc. Among the 13 courses, the wagyu/short-rib (bone) was heavenly. I never hard such a thick cut before and the sauce is so scrumptious. I would say there are ~3 courses that I wasn't fond of due to a more vinegar/sour taste (prefer more sweeter food), but I'll attribute that to not being acclimated to those type of dishes. Many of the courses comes with a neat effect ranging from dried scallops that melts into the broth to a dried ice smoke gushing out a bowl. I especially love the fruity aromatics that helps accentuate the course. Be sure to come up with a 10 second phrase to be recorded when the balloon comes out! If nothing comes to mind, singing happy birthday works! One thing that I appreciated for an upscale restaurant is how chill everything was. The only dress code is that men were requested to wear jackets (but definitely not required). You could get wine by the bottle or by the glass and sounds like they also have beer. All of our waiters were pretty friendly and don't mind taking pictures. You may consider bringing a DSLR like I did due to the low lighting (I ended up shooting at ISO 8000). All-in-all I had a good time and would come back to try the Gallery experience. Pro-tip: Make your reservations early (pref one month in advance)! One cool thing is you pay everything up-front, including tip so the only bill you may have to pay in the end are for the drinks. On the other hand, that does mean all sales are final. Alinea will contact you one week ahead of your reservation to ask for allergies and other accommodations so make sure to put in a valid e-mail address/phone number!

Our son is working his externship at Alinea over the last 6 months so we had to go. Alinea is worth the cost. Great experience with food, visuals and the staff there is great fun and very interactive with the patrons. The owner was there and was friendly and participates in the overall experience. Bring your appetite, you'll need it - and a fun attitude you will have a great time for a few hours.

Absolutely. Must. Go. Probably the most fun I've had at a restaurant. From escort to the table, the synced presentation of each course, the vivid storytelling of each dish, and the experience of the flavors itself, Alinea was fantastic and so new. Each of your senses will be stimulated, and what a delight it was to incorporate movement, sound, and even aroma into the evening. Simply extraordinary. There is definitely a lot more that can be said about the dishes, and since it's a fixed menu, there's no need to recommend the dishes and spoil the surprises :) (MINI SEMI-SPOILER: I would say, that the corn broth and seaweed crackers were my absolute favorite, and the wagyu itself was just awesome (though the sauce was a bit sweet. Really enjoyed the cold soup too, and the apple dry ice was amazing.) END SPOILER: So there you have it. Will definitely be back, it was so much fun, and can't wait. If you have the opportunity, save up if you have to and take the plunge :) Obligatory tips: There's some street parking available, $14 valet, and once you're in, you'll be well-taken care of. Plan for a longer dinner, and don't come super hungry or you'll be tortured as you wait between courses. Enjoy the experience, and come with people you love :)

Highly over rated. It's not worth it for vegetarians at least. From the Google pictures I saw I assumed that everyone got their desserts made on the table. However, their new policy is that whoever eats at the gallery is the only one who experiences the table dessert. There was no 'wow' factor at all. Sixteen at the Trump hotel was much better in terms of food. Highly disappointed.

We first discovered this restaurant when watching Netflix Chef Table and was intrigued by the technique and the concept of everything that place represent.  So we planned to set there as my destination for my birthday. It took quite a lot of effort to get the reservation. We set this as first priority and in order to book the flight from LAX to Chicago for our dining experience.  Overall the 12 courses of experience did not fail us at all.  Although we arrived little late due to the snow, and yes, it was below zero that day snowing when we had our dinner reservation.  The whole experience is definitely worth it.  I think posting photos just doesn't do full justice because every dish is more than visual effect, also other senses, especially smell and sense of wonder of what we get in a dish and multiple ingredient on our palate when we taste each dish. We have the wine pairing meal and the place is so low key from outside but it's just broaden up once you are inside.  As much to describe every dish, I decide just to present all the dish-theme.  The rest you'll have to discovered on your own once you are there.  No doubt the service is excellent and not any less.  We thoroughly enjoy our meals as truly an theatrical experience as it be.  Theme of dishes are listed as follows: Ice Crunch paper Contrast espana swirl thai dish/thai character yellow branch , glass toast bone smoke rock nostalgia The display and plate setting of each dish is so creative , keep your eyes wonder like a child.  Overall, I can't say enough of how much we enjoyed our experience, hoping one day we will return to enjoy different dishes of chef's creation.

By far my favorite restaurant EVER. After visiting Alínea, I will have a difficult time finding another place that present you with the most delicious food. My taste. Ufa were jumping with joy.  Can't wait to come back and try the new menu

Was there on Dec. 30.   After many trips to Alinea # 1, tried Alinea # 2.     Some amazing dishes.  Favorites, the truffle with cracker and blue cheese.  Also corn soup.          Some, not so much.     Big disappointment was the waygu beef short ribs.  Fatty.  And the sauce was too sweet.        The sommelier seemed to be focused on the upsell.  Our bottle of Reisling was "not cold enough" to drink before the food arrived, so "how about a glass of champagne to start."   Declined.     Then (with only about 6 people in the dining room upstairs) she was nowhere to be found to pour a second glass of wine when the first was empty.    We were ready to help ourselves when finally she responded to our entreaties and poured some more.            There are buckets with ice which spin a warm bottle to appropriate chill in about 5 minutes.   20 minutes after our wine was served, it was still pretty close to room temp.  Maybe there was not enough ice in the bucket.             The wait staff explains each dish, but some were better speakers than others.    Talking too fast and mumbling did not do the food justice.          We will go back when there is a new menu.
Everything about this restaurant is perfection. The people, the service they provide, the food experience, and the ambiance. Truly remarkable and unique dining trip.
Exceptional establishment well deserving of its 3 Michelin stars.

**MY 200TH REVIEW!!** Alinea is a dining experience that is defined more by the journey than the actual taste of the food.  But when the experience is as beautiful and mind blowing as it is here, the few missteps in the food are easy to forgive. From all the foodie lists and conversations with my foodie friends, Alinea was always heavily discussed and recommended making it easily on the top of my bucket list of places to eat.  Therefore, when I was gratefully and humbly gifted the opportunity to eat at Alinea from a person who is incredibly generous and amazing, I was more than ecstatic.   Scoring the reservation during the short window in which I was going to be in Chicago was a big worry.  Considering the odd times it is actually open (Wednesday through Sunday for 5:30-9:30) the actual times I could go during my visit was very narrow.  Thankfully, my friend realized that they tend to open slots in two month increments around the 15th of the month.  Another helpful way is to follow their Twitter or Facebook page which updates on openings.   There are several dining options that vary by number of courses and number of people.  I was fortunate enough to dine at the Gallery which is their 16 course offering perhaps their most fully developed experience especially with just two people.  From the beginning to end, each course was incredibly thoughtful and playful that incorporated unique elements that mostly exceeded my already high expectations.  It was an interactive experience with waiters who carefully explained each dish.  As I mentioned earlier, there were several courses that may have looked visually stunning, but in terms of taste a little bit of a let down.  However, each course built on the last letting you experience food in ways you never really thought were possible. The service here was top-notch.  Very attentive to our needs and super great about explaining all the different aspects of the food, the wait staff did not disappoint.  Unlike other restaurants, when you book your experience, the tip is already included in the price.  This makes the end of the meal all the more seamless - less about figuring out how much to tip and leaving the restaurant stress free.  While there was valet available, most of the people seemed to take Uber or taxi over. Overall, Alinea is a unique one of a kind eating experience that easily sits near the top of my most memorable dining experiences that I can only thank my friend who made this all possible.

When you select 5 stars for a business on Yelp it says "Woohoo! As good as it gets!".  Alinea is truly as good as it gets.  In fact, if you are purchasing tickets for Alinea, odds will have it that you are fully aware of the prestige of this place.  I was gifted a birthday present of dinner for two by my wife.  It was truly an amazing experience that blew my mind.  I'm a classicly trained chef, yelp foodie, and have traveled the country coast to coast many times, and I'm telling you, this is the best.  If you want to get nit-picky, you can at the very least claim Alinea is the best restaurant in Chicago. Now I will save you the dish by dish details.  I would recommend not doing to much research before you eat here as well.  After you eat, check out Grant Achatz on the Chef Table tv show.  It will cover his incredible back story and solidify the amazing experience you had. The one tip I will give; dress formal!  I really had no idea what to expect for the dress code and when I called and asked, I was told it was casual.  They go way out of their way to make you feel comfortable, but with only a dress shirt and slacks, I felt way under dressed.

Underwhelming and overpriced. High expectations as all I heard about from previous diners was the magical culinary experience, surprising performative presentation of dishes and unparalleled service. The food was good. Unique. Nothing was magical. There were no surprises. No performance. The dishes were presented in front of us and explained, yet, our main server tended to mumble more than anything. We had to ask him to explain again a handful of times. The highlight was when a table in the room let go of their balloon and it melted over the ceiling light. Ta-da! I guess that's why we paid a hefty service charge? The name Alinea now stands for something worth paying an arm and a leg. Decidedly not worth it in my opinion. Left intoxicated by the wine pairings, not from the experience. Buyers beware.

I have much respect for chef grant achatz and his amazing creative work, a great mentor to many and has thrived and overcome more difficulties then any other chef. To be an Michelin star restaurant consecutively over the years is an accomplishment of it's own. I have experienced Joel Robuchon's L'Atelier with molecular gastronomy influence and it was nowhere compared to our edible voice changing helium balloon at our table side. The wine pairing was exceptional & very generous. I can go on and on but you have to experience all the sensation & senses yourself.

There aren't enough stars in the world to rate the experience we had at Alinea. If you want to be royalty for 3 hours, you have come to the right place. Each dish is crafted to perfection with an artists touch, and an entertainers delivery. It's an alternate universe to everyday life and food. You will leave exhausted, and gloriously happy. (Vinny was the best)

Alinea absolutely lives up to its reputation and is worth every penny. I visited Chicago in mid-November 2016 for the first time to primarily go to Alinea and don't regret it at all! It was the best dining experience I've had up to now (we did The Gallery experience). They play with all your senses throughout the whole meal, from the moment that you walk through the doors. They play with absolutely all your senses, your expectations and constantly surprise you with a meal's presentation, how food's served, the room's ambiance and such, throughout every course.  Service was impeccable and very attentive. It was nice having a rotating group of waiters as each one brought a different vibe and personality to each course presentation. Make sure to get at least the base wine pairing to go along with the meal, it compliments the food really well.  I'd want to go into detail of every bit of the meal, but I honestly wouldn't want to spoil it in case they re-use any part of how they did things. I'll just post the card hinting at what the meal was. I definitely feel like I'd come back every couple of years given how much the whole menu changes, you just know it'll be a different experience every time. We overheard during the meal as well, that for our night's menu, there was barely any hold overs from the previous menu. They're always changing and improving.

After waiting months to finally get an opportunity to try out Alinea, I have to say that I was rather disappointed by the experience. The ambience, staff, and food presentation was exactly as you would expect from a Michelin restaurant. Everyone was very attentive and friendly, and you could tell that each dish was very deliberately designed. There is no doubt that a lot of thought went into the whole experience. My only gripe was with the food. Maybe it has to do with personal preferences, but this is the first time that I have gone to a Michelin restaurant, and came out of it feeling very polarized about the dishes. Either I absolutely loved the dish, or I disliked it to the point of not wanting to finish it. Overall I thought the experience was good, but I am not in a rush to try it again.

The group I went with spent the weekend trying to figure out our assessment of Alinea.  We'd all been looking forward to the experience but ultimately left dissatisfied and unable to pinpoint exactly why.  For my husband and I, the molecular gastronomy and artistry of playing with the delivery and presentation of the food, as well as the environment in which you eat it, was truly a unique experience. Something that we likely would only get at Alinea. The staff was obviously knowledgeable about the dishes - but the HOW the dishes were made and the WHY the dishes were presented as they were was what we were truly interested in and the information that came with the delivery was very short on this. We learned far more about this watching the Alinea episode on Chef's Table than during our actual experience eating at Alinea.  [Side note: I highly recommend anyone thinking about going here to watch Chef's Table (Netflix) first-- I think it helped me/my group appreciate the experience at a level we would not otherwise have done just going here cold.] Otherwise, the food was disappointing. The presentation was great, but the food itself wasn't.  I had high expectations-- which I think were reasonable based on the press, michelin stars, Chef's Table, and eating at other wonderful establishments as well as from reading Alinea's cookbook.  I thought: (1)  I would get to eat lots of interesting and playful things. What they served was delicious, but there wasn't as much variety or uniqueness in the actual food as I would have expected.  There was a lot of fish in the courses we had. I've had pork belly that has been better cooked.  Again- presentation was awesome, but this wasn't the greatest culinary experience I've had. (2) Portion sizes would be perfect.  I've been to many places serving a set menu with multiple courses.  I was shocked at how big some of the courses at Alinea were-- and I left feeling incredibly full (which I don't like-- but how could I not eat everything?).  Some people in my group stopped eating towards the end--  it was just too much.  My entire group agreed we would have appreciated less of most of the dishes so that we could have enjoyed all of the dishes more. (3) We would have an appropriate dessert.  Instead, the last 3 courses (of 14) were all desserts!!!  It was too much.  We would have much preferred more entree type dishes. (4) Coffee served during dessert.  We were asked about our coffee orders around the first dessert course.  When the second course came we asked when we would actually get the coffee and were told "during dessert".  We didn't actually receive coffee until after the desserts were done.  At that point, we all felt that we should be leaving since they were clearly preparing for the next service, so we didn't enjoy it. My last note is that Alinea could have helped us prepare for a better experience.  Almost immediately when we sat down we were offered a truffle dish that would cost $125 (or $150) per person-- and that the entire table needed to be all in or not.  For at least one couple in our party, that was an awkward question; it would have been nicer if we had that information in advance to discuss rather than feeling put on the spot to make a ~$300 decision per couple.  While we can afford to eat here, this isn't going to be something we do more than once a year. Immediately after that question was the question about the wine pairings.  Again, it would have been helpful to know (perhaps it is online, but I can't find it) that there were three options in advance, about what the options were, what kinds of wines would likely be served (what the theory or experience goal is with that option) and a price range for the options (the range was something like $215 to $419 per person).  However, for this, they were willing to accommodate different people getting different options. I debated about what rating to provide.  Regardless of the number, I'd said I thought I had high expectations- which I think were completely reasonable- and Alinea didn't deliver.  And it was  too expensive an experience not to have.

Best restaurant in Chicago and USA. This was a surprise from my husband who gives the best surprises :) and we loved the experience. Words won't do justice in describing the food it was an artist's expression. Was lucky enough to meet Grant Achatz as he painted the finale dessert on our table.

I have been wanting to check this place out for a few years now. It has been ranked as one of the top restaurants in the world so we decided to celebrate our 14th anniversary here. My rating for this place comes with highly critical expectations and rightfully so. I have been to Charlie Trotters, Tru, 42 Grams, Duomo (Sicily), Europea (Montreal) and other ultra fine dining places here and abroad and I honestly cannot say that Alinea takes the top spot in my dining list. If your exposure to this dining category is minimal to none, you might say that this is the best dining experience ever. Otherwise, you might think it would be at par to some, better than other or even worse than some. I had a good experience not a WOW experience. We paid 250 pp without drinks and we were seated on the second floor. The moment I sat down, against the wall I felt the seat was a bit low and uncomfortable. As minor as this is, it sets the tone for rest of your dining experience. Trout/coconut/passion fruit - interesting scallop/nori - super yum Sanma fish - I am a seafood lover and this one I did not consume, it just didn't taste right. the presentation was superb. cider/orange/maple... - good pork belly - fantastic but anyone can make this dish taste good. pear/paprika/jamon - i already forgot this mastic concorde - if this is the one with the foie grois then it was outstanding black truffle/gruyere - this one was truly divine Wagyu - so so so good! Short rib - delish desserts - well done Although the servings were very small, I thought it was enough. Im glad we did not order the soup that was the special for the day 120 USD for a bowl of soup because at the end of meal, I couldn't even finish my dessert Service is good to very good. We had some dietary restrictions against refined sugar and the email communication was very efficient. Just like most places that charge a lot, it can be a bit pretentious. I have to say that the service was more casual than refined elegance. There were a few flaws like they refilled my sparkling water with flat water. They tried to take my dish even when I was not done (twice). We mentioned our anniversary in our email and there was no acknowledgement of it in any way shape or form. A bit disappointing. All in all it was a good experience. Was it worth the money? Sure. Would I recommend it? Absolutely! Would I be back? Not unless someone else is paying the bill.

TOTALLY NOT WORTH THE MONEY. VERY DISAPPOINTING. TOTAL JOKE! I want to say these words out loud so many times after having a chance to experience the wholly expensive tasting menu at The Alinea !!! I couldn't believe myself after waiting for 3 months and finally be able to sit and have their tasting menu & wine pairings ($295 for the meal +$215 domestic/intenational wine) PLUS tax PLUS 20%service charge at The Galeria, that this is THE WORST experience I've ever had among all other 3 Michelin-starred restaurants in the country that I've been to. Having a very expensive meal at 3 Michelin-starred restaurant, without any doubts, everyone's expectation is the service, meal & beverages and the overall experience should be SUPERB. Sadly, it did not happen at The Alinea. First of all, the guy who was in charged of pouring the wine, was not friendly at all and the worst thing was, every single bottle of wine that he poured to my glass was only a sip size of volume. I've finished every single wine before the food came, therefore, I totally don't think I've experienced the "Food and Wine Pairings" at The Alinea.  Secondly, the menu was laid out on a piece of paper with about 12 different unique names, just their way to try to surprise and impress us with the food they will serve, without giving out all the details about the descriptions of the dish. Unfortunately, every SINGLE dish that came to our table DID NOT impress us. At. All. Zero. For a three Michelin-starred restaurant at least I'd expect there would be at least caviar, lobster, abalone in one of the dish. What we got was mostly cheap ingredients! A total joke! All dish was served in a tiny portion with mostly sweet, creamy sauce and among 12-13 courses there were 3-4 dessert which were chocolates and ice cream. Are you kidding us? We're coming here to spend over $1000 worth of meal not to have ice cream or chocolates !!! The other courses that are really disappointing are: FRY- A deep fried of icefish with orange mandarin sauce.  To be honest, almost all fish dish served in Chinese food restaurant tastes better than this. YELLOW - Pork Belly. Curry. Banana.  Served in a tiny yellow flexible plastic bowl with a few very dry, tiny pieces of pork belly covered with yellow curry sauce. A total joke! The pork belly you can get from a lot of food trucks taste much better than this dish and the size is a lot bigger too! PAINT - Cherry. White Chocolate. Bourbon. Nothing exceptional here, doesn't matter how good the paintings the chef was trying to do, this main item in this dish basically just white chocolate.  BONE - Wagyu beef served on top of bone marrow. A good wagyu should just melted in your mouth. Instead, the wagyu here was flavorless, did not melt in my mouth. PETAL GLASS - Purple Allium, Black Pepper, Onion. Lapsang Souchong. Maitake. The biggest item and served in the most generous size was the Purple Allium Flowers which were inedible. Finally, again, TOTALLY NOT WORTH THE $$$$ !!!

Alinea is worth the expense and lives up to its reputation without question. Every aspect and element of this dining experience was a sight to behold! Everything was beautifully presented and was designed to delight the diner. I didn't even get a hint of pretension from the decor, waitstaff or food, despite this restaurant's sterling reputation and rating. I enjoyed myself thoroughly here. Every course was impressive and innovative. My only teensy criticism is that several dishes were notably salty to me. Very few of the other reviewers seem to agree with me, so I will chalk it up to being pregnant and having a sensitive palate. Otherwise, everything about this restaurant was impeccable.  Highlight was the non-alcoholic beverage pairing. It exceeded all of my expectations and must've required a lot of thought and work, despite it being half the price of the alcoholic beverage pairing. Brava!

Truly one of the most exotic, unique, and special dining experiences in all of Chicago. This restaurant has truly earned it's Michelin rating. I will admit that the dishes and flavors were not necessarily the most life-changing aspect. But the experience, plating, and display of concepts was what truly made the experience. Would not necessarily go back because of the high price, but definitely worth trying.

I was fortunate enough to have dinner here this past summer. This was easily the most incredible dining experience of my life. It was so much more than a dinner, I would call it edible performance art. I recommend not reading about all the details in some of the reviews. It's definitely more fun to be surprised. We did the gallery option, which if I remember correctly had 18 courses. All delicious and beautiful! Definitely worthy of the three Michelin stars.

I would describe it as a fun, mysterious theatrical puzzle of gastronomy. While entertainingly delightful, we weren't as fond of the formal ambiance. As for speaking strictly on food quality, I would put many NY restaurants ahead. But Alinea wins hands down on the delivery of innovative dishes. Definitely worth a try but don't expect to have your taste buds explode on every course.

Grant Achatz's newly decorated restaurant reminds me of his old decoration. This place is to dining what MoMa is to art. The visual is more stunning than the dining pleasure. At three Michelin, you should expect perfection and this delivers.  I prefer NEXT, his second Chicago restaurant. That place combines dining pleasure and plating. If you need to get engaged, a must. Wait until the dessert which is beyond description.  By far superior to Grace, the other three Stars Michelin in Chicago. I personally prefer the Gordon Ramsey experience at the Trianon of Versailles (Chocolate, Beef and Wine). In Chicago the best price/view/Michelin is 16 at Trump.

If you have seen the Chef's Table special or any if the other documentaries that feature Alinea, approach with sobriety.  We sat on the 2nd floor and had a wonderful meal.  However,  I was expecting more of a "show"...theatrics, drama. intrigue,  etc.  This was based on preconceived notions encouraged by food show hype.  Did not get this.  Staff were attentive but I got a slight whiff of flippant and haphazardness.   My guess is that demand has overwhelmed the ability of the venue to deliver on its core values.  I also presume that higher paying guests get acess to the more cutting edge aspects.  While I applaud the chef's creativity,  I condemn him for allowing fame to promote his restaurant as he simultaneously dilutes the experience for all but a select few patrons.

This restaurant offers perhaps the greatest culinary experience in Chicago, and even in the whole USA.  My family, including my mother-in-law and my teenage daughter, was all dressed up for this special dining occasion.  It was my daughter's first time at Alinea; she had asked us whether she could invite her best friend, and we said "Yes".  These two teenage girls were so excited to be there that it was almost comical.  They were quietly squeaking and hooting at the foods all along.   We booked for "the Gallery" and it was awesome as always.  My husband and I have been at Alinea quite a few times.  As we observed, the entree in the Gallery experience seemed to have been changed somewhat.  Wine pairings were all nice, ranging from good to fantastic.  (We don't usually like wine parings at other lesser restaurants.)  The wine director/sommelier obviously has an excellent taste. We have already made another booking at Alinea for the end-of-the-year dinner for our family.  We can hardly wait for another fine meal at this lovely restaurant.

As many have said before, maybe you should skip the reviews and allow yourself to be surprised.  We did the gallery experience as opposed to the salon. Highly recommended.  I do have to say that you will need a lot of foresight to book this reservation unless you plan to come with a group of 4.  there are 3 tables for 2 available each seating (there are 2 seatings), and I would just say that the effort to book my table for 2 on a saturday night was indeed crazy.  Just realize that the tickets historically speaking go on sale on the 15th of each month, at exactly 10am or 11am.  Just get your finger ready... by 11:01am Saturday and most of Sunday was completely sold out for any seating..  the seats for 2 were gone by 11:00:01. A lot of the surprise factor for me was lost out because a friend had visited 2 weeks prior and took a bunch of photos that ended up on my social media feed.  While I do not consider myself any sort of food authority, I have dined at maybe 30+ Michelin starred restaurants in my lifetime (5 of them w 3 stars) my overall opinion based on food alone is that Alinea was not quite at the top.  What takes Alinea over the top is the combination of media elements that make it more of a show.  The service is impeccable. Tons of smiles as well. These people love what they're doing.   Every element of the dining experience all fits in. Whether it's the synchronized music with service, or the magic of the room changing shape between courses, or the great stories Grant Achatz (he was there and personally serving us at times!) was telling our group around the kitchen table, it was an unforgettable experience.  I don't know if I can quite describe the food in much detail so I'll just use this as more of a summary space.  The wine pairing was delicious. So was the non alcoholic pairing. I read in another review to pass the non alcoholic pairing, but I completely disagree. I loved it (my wife ordered it).  The food requires all your senses so do please enjoy :)

What could I say that hasn't been said already? Surprised throughout the meal as the chef only have 1 or 2 words on the menu for the courses. Favorite courses of the night were the black truffle toast and rock dessert. Just wow. It's also white truffle season when we went, so for a $125 charge per person, we got potatoes with white truffle shavings. So damn good. It's also quiet the presentation. I think our bowl of potatoes was served on top of a stack of 3 plates.  Service was fantastic, as one would expect from a restaurant of this caliber. What was fun was that the waiters were super friendly and would crack a joke or chit chat with you if you're cool with it.

Expensive but well worth it. I don't think that I would ever go again however I was glad that I went once. The meal was superb and the wine pairings spot on. Service was excellent without being snobbish. The food was life changing and not like anything I had experienced before. There were flavors that evoked memories and flavors that awoke senses in me. I can really compare this restaurant to any other I have ever been to so it is #1 in it own category. I would not pay to go again. However I would go if someone else was paying.

After watching Chef's Table on Netflix, I thought I would find myself eating at Alinea only in my dreams. Fortunately the stars aligned, and me and some friends squeezed Alinea, a BYU/MSU football game, and an Eagles/Lions game into a 2 1/2 day trip from Utah. As much as I love football, Alinea was the highlight of the trip and truly a culinary experience of a lifetime. Many reviews offer a detailed play-by-play of the evening, but I would recommend, "Don't read the details!".  Alinea isn't just a meal, it is an experience. Chef Achatz and his amazingly creative staff have designed an experience around their food. There are tricks and turns, a few jokes, and some killer food. The element of surprise is half the fun, so don't lessen the experience by knowing every minute detail of your meal before you arrive. Our first course was "Ice". There were five small glasses, set in a chunk of ice. In the cups: 1. Black truffle mousse, with grated black truffle, 2. Chunks of king crab in a crab vinaigrette, 3. Herbs from Chef Achatz own garden, 4. Osetra caviar, 5. Egg yolk custard. We were then given toast points, and encouraged to mix each of the ingredients on the toast to create our own taste combinations. Each little cup held a bit of culinary perfection, and mixed together in different ways, each bite was a new experience. This dish is probably the single most memorable dish I've ever eaten. Amazing! We sat at the "kitchen table", which is a glass contained dining room with with full view of Alinea's kitchen. It was simply amazing to watch Chef Achatz work in his  3-star Michelin kitchen. There had to have been 20+ staff members in the kitchen, yet is was crazy quiet and orderly the entire evening. If you can swing the cost of the kitchen, DO IT!  The cost is ridiculous, but so is the cost of the entry level dining option - and for me being in the kitchen made the night. It was also a nice bonus to have Chef Achatz join us personally to add the finishing touch to the dessert grand finale. We don't drink, so we added the non-alcoholic drink pairing - which I wouldn't recommend. Some strange concoctions that didn't enhance the food. Not worth it... As for details, I will say no more.   The food is amazing, the experience is even more amazing. My recommendation would be GO!! But, skip some reviews and let Alinea surprise you.

We did the salon tasting with the wine pairings. It was amazing and the best dining experience we've ever had. The staff was very knowledgeable and the explanation of the dishes were great. I highly recommend the wine pairings. They were wonderful. There was an additional supplement of pommes robuchon (whipped potatoes) with shaved white truffles for an additional $125.00 that we added which was my favorite. I don't want to spoil any surprises but you will not regret coming to Alinea. Our dinner was 3 hours and we were completely satisfied. I can't imagine the gallery or KT tasting but I'm hoping to come back and try.

What an experience!  Was brought here for a wedding gift by some very close friends!!  The attention to detail is second to none.  I have no idea how they managed to fix my napkin ever single time I got up from the table.  I will not go over the dishes so as not to spoil the surprise for anyone, but you never know what you're going to be eating by the end of the night.   Mind blown!

This was my first dining experience in a [three-star] Michelin star restaurant and my first time dining at a restaurant of this caliber alone. I've read plenty of articles and perused various media about Alinea, so I did have high expectation, but at the same time it did intimidate me.  Upon walking into the restaurant (plain gray facade only indicated by its building number), you can sense the refinement. The staff is warm and professional upon reception/host's stand, through being seated, and until the end of service. I chose the 12-course Salon experience (I don't believe the other experiences had seats for one), and elected the wine pairing once seated.  My ticket specifications were reviewed first (food allergies/dietary restrictions) prior to going over the menu. Side note: I would also like to add that their professionalism also extends to when your purchase your dining ticket online--the communication was prompt and all of my questions/concerns were addressed thoroughly. The 12 courses progressed as follows: ice, crunch paper, yellow, spectrum, swirl, contrast sangre, cloche, bone, toast, branch glass, nostalgia, Okinawa. These courses seemed to carry an autumnal theme. As expected, the meal began with a rather showy first course, having me hold a bowl of ice in my hand while eating it. It was a sweet (coconut, passion fruit) and savory/salty (trout roe) dish, and I began with tasting very small portions of each component, then mixing them together. Considering the plating and the components, I had expected dramatic flavors, but, when eaten together, it was actually offset more on the gentle side because of the ice plate. The next standout course for me was Spectrum (sanma or pacific saury, avocado, katsuobushi), and this was the best tasting, most well-prepared fish I have ever tasted (and I typically do not like eating cooked fish). While the course had three other components (shishito pepper, avocado, and daikon, I believe), the sanma stood out as retaining its natural flavor and moisture, which was surprising because it is a small fish and was covered in the three striped sauces.
