My last favorite course (while they were all delicious courses) was the Branch Glass course, largely due to my love of mushrooms. The maitake was prepared in a way that you would think it evolved into a new type of a meat--great texture and retention of its mushroom flavor. It seemed that this dish was a progression of earthy to light, starting with the maitake, progressing with integration of the lapsong souchong tea component, and topping off with the slightly sweet and sour blueberry glass. My favorite dessert course was Okinawa (chocolate, sweet potato, miso), for which the plating by itself was beautiful and meticulous. The server said it was supposed to be reminiscent of the beaches in Okinawa. Again, this was a course where I asked how the odd ingredient, miso, would mesh with the other sweet components, but the richness of the chocolate (which oozes from the "rock" looking piece), plays upon the depth of the miso and makes for a dessert that is not overly sweet. The wine pairing was worth getting, but I am also a wine novice. Nonetheless, the sommelier was personable and highly knowledgeable without making me feel uncomfortable not being familiar with the wines that were served. She was great at describing what components of the courses play off with the wines (or vice-versa). The pairings that were most memorable were the Seikyo Takehara Junmai sake with the Yellow course and the Valdespino Tio Diego Amontillado sherry with the Swirl and Contrast Sangre course. Overall, the food itself was amazing; however, my critique would be that I wish there was a higher level of the molecular gastronomy presentation with the Salon experience. But you can still sense the curation and thought put into each component, dish, and presentation. The service was top notch, with the servers being very eloquent, courteous and amiable. I did sense, though, an urgency once they served the dishes and I asked questions (although, all of my questions were addressed). For those who are curious, you won't feel overly full after dining here, but I have a rather small appetite, so I was actually completely satisfied by the end of the night.   Despite my few critiques, dining at Alinea was totally worth the splurge. It truly is an experience of food and showmanship of culinary techniques. This restaurant completely deserves the praise and accolades that is has received.

When I was a child I went to a museum on the east coast, the Boston museum of science, I believe --side note: I haven't rated that museum on yelp because it deserves 10 stars. There's an exhibit there where you are instructed to stick your face into holes carved out of a wooden box, sniffing reveals you have decided to treat your nose the aroma of Bear, Raccoon, Deer, or any other woodland creature's scat. That cheeky museum, in the pursuit of individual knowledge, essentially instructs visitors to smell farts. Eating at Alinea is the closest I have ever been to being reaquainted with this childhood memory, eating at Alinea is the food analogue of being asked by a trusted authority on art to smell farts.  10/10

We visited here the weekend of the Chicago Marathon and purchased the base level tickets. I wasn't impressed with many of the courses, pork belly, beef short rib, and wagyu didn't do much for me. There was also a deboned mackerel. The best course was a dehydrated scallop served in a broth. The most fun was the banana flavored helium balloon of course .  Overall the service was excellent, staff was friendly, they accommodated a trip to see the kitchen after the meal.  After forgetting the souvenir menus in the cab they mailed us additional ones (we live in Maryland). I don't regret the visit, but I can't say we enjoyed the meal very much. It's also hard to judge because of the 3 available dining options we chose the cheapest which was still very $$$$.  Be prepared to spend, even after the 235 per person, they offered a supplemental dish the night we were there of white truffles for an additional 125 a person, and the whole table has to get it. We chose not to. We also skipped the wine pairing of 155 a person I think? and instead opted to share a bottle. We had great fun with the gastronomy vibe, but the room we were in was quite isolated, next to the bathroom and stuffy to me. It was quiet and a bit awkward to listen to everyone's conversations.

So happy I got to experience Alinea!  I was moved to get tickets to dine after watching the season two premiere of Chef's Table spotlighting the restaurant and wasn't disappointed. Got the 10-14 course experience with the introductory priced wine pairing. Every dish was surprising in its presentation and taste and the wines were paired perfectly. The meal was thoroughly satisfying - I'm so happy I got to check this restaurant off my bucket list.

Yes, it's absolutely as good at you've heard.  From start to finish, Alinea knocks it out of the park and engages your every sense.  It's much more than a meal; it's an experience like none other.  It's pricey, but you get what you pay for and more.

Tickets to Alinea are coveted and he's to come by. I jumped at the chance to be invited. So I feel blessed  to be able  to eat here twice in my life. Regardless if you like all of the ingredients, or even if you don't think of yourself as a foodie, you will have an amazing evening here. The service is great and all of the staff a highly skilled at explaining the dishes and ingredients. So don't be afraid to ask again, what something is or how did they do that? With the presentation of all of the food you will be entertained by all of your senses. You mouth will be pondering all of the flavors and textures and temperature going on at one time, leaving great conversation amongst the table. It's ok if you are afraid of some ingredients, nothing is ever over powering and always perfectly balanced.  Part of the adventure is trying blindly and you will surprise yourself with the magic and science behind these plates. So if your are wondering how much??? We had the short menu of 14 items at about $250. We also had the basic wine pairing at $135.

My dream to eat at this restaurant finally came true! I had the most amazing dining experience with my fiancée last month. Not only is the staff friendly and not stuffy like some fine dining restaurants, they made the dining experience fun. The food was beyond imaginative and tasty! I was mind blown at some of the techniques they used on their dishes that night.  I don't want to ruin the experience for others but these guys really know how to throw a fancy dinner. I am glad that I was able to enjoy our anniversary dinner during our trip to Chicago. Bravo!

There are very few vegan reviews so I thought it would be helpful to write one.  The presentation was very cool but the vegan version didn't live up to the reputation of the restaurant in taste compared to reviews from omnivore patrons.  I appreciate that they tried to make a vegan version of their dishes but their meat and dairy substitute choices seemed very bland. For example, there are more options than tofu when it comes to fake meat and there is more than sorbet as a vegan ice cream replacement.   That said, it's definitely a unique experience.
I've done my share of fine dining experiences in New York, but Alinea is truly an experience. It's worth going at least once.

Not impressed with the alinea 2.0.  The last time I dined was 2009, that was more real with soul.  Now it seems all about ego, tricks, and ponies.  Each dish I had in the past was better than the next, black truffle explosion, bison and pine.  If something didn't work it wasn't because it wasn't good, it was my personal taste. 2.0 is over priced, stuffy, messy, and over the top.  It's not real food.

The most AMAZING dining experience in my life. I've been wanting to go here for years and finally made a trip to Chicago for one night just to go here! Tons of SPOILERS so if you want to be surprised skip this review! I know the menu changes but just a disclaimer!  We attended the gallery tasting which consisted of 18 courses. This is the middle tasting menu.  Communal- When we first arrived we were seated in a huge communal table with different items in little glasses that were in an ice block. Tables are separated after the next course. The items in each glass were: truffle mousse, king crab, herb salad, osetra caviar, and an egg custard. They told us to wait until everyone was seated. FYI this is why you need to be on time, everyone is waiting on you if you are late!! DON'T BE THAT GUY OR GIRL!! Once everyone is seated they gave everyone toasted brioche and told us to start digging in! Shaker/Roll- For the next part we were asked to leave our belongings at our seats while we moved to the kitchen to get our next courses. They made an alcoholic drink (gin, tomato, chartreuse) in front of us with a little roll of cucumber, feta, and caper leaves. Since I told gen earlier I didn't drink they made me a special non alcoholic drink with ginger and cucumber that was so yummy! Cruno/Paper- Diver scallops are pureed and then formed into these paper looking things! A delicious corn broth is poured over it to re-hydrate the paper looking things which then turns into a scallop noodle. OMG. This was the most amazing dish ever. So unique, so full of flavor. The crunch part was a nori roll that was filled with scallop mousse. DELICIOUS. I wan't these packed up in snack bags! Contrast/Sangre/Swirl- This course consisted of: Contrast (tomato soup, freeze dried watermelon, parmesan), Sangre (green peanut, iberico jelly, apple jelly, sherry foam), and Swirl (apple, yuzu, lemon verbena)! The smokey thing coming out had strong scents of yuzu infusing the air and table while we ate these dishes! AMAZING! I hate tomatoes and I actually liked the soup, so many interesting and different flavors! Spectrum- A big plate comes out with what looks like a painted fish! The main item is a mackerel with an avocado sauce, aji amarillo sauce, and katsuobushi sauce. There is also a potato stuffed pepper, a radish salad, and avocado. I loved mixing pieces of the fish with all the other sides. Such a tasty dish that just looked so fun! Yellow- This came in a weird silicon bowl that fit your hand! This dish was pork belly in curry with banana. The pork belly and the sauce were amazing! There were also sliced fennel on top for that extra texture. The pork belly was so good and was cooked perfectly. The sauce was not a typical curry, it had a sour note to it that made it extra special!  Toast- Um YUM. This is what they called their version of a grilled cheese! This was a piece of pumpernickel toast with gruyere cheese and black truffles. This was so good and so rich and so filling! I can't even express in words the taste explosion in my mouth! Petal/Glass- I wish this course came earlier because I LOVE mushrooms but I was getting so full! This was maitake mushrooms,apsang souchong (black tea), with blueberry paper. If you love mushrooms you will LOVE LOVE this. SO SO good and the blueberry paper added a sour element and just made it just that much better! The petal was onion, purple allium, and black pepper.  Bone- This dish was one of my favorites of the whole night! A piece of wagyu on top of a crispy rice square seasoned with myoga (type of ginger). This was just such an interesting and surprisingly good course! It kind of reminded me of a savory rice crispy!! Who doesn't like a savory rice crispy?! Cloche- As they put the bowl down and lifted the cover, all sorts of aromas hits you! I think it was anise and clove. The bowl contained tender short rib pieces, lentils (OMG SO GOOD), and champagne soaked grapes. The short ribs and lentils were so freaking good. I kept going back for the lentils though!!  Nostalgia- WOW! I was stuffed an manged to eat the whole thing. This had all sort of textures going on with bubble gum, cake, strawberry, and cherry flavors! This also came with a banana helium balloon that actually floated! Everything in this dessert was so fun, unique, different, and yummy!  Paint- All of a sudden we see people taking down the paintings on the ceiling and putting them on our table. The the lights go off and music starts playing. Then different people are coming by the tables painting and spreading all these different things on the painting. Then at the the end they smash a freeze dried sort of ice cream thing and bam! Dessert is served! Gold- The last item is a gold flake wrapped candy with sesame, brown butter, and feuilletine (praline flavor). I was happy. Worth every penny. WHEW I AM DONE!
Did a business dinner here and everything was impeccable- from design, service, food/ wine pairings and presentation. Will be returning with my boyfriend, and highly recommend this restaurant.

Yes, it's very creative. Yes, the concept is brilliant. Yes, the execution and plating are spot on. I know a lot of people go for the experience, but I was also looking forward to Joel Robuchon level food. This was not as tasty as I was expecting. It's cool, what with the balloon you eat, a campfire themed dish, etc. There was a platter that came with 100 flavors and you can only ask about a few to see if you are correct. Fun! The thing that turned me off though was the sommelier. We did the wine pairing, each wine was excellent. It was my birthday and I was tipsy, so I jokingly asked for an extra sip of one of the wines. Guy didn't even look at me or respond. Had he said, "sorry, it's against policy", I would have been ok, no problem. But being completely ignored like that at a restaurant that prides itself on all facets was disappointing.

If you are looking for a very special restaurant, (pricey) for a special occasion, this is that place.  Everything that comes to your table will be beautifully prepared and presented.  We ate off The Gallery Menu.  Check out their website it is top-notch.  This is one of reasons we gave this restaurant a try.

I'll keep the review short and simple bc giving to much detail will ruin your experience lol. The staff is exceptional and very knowledgeable of the plates and they really made us feel comfortable. Most of the plates were small but packed with flavor and the presentation was incredible. It really takes the food experience to a new level. incorporating not only taste but smell and sight into the equation. We all did the wine paring which was incredible and every drink was perfectly matched with food being served. Of course it's a costly experience but it's well worth it. I highly recommend dinning at alinea!

Went here shortly before they closed for the renovation, and our meal was unforgettable.  The experience is literally once in a lifetime.  You obviously pay for it though, which makes us unlikely to go back. The space was beautiful, the food was unique and delicious, and the service was fantastic.  Surprisingly, they have a selection of very reasonably priced wines, so we ordered a bottle of wine in lieu of going with the tasting pairing.   Overall, very glad we went, but we'll likely frequent Next instead for a similar experience at a lower price point.

Have to say I was disappointed.   I was expecting a lot. The food was very rich, a lot of creamy sauces and salty flavors.  One veal dish reminded me of cat food.  Most notably disappointing was the wait staff.  They seemed relatively inexperienced for a restaurant of this caliber.  One server repeatedly could not speak about the dish she brought out.  I sent back at least three courses barely eaten and each time the waitstaff assumed I was full vs asking if I liked it. Not once was I genuinely asked if I enjoyed the food. It was more of an assumptive "of course you did".  I actually went out and grabbed some French fries after.  Given I flew from California specifically for this restaurant and I have been to many of the best (French Laundry, Benu, Meadowood, PerSe, ect ect ), this restaurant did not compare or live up to its reputation.

a once-in-a-lifetime experience--more performance art than dining--truly unforgettable--more fun than the french laundry, trio, the late charlie trotter's, chez panisse and other big-name restaurants we've been to

We did the gallery experience and it was worth every penny. After dining here I've decided I'm going to keep this review short and sweet. It's best to be surprised and truly experience all the uniqueness this adventure offers. Didn't do the drink pairing with it but honestly I'm glad we didn't. Get a bottle of wine there and you'll be golden! Plus many of the courses come with a small drink as part of the experience anyway.  You won't leave hungry, even though many of the courses are prepared as "bites"... We were stuffed!  Prepare to have every one of your senses involved in this meal. Hands down best meal of my life and I can't wait to go back.

Me and hubby came here to celebrate my big 3-0 and our first wedding anniversary. Service was impeccable and the waiters were very attentive to us. To summarized each and every dish: everything were so delicious, succulent and mouth watering. Below are the menu and everything were beyond wonders: 1. Handcrafted ice bowl with hawaiian snapper n dice coconut 2. Scallop paper noodle with corn consomme 3. Scallop mousse with kombu seaweed 4. Parmesan custard with tomato soup 5. Cherry foam green peanut puree n blood peach 6. Green apple with yuzu 7. Mandarin satsuma puree, ice fish tempura, radish icicle 8. Blueberry cream, maitaki mushroom. Garlic thyme butter blueberry sheet 9.elderflower with french onion sandwich 10.crostini gruyere cheese custard oz truffle 11. Chicken thigh salsa verde, amco chili truffle, chicken creme fraiche 12. Bonbon 13. Green thai curry veal with lettuce chamomille n melon 14. Onion wagyu beef with rice krispy 15. Fennel ice cream with taco chocolate icecream 16.white mousse n fruit sauces

What an amazing birthday dinner! Each dish was perfect and presented by servers who were so knowledgeable about everything that went into each dish.  I would recommend this to everyone who has an open mind and isn't afraid to try new exciting things. It wasn't as quiet as I assumed it would be and I liked that.  My pictures will do this review better justice than I ever could. Can't wait to find an excuse to come back.  And that's all I have to say about that.  Jackée

I have visited Alinea two times within the past year and experienced two different seasonal menus. This review is based on my most recent experience for both my conjoined birthday celebration with my boyfriend.  I thought my 22nd birthday dinner would be unparalleled, but I am throughly disappointed. The first waiter to greet us seemed quite rude and unfriendly. He checked my ID to see if I was 21 and handed my license back without saying "Happy Birthday". Most servers need to know today's date in order to validate someone's age. I even made the effort to email them in advance to let them know about our birthdays and still got no warm welcome.Less expensive and low-end restaurants have waiters who acknowledge your birthday. I understand that this is a very petty thing to criticize. However, I expect to be treated like a princess if I am choosing to spend two birthdays here.  Then, they started preparing for dinner. Another waiter merely TOSSED my napkin on my lap, while gently placing it on the woman beside me. Uh, how about treating everyone equally? Am I taken less seriously because I am dressed casually? If I already paid the moment I made my reservation, I can obviously afford it and wear whatever I choose. Needless to say, my outfit was definitely put together even if it was not formal attire. As a fashion blogger, I think I know how to dress.  Needless to say, I posted an extensive rant on my Instagram within 5 minutes of sitting down at the table. The photo received an surprising 4,000+ likes and multiple comments of fellow customers with the same negative experience. There is a certain level of professionalism that I expect from a 3 Michelin star restaurant. Maybe it's just me being picky about the service I am paying almost $500/person for. The summer menu was also very disappointing. Citrus flavors dominated my taste palette repeatedly. My first visit before the renovation was in November, and the menu was much more diverse. As of right now, my experience at Alinea has been 50/50. I will go back again this fall to try their new menu and hope that the service is not as low-quality as it was on my birthday.

This is a review for the Gallery experience at Alinea 2.0. My date and I had been very excited about going to Alinea, but left disappointed. Maybe Alinea 1.0 was better? Would strongly recommend Grace, or even Next, over Alinea if you're looking for a fine dining experience in Chicago. Atmosphere - The presentation and plating of all the dishes was fantastic. The seating at my table was uncomfortable -- I'm tall and kept bumping my knees into the table and my back started hurting pretty early into the meal. Service - Friendly, but expected better from a 3 star Michelin restaurant: I had to ask for a water refill, my date had her sparkling water refilled with still water, and at one point the server introduced a dish to us and then realized that part of it was missing. Food - As mentioned above, beautiful plating on every dish. But I felt like there was more emphasis on plating than deliciousness. I wouldn't say anything there was anything that tasted better than good. This was the most disappointing part for us. Doesn't seem worthy of 3 Michelin stars and wouldn't be surprised to see Alinea lose a star this year.

I went to Alinea for my birthday and it was definitely an unforgettable experience.  I ate here pre-renovation so I can't say what it's like now, but when I ate there I had an enjoyable time.  The main thing here is the showmanship and the presentation.  Alinea is one of those places that, when you go, you think, "I didn't even know you could do that to food!"  It is such a unique experience that I have not had anywhere else.  As other may have mentioned, you may not fall in love with every dish, but you can definitely appreciate the creativity and thoughtfulness that went into each dish.  The service was also excellent, and as part of my birthday they gave me a glass of "birthday cake" champagne which was the oddest, but most delicious champagne I've had.  It literally does have the aftertaste of eating birthday cake which was interesting.  Definitely a must try, at least once in your life place.

the experience took place in september 2015.  yes, a year ago, but better late than never! looking back, i wouldn't say i enjoyed my dinner at alinea.  the whole experience was pleasant enough if not amusing and entertaining, but the food was not nearly as impressive. let's get the facts out of the way first. - reservation is hard to come by - dinner is prepaid at the time of booking, including tax and tip, but excluding alcoholic beverage charges  - restaurant is hard to locate with almost invisible signage - jacket is required for men, and most women are outfitted in much formal dresses as well - food is heavily geared toward molecular gastronomy concept - at one point there were more service staff in the whole restaurant than diners (we had one of the last "show" time slot) truly, what bothered me the most was this theatrical molecular gastronomy thing.  nothing is preserved in the original form, shape, taste or substance which can be fun in the first few courses, but the whole meal consists of this ridiculous illusion.  if all i wanted was a show, i would've gone to las vegas to see cirque du soleil. each and every dish was beautiful and unique, but i can hardly say all were delicious.  in fact, some were even hard to swallow without gulping them down with water.  we had a memorable wedding anniversary celebration at alinea because it was very interactive and magical, and the bubble gum thing was also memorable and fun, but again, i could've had better tasting food using the same ingredients at a fraction of the price.          i get the trend and also respect the new ways of incorporating science into food to elevate our senses, but let's not lose the essence of restaurants; delicious food served with smiles, and in return appreciation for quality ingredients, artistic hands and masterful minds behind them.
3 Michelin star worthy creativity. 2 Michelin star worthy taste. Zero Michelin star worthy service.

Best restaurant in the world. Going to a 3 star Michelin restaurant has been on our bucket list and this exceeded all expectations. We consider ourselves major foodies who live in New Orleans, constantly bombarded with excellent food. This restaurant was next level. 12+ small, creative courses. Each course was creative, rich and complex in flavor and impressively presented. The wine pairing is a must - one of the few times where the food actually does bring out different notes in the wine. Worth every penny and was a once in a lifetime experience.

This restaurant was very artistic and innovative in terms of presentation. I especially enjoyed the citrus aroma infusion for one dish. However, in terms of taste I find it too strong overall even compared to french cuisines in Paris, lacking the balance of taste. I think you can get much better food in New York 3/2 michelin star restaurants for less cost.

Alinea was part of my surprise birthday weekend to Chicago, and it was definitely the highlight of the trip. Alinea recently transformed their dining experience with a new menu and interior decor. I wasn't able to visit pre-renovation, so I can't compare, but the new "2.0" menu was ridiculously delightful. They excel at incorporating all senses, and the performance aspect was far above my other 3-Michelin star experiences. The food itself was also very good and in my top three. We had the upstairs Salon menu, which was the shortest of the menu options. With 11 complex courses, I left thoroughly satisfied. I can only imagine what the Gallery or Kitchen Table menus must be like. A future trip for sure! Some highlights: Course 1: Ice - Served in a bowl made of ice. The unique combination and complex flavors made this one of the more memorable courses of the night. Who would have thought banana sorbet, macadamia, coconut, and prawn tasted so good together? Course 3: Contrast, Sparrow-Grass, Swirl - A visual and olfactory delight. The "swirl" dish released a strong yuzu-scented fog that cascaded over the bowl. The "contrast" was my favorite of the three because of the various textures - olive oil gummies, lavender gel, tomato, watermelon, and parmesan custard. Party in my mouth! Course 6: Glass & Petal -  My favorite savory course. Beautiful plating, thoughtful presentation of onion within itself, and morels! The "glass" dish had glass-like shards made from blueberry and lapsang souchong tea. Underneath were morels covered in foie gras sauce, with bits of a pickled green. So good. Course 7: Toast - Shaved black truffle finger sandwiches!! We are talking pumpernickel toast, layered with gruyere cream, and copious amounts of truffle. A lot of times, black truffle is dried out and lacking in flavor. This was not one of the those times. Heaven. Course 10: Nostalgia - I was excited to see the iconic helium balloons had stayed on from the previous menu, though now in strawberry taffy flavor. The table next to us actually lost a balloon to the ceiling. I wish I got a snap of the waiter standing on a chair and poking at the balloon! The plated part of the course was a dark chocolate square with caramelized fennel ice cream inside, served on an amazing lemon white chocolate cookie over sabayon sauce. Course 11: Paint - This was like a pre-plated version of their table top paint show. Cherry, white chocolate, orange bourbon, coffee, and pistachio flavors made for an insane flavor explosion. Truly one of the the best desserts I've ever had. My sweet tooth can die happy now. Other than a few forgettable dishes, the food was remarkable in its own right. The creativity was evident in every course and flavor combinations consistently surprised me. The service was on point, but laid-back at the same time. This was finesse without the stuffiness. Timing was a little off, and we did have moments where we sat for more than a few minutes over an empty table. Total dining time was just under three hours. I was a bit surprised at the lack of any extra courses, bread, or mignardises with the check. Perhaps that's only for the longer meal options. Not a big deal though. This was in my top three dining experiences, and I wouldn't hesitate to go back.

If you're on the fence about spending the money on Alinea, consider this: you may not fall in love with every single course (out of 18ish courses you are bound to like some better than others) but you will have a unique opportunity to try seasonally fresh and exceptional ingredients paired with an experience to remember.  I would advise avoiding too much research or yelp trolling. Allow yourself to be surprised and make your own judgments. I can promise the entire experience will be exceptional.  I can't say enough about the service. Every staff member remembered and acknowledged the occasion we were celebrating. They were prompt and formal but willing to joke around with us.  Overall, I am very impressed.

Magical. We were fortunate to sit at the chef's table, which was really the only place I would want to be. The meal was definitely an experience - yes, its pricey, but its once in a lifetime (at least for me). My cousin and I were fan-girling over seeing Chef Grant literally steps away from our table. I don't want to spoil all the surprises, but definitely the most interesting meal I've ever had. The wine pairing was out of this world and a definite must.

Alinea doesn't need another 5 star review, but I'm going to add it anyway.  My husband and I went to Alinea last Thursday as a birthday treat. Neither of us had experienced the original Alinea but we were extremely excited to see the new re-vamp.  True to his word, Chef Achatz has re-imagined Alinea away from the original mystere and trickery and has concentrated more on straight up elegance and mind-blowing food.  I had not been to Alinea before but I had heard and read enough about the experience.   I've eaten at Next twice (Vegan and Modern Chinese) and you can't help but compare one experience to the others.  When it comes to food...there's no question.  Alinea is on a whole different level compared to Next.  There was less shock factor at Alinea than you have at Next...less theatrics.  But the food taste and quality is noticeably better - and that's saying a lot because I think Next is phenomenal.  What I love about Next is the way the dishes are presented as tools, and something you didn't realize was even edible and thought was a center piece because the 7th course halfway through the meal.  Or you'll find out your plate is edible at the end but only after you rehydrate it or something like that.  Alinea has less of that kind of show experience (which I love at Next) and focuses just on wowing you with their creations.  For example, one dish was dehydrated scallop paper that was rehydrated in front of you with an amazing broth to become a large scallop noodle that tasted like the best scallop of your life.   Service was impeccable from start to finish and the new atmosphere is open and brightly lit with a simple elegance of whites and grays.  I was actually surprised at how bright it was and had expected much darker lighting that gave a more intimate feel.   We did one alcohol pairing and one non-alcohol pairing.  The wines were exquisite and plentiful and I was happy to just take a few sips from each of my husband's servings as I would have been pretty drunk if I had a pairing of my own.  The non-alcoholic pairing was not as inventive as what you'll see at Next (bell pepper foam, interesting drinkware methods) but each pairing was some sort of juice that included 2 "normal" ingredients and 1 crazy ingredient that blew your mind.  For example, crazy ingredients like banana pepper or black garlic. I don't want to spoil the surprise by describing the dishes but trust that you will not be disappointed and this is an experience to remember.  The hype is worth it, the accolades are worth it.  I feel very fortunate to have experienced such culinary genius.

As some others have suggested, reviewing or awarding Yelp stars to a 3 Michelin Star restaurant seems a little pointless and redundant. This was our 6th (3star) to dine at and what they all have in common is incredible food, impeccable decor, and the best trained staff you will find. To each his own, but I don't know how any 3 Michelin could get less than 5 stars on Yelp without some unimaginable error or event. But from our experiences, each of them are unique in their own way and hard to compare as much as we attempt. As the reviews state, there are different dining experiences at Alinea, and of course different prices. We had the 11 course tasting menu for 4, so no kitchen tastings or family style downstairs. The creativity of the dishes was maybe the best we have experienced, the staff was very professional but also very friendly in a simplistic way, less formal than other places. As a wine bar owner I was a little disappointed in the wine pairings, one Australian Syrah completely missed the mark, and I don't agree with serving 2014 vintages of red wine at these prices (too young). What was INCREDIBLE was our son's non-alcoholic drink pairings made from fruits, herbs, and vegetables. They were so good and fascinating we all almost ordered those also!! The best non-alcoholic drinks I have ever had...period! Would I put this as our best dining experience ever? Overall, we are so happy we finally were able to dine at Alinea and throughly enjoyed the whole evening.

I have to admit that I was so excited to visit this restaurant. It is beautiful. The food looks like a piece of art. I have to give it one star because of THE FLY IN MY FOOD!! When I brought it to the attention of management, they acted as if it were no big deal. Offered to get me another plate. How can a place of this reputation act as if it is not a big deal that there was a FLY IN MY FOOD!!!

I had heard about Alinea and every now and then, heard more about it, a pop-up restaurant there, so and so award here, but I have to admit, it was until Netflix's "Chef's Table" that my husband and I thought: "We are going, and we are going NOW!" So luckily were were able to secure a table for 4 (at the Gallery!) and had a party of 2 ready to make the pilgrimage with us to Chicago. Unfortunately, 4 days prior to our reservation, one of our guests cancelled and it ended up being just the three of us. The restaurant does not issue any refunds. So make sure you are not canceling (unless you are among the lucky few who can sell their tickets to others). They were not willing to apply the $400 credit towards something else (e.g. wine paring) either. C'est la vie [in the universe of Alinea].  All that aside, our evening at Alinea was quite memorable. We dined, along with 12 other patrons in the Gallery. Of course I am not going to spill any details of "the show" but let me just say that they blew our $#%@& minds away!!!! Chef Achatz and his team are doing something quite special here. Their work, their food, moves something in your being that simply cannot be explained.  At some point, during one our magnificent and theatrical dessert courses, I caught myself with teared up eyes, overwhelmed by emotions that I never thought "food" as I knew it until then, could spark within me. I felt very lucky to have experienced Alinea.  They serve beautiful wines by bottle and glass.  Staff could seem a little standoffish, but I think it is because they have very high regard for the establishment that they are a part of (or at least I hope!). Description of a three Michelin star restaurant: Une des meilleures tables, vaut le voyage.  Alinea: truly exceptional and definitely worth a special journey...

It almost feels silly reviewing this place on Yelp, but it was an awesome experience. If you're thinking about it, just bite the bullet, pony up the cash, and have the meal of a lifetime.  We got tickets to the Gallery and had a fantastic, and importantly, really fun meal. I don't want to spoil any surprises -- so won't bother mentioning specifics -- but the meal was totally worth the splurge.  If you're lucky enough to snag a reservation, enjoy!

Ok so Alinea 2.0 I was expecting so much more.   I liked you better before. I was expecting more Willy Wonka. It just left me flat, saying "Danka." It lost its scientist, fun, flair Even though all the food was prepared with much care. It's getting too hard to rhyme...but I have to say...it was a great meal BUT there was a lot I didn't love.   Didn't love the "progression of the meal" Didn't love walking into the communal table Didn't love my caviar frozen to the bottom of the glasses on the first round Didn't love being stuck at the end of the row in the kitchen and straining to try to hear what chef was saying  Didn't love the loss of the "wow" factor Didn't love the duplicate desserts....come on, we've already seen the balloon and the artists dessert. Didn't love the hike in the price  Didn't love single stall bathroom on the first floor that was out of hand towels half way through the meal Did love the food Did love meeting Grant Did love the overall aesthetics  I can't say anything bad about Grant. This is the end of my rant.

Chicago. Day 5. Extravagant birthday dinner. Amazing food.  Great non-alcoholic drinks pairing. Perfect service.  Good atmosphere. Extremely fun experience.  Highlights: Ice tray truffle, caviar communal table appetizers. Surprise table transformation.  Dry ice fruit bowl. Puffed rice bone marrow wagyu beef nigiri. The balloon. The paint. Overall, not just a tasting menu but memorable enjoyable experience. "As good as it gets."

The worst experience I had at any 4 star restaurant! For the money I spent and the fact that this restaurant had 3 michlian stars you would think it be worth it but it wasn't ! The service was terrible ! The servers were cussing at our table and had no idea what dishes were what and what it even was! two of my friends flew from other states to come to experience this restaurant with me and they feel very disappointed in the experience and cheated out of their $300 plus money and we had Informed the manager of the terrible service who could even care less! All of my friends and I work in the restaurant industry in 5 star hotel restaurants and know how a good quality service supposed to be and this was far from it! They did not apologize or do anything to accommodate us! What a waste of money ! It was not worth it at all! Will not return and will let others know to not even waste a single time or dime here!

Let me preface to say that the party I was with we're already huge fans of the Alinea Group and Grant Achatz. We were very eager to visit the restaurant, taking advantage of the opportunity where we all were in Chicago.  We opted for the Salon dining option for 4 people at 9:30 pm. We were greeted immediately and brought out to the dining room. I'll try to avoid spoilers about the experience because I think that is half the magic that takes place at Alinea. Surprise, whimsy, and wonder.  In terms of the food itself, keeping its prestige and price in mind, I was impressed but not blown away by the food. Maybe my expectations were set a bit too high but compared to other three star michellin and worlds 50 best that I have visited, I would say it was just a tad bit underwhelming. Some dishes were absolutely exceptional and will forever be remembered as some of the best plates of food I've ever eaten from a technique and inventive perspective but some dishes lacked the same excellent cohesiveness in concept and execution. However, they reportedly to change their menu every few months so I understand that it's incredibly difficult to uphold consistency at that level while constantly trying to innovate and evolve so I really don't fault them as I do appreciate their willingness to experiment. Were my expectations on the food met? Maybe not. Was it still one of the best meals I've had? Most definitely up there.  What sets Alinea apart is its service and flare. The tricks and surprises on the senses is truly remarkable. This was more theater than fine dining. We were constantly questioning the reason for everything they presented to us knowing that it would result in something either magical and surprising that would serve the compliment the food in a multi-sensory experience. Without giving anything away, I would just recommend to let yourself be immersed in the world they create and remember to see, smell, hear and touch in addition to taste for the full experience.  With that said, I couldn't recommend Alinea more of you have the means to do so. It comes with a hefty bill but it was definitely more than just a dinner. It was an experience we will all remember forever and an example of a restaurant that pushes its boundaries to create a meal about more than just tasting the food.  PS we fan girl'd afterwards and got a pic with Grant. So as an aspiring chef there was no better way to cap off the night than meeting the master himself.

Alinea 2.0 is demonstrably better than the original.  Chef Grant has taken as step back from the theater aspect where plating is amazing and the food looks different than it tastes. The creativity and playfulness is still there, but it is more restrained. The focus is now on amazing food and they nailed every dish.  Nice use of several different cultures and cuisines while still maintaining a coherent meal.  The focus is now the food and its one of the best meals I've had. Before, Aliena was the best experience but you left hungry and underwhelmed. Now its a perfectly well rounded meal and experience Service still is top notch.  Pacing was perfect at right around 3 hours.

Does Alinea need another 5 star rating? Probably not...but honestly I believe it deserves as many stars as humanly possible. This was definitely the best meal I have ever had. It was so creative and whimsical, so full of surprises, and so delicious. And I think it is hard to find all of that. I agree with others that it isn't worth spoiling anything -- so don't read details about the dishes in the other reviews. It is so cool that they really take the theatre part of it seriously and there really is a show and there really are so many things that you don't expect. And they really pay attention to, and are concerned about taste and smell and texture. The service was of course wonderful and friendly.  My only complaint was that there weren't more courses! I was so sad when we got our first dessert!

Alinea has been on my bucket list for a few years, and when I saw "Spinning Plates" at the Milwaukee Film Festival, my desire to experience Alinea grew tenfold! It was closed to remodel and redesign the menu for a while earlier this year. When the reservations opened up, my friend was able to get us in. There seem to be two dining experiences, and the reservation we were able to get was for the 11 course experience. I believe the other might be called the Galleria experience with a few more courses. I didn't really know what to expect, especially since there were changes recently. There were diners at two other tables when we arrived in the dining room we were assigned to. It was fairly quiet. I sat across from my friend at a wide table, which allowed plenty of space for the plating and presentation, but it seemed like she was far away and I didn't want to speak too loudly in such a quiet dining room. Eventually, other diners arrived and the noise level picked up, so I felt more comfortable and relaxed talking across the table in a voice louder than the near whisper I was using when we arrived. I thought the staff was warm and friendly and did everything they could to make us feel welcome and enjoy our experience. One of our servers even joked with us to keep the atmosphere light and fun.  A wine expert was sent over to answer questions and make suggestions, but in a very "laid back" way, as a friend would who wanted to help you make a good decision and not like a wine snob would that wanted to push product. For our experience, he suggested we start with a glass of champagne, so we did. That worked for the first 4 or 5 courses, and then I switched to a glass of pinot noir per his recommendation due to the next group of courses coming. As for the food, what can I say? My mind was blown! That's why I wanted to dine at Alinea, to have my mind blown. I posted some photos, but I'm not going to get into much detail because I couldn't possibly do the dishes justice with my descriptions. A card on the table listed single words to help us track our courses. The server asked if we had any food allergies and explained that the chef uses fresh and in-season ingredients to help plan the menu. We waited in anticipation to see what dish and what components of the dish would represent the word for that course. I think anticipation is what heightens the experience. What are they going to do next?!?! The menu card stated "Ice" would be the first course. Our first course was served in a hand-carved bowl of ice. Inside the bowl were refreshing flavors of Ebi (shrimp) and citrus and coconut.   The next course was "Crunchy Paper" on the menu card. What arrived were crisp, small sheets of paper made from SCALLOPS! They turned scallops into crisp flat sheets! They were served in a flavorful seafood broth. A very savory scallop mousse wrapped in nori (seaweed paper) was also included in this course.  The rest of the evening continued this way with mind blowing, beautifully presented, and very delicious dish after dish. We were both full after the first 8 courses, but we aren't quitters, so we pressed on to the final stretch, which included an edible strawberry balloon and a platter with a combination of flavors, colors, and textures displayed like fine art! At the end, we were given another menu card with a few more words to help describe each course. From the warm greeting at the hostess station, to the welcoming and approachable servers, to the mind blowing food and carefully selected wines, this was one of the best, if not the best, dining experiences I've ever had in my life.  It was worth every penny, and I will to do it again! I'm grateful for the invitation to join my friend for this amazing dining experience, so I could get to Alinea sooner than later!
To die for. Must try. Service was impeccable. Food was out of this world. Everything was beyond amazing. So glad I got to try it!
The feast of the Gods.  Very special time for special occasion and everything is above expectations.

The experience was definitely different and worth checking out. It was art/entertainment/dinner all in one. Must buy tickets in advance and tables only come in pairs up to 6. If you have an odd number of people you would still have to pay for the extra seat. We ended up booking late and had to get 2 tables of 2. I requested if we could sit nearby but they wouldn't accommodate and not only were we not in the same dining room, we were on separate floors! We couldn't pick a different date since we were only in town a few days. The table arrangement was odd and didn't make sense. There was a table of 4 next to us with only 2 people sitting there and another empty 2 person table near us. They could have easily sat us there. Maybe since they know they can get the clientele, you have to go by their rules.

Finally visited Alinea for a long overdue graduation celebration dinner.  I have been looking forward to this for a long time and especially since I watched Chef's Table.   Feeling ok about Alinea.  Liked the experiments and concepts and enjoyed the presentations.  When it came down to the most important point for me, just wasn't wowed by the taste of the food.  Many flavor combinations didn't work for me and did not like many of the dishes.  It was a once in a lifetime experience.  Definitely don't want to come back again.   Servers were attentive most of the time but there were key points when service just failed: 1. All of the tables around us received a long explanation of the artist and concept behind the abstract art last dessert.  Our server just came by and told us "art art art" and gave an extra weird explanation of "utensils utensils" when he laid the spoons and the forks down.  Did not understand the humor behind this.  It was 11:30PM as we were his last guests, maybe he just got tired of explaining for the nth time. 2. When my hair got tangled with the taffy balloon, I was struggling for 5 minutes to get it out with the hot towels they'd provided.  There were 3 servers behind me and they definitely saw what happened.  It wasn't until I flagged one of them down that he suggested washing my hair in the lady's room.  Is it the norm in hospitality industry that when you see a guest struggle with taffy in her hair that you ignore the problem until she asks?  Or is it the norm that when you get taffy in your hair you'd automatically know that you shouldn't use the hot towels provided to you and go straight to the bathroom?

You pay for the experience and what an unique experience.  Our started on a shared table and a delicious appetizers, we moved forward to visit the kitchen and when we got back we had our own table. They kept surprising us with singular meals. The best part was the desert. I highly recommend it.

This was an amazing wonderful experience, certainly much more than just another great meal.  More to follow soon, when I've had time to sleep on it. Dining at Alinea is an elaborate affair, so let me elaborate just what it was that we ate and drank: Osetra Caviar, King Crab, and Condiments: presented in glass in wells in a large block of ice. 2000 Krug "Clos du Mesnil" Champagne, France 100/100 Cucumber, Feta, Caper Leaf Gin, Green Tomato, Chartreuse Scallop, Corn, Butter Shio Kombu, Nori 2012 Domaine Laroche "Les Clos" Chablis Grand Cru 100/100 Sweet Potato Curry Yolks Collet Demi-Sec Champagne, France (NV) 95/100 White Asparagus - Lychee - Lily Bulb Our bowl filled with citrus was set to release a great quantity of smoky mist, as solid carbon dioxide sublimated to vapor and poured out onto the table, then down to the floor. Icefish - Daisy  Mandarin - Radish 2012 Kiedrich Grafenberg Riesling Spälese, Robert Weil, Rheingau, Germany 100/100 Morel - Blueberry - Lapsang Souchong Onion, Purple Allium, Black Pepper 2012 Shiraz, Henschke, Mt Edelstone, South Australia Gruyère - Black Truffle - Pumpernickel A volcanic bowl was placed on the table, containing aromatics, such as cinnamon and star anise, and set alight Something was presented on volcanic platter . . . . Veal Cheek - Chamomile - Melon Wagyu - Rice - Myoga 100/100 The restaurant's name comes from a variant name of the "pilcrow," [ ¶ ] a typographical mark used to indicate individual paragraphs.  The name alinea comes from Latin, "a lineā," meaning "off the line."  Please don't bring your small children or babies, this isn't the right place for them.

I've lived a very blessed life to be able to say Alinea was one of my biggest disappointments. So. Much. Hype. I knew I would have to try Alinea at some point in my 2 years in Chicago. The 6 months of renovations made me nervous I wouldn't make it in time but the stars aligned & I had a table for 2 on the Saturday night of my graduation weekend, the ideal culmination of my time in business school & Chicago. Meant to be. But then.. I mean.. Everyone is helllllla reluctant to say anything bad about this place after paying ONE THOUSAND DOLLARS ($1,000.. Literally. For 2 person dinner with wine pairings) cuz it's painful enough to shell out that kinda money & then to have to admit you wasted all that money on the most EHHHH of meals.. But I'm gonna break this down & tell you: THIS PLACE WAS NOT WORTH IT AT ALL. At all. True story: I went to White Castle for the first time the next day & thought that was a better meal than Alinea. Do that instead.  First & foremost, I did not like the food. I'm a fancy bitch & it's not like I didn't like it cuz it was unfamiliar or different, it actually all tasted kinda subpar. The combinations & flavors were wack. Lamb was so so gamey, ugh! Another example: dish of morels. It was like a cereal bowl of morels in a cream sauce. I thought it was one of the laziest, most unpleasant dishes on the menu. I like morels but after a few the texture starts seeming creepy & it gets too heavy & makes you kinda gag. Gross.  I hadn't been there before the renovations so I can't compare. But here are a few other things that were fucking annoying about this new Alinea experien: -NO SURPRISES. You're getting served your meal in a room of other tables also getting their meals (duh, right?) except it's the fucking WORST cuz all the tables are getting different dishes at different times. So my reservation was at 8:30-- apparently they had tables at 8:20, 8:40, & 8:50 as well cuz I could see all the damn dishes that were gonna come after the one I was eating cuz the tables across from us were getting them already!! Goddammit, I thought the surprise was part of the whole fucking point!! No surprises!! One silver lining with a table behind us in the line-up meant I could listen again to the description of the food cuz they just kept blowing through them all -NO DIRECTIONS. I'm not accustomed to being served a beautiful plate of abstract shit just sprawled across it so I don't know how to eat it. Staff was sooooooooo ho-hum & I had to ask every. Single. Dish.. "Sooo.. How do you.. Eat.. This..?" Stop making me feel like an asshole. Found out afterwards that this new Alinea post-renovation is encouraging guests to eat it however they want. You know what though? That is really fucking unhelpful cuz I don't know how to eat whatever this thing is & you just gave the description in one breath (rushed, abrupt, incomplete, unsatisfactory)  -STAFF SUCKED. Mentioned it already but the staff was incredibly blasé. Like maybe they got used to 6 months of not doing that damn thing but the service was kinda clunky (different servers asking each other things & shooting the shit) & the attitude was VERY eh. Indifferent, casual, just whateverz. Even if it was McDonald's I would be like, not that nice but whatever. But for this caliber of a restaurant?? Eye rolling, smirking, not at alllll polished. New staff ASAP pls I'm giving it 1 star cuz the plates were pretty, I'll give them that. BUT none of that cool drawing dessert on your table or aromatic experience (some wood chip burning thing MIGHT have been planned as an aromatic  experience but I'm not sure cuz 1. I didn't smell anything & 2. The staff didn't tell me about it) that I was super super hyped about. Soooooooooo disappointing.

You must go once to experience the food, presentation, service.  but in my opinion once is enough.  Visual excellence.  Creative preparations and 4 star chef/owner - Grant. Was rated #1 in USA a few years ago.

Most amazing meal I have had in my life, twice. I have traveled around the world eating at several 3 Michelin star restaurants and this is by far my favorite. Food and service are outstanding of course, but what is different is the experience. The food and portrayal of the food tells a unique story making it a one of a kind experience each time. Whenever I visit Chicago, I make a point to try to get tickets to experience Alinea again and again.
Amazingly creative and perfectly prepared food, emotions-provoking atmosphere/experience, wonderfully knowledgeable staff -- we were so impressed. Definitely magical. Chef Grant knows his craft.

Let me begin by saying that I made the trip to Chicago solely to visit Chef Achatz at Alinea.  As a lover of food and fine dining how could I not? Arrived at the restaurant and was quite surprised to find that it is located in a very quiet and almost residential area.  I actually quite liked this, as I felt it added character to the restaurant.  You walk in and see what looks like a long hallway but really is just an illusion, there is a dining area by the kitchen downstairs and one upstairs,  My husband and I were seated upstairs and were relieved to find that we had a great corner table with plenty of space and privacy.  Had the tasting menu without the wine pairings opted to order bottles (2) of wine instead.  Sommelier was gracious and helpful with suggestions but ultimately went with a Russian River (yes please) Pinot Noir. The meal itself was fun and whimsical, the flavors were just ok.  Some of the dishes, especially the chicory root wrapped in twigs (were you have to forage for your food) just did not wow me.  The presentation and the "aahs" were greater than the taste.  Our favorite dish, which was not on the tasting menu and we decided to add on was the truffle risotto.  The helium ballon was so much fun.  We laughed so much trying to get it in our mouths.  Favorite part of the tasting menu, the dessert.....oh my!!! the set up, the presentation, just wow.  Truly an edible work of art.  The flavors delicate and mild with such a great mixture of textures.   Overall a dining experience I will never forget, just left me wishing for bolder more memorable flavors.  If you have the opportunity definitely visit.  I also loved peeking into the kitchen as I was leaving.  Always a fan of seeing #chefsatwork. M.P.

What an experience! It was an art. Visit to kitchen was amazing and service was perfect throughout dinner. Sommelier explained about all wine for pairing and it was impressive with his knowledge and enjoyed selections. All I can say about dinner is that it was art/entertainment. It's super pricy and hard to make a reservation as we checked availability for past 2-3 months everyday for two seatings and we got lucky a day before as we were being very flexible. It was once in a life time experience.

I have eaten at pretty much every 3 Michelin star restaurant in North America and Alinea is my absolute favorite.  I was there last week post renovation and chef Grant Achatz' creations were beyond spectacular........his attention to detail and unbelievable level of creativity makes for a unique experience.  An absolute must for any true foodie!

It's so glad that Alinea completed their remodeling work and it's an excited news that we got our reservation tickets!!! Feels so lucky!!!!!! We chose the "Gallery" one and we do think it's a serious contender for best restaurant in the US (another contender is The French Laundry). First, the new decoration completely blow our mind. The "gallery" one will let everyone sit together to take the first course in one huge table. After everyone completed the cocktails with a kitchen tour, the huge table disappeared magically and the individual tables are ready. If you realize the paintings on the roof, yeah! They are not only beautiful but also for the surprise of your last course!! I prefer not to leak the details here, but that's indeed a super surprise!! Second, for the food, most of the dishes were pretty amazing! The "molecular gastronomy" cooking is super creative! The scallop (in paper shape) is the best scallop we ever took, and the cheese course is the best pair we tried before! The strawberry ballon is not only tasty, but also made the whole dinning room full of joy and laugh. The last course, wow, one of the most creative one we ever seen in US!  Service part, each staff is well trained, extremely attentive and polite. They also quite willing to share the knowledge and experience they have and answer any question we have. If you still trying hard to get the tickets, try it harder! Totally worths!!!!
By far the best meal I've ever had! The experience was mesmerizing! Each course was perfection! Chef Grant and the staff truly gave us a once in a life time evening!
An experience worth trying... delicious, artistic and truly professional. Having been to Next, Grace, and other higher end dining experiences I will say this is truly unforgettable!

Okay, I've given a lot of five star reviews, so it pains me to give Alinea only five stars. It's been years since I went, but as I told my father later, justifying the cost of the meal, you really only need to go to Disney World once (or maybe the Moon would be more apt). Hyperbole? No, sorry. I went in with high expectations, and was blown away. I wish I could remember the details of the meal -- this was 4 years ago, I believe -- but what I do clearly recall is the hair standing up on the back of my neck. Twice. Yes, that good. To end the evening, as if it needed anything else, I got a chance to meet Grant and had a quick tour of the kitchen ... feeling like I was backstage, seeing half engineering, and half magic.

My wife and I were very excited to eat at Alinea in late June 2016 for our wedding anniversary. Having worked hard to book tickets for that day in advance and shelled out the advanced charge of over $500 (including a 20% service charge) our expectations were high. We were greeted warmly and seated promptly after arriving. The creativity and taste of the food throughout the night was absolutely amazing - except for maybe 1-2 courses we both loved everything.  However, the main issue we had was the service. As with other places we've eaten, the servers changed often with different people serving us different courses. However the quality of the servers was poor to say the least. They mumbled and rushed through the explanation of each course to the point we honestly didn't know what we were eating or the complexities involved. What's worse is we could hear servers at other tables explaining the courses with details that were never provided to us which would have made it a much better experience. Further, the people who served us didn't seem particularly happy or interested to be there or doing what they're doing. What's frustrating about this is the restaurant pre-charges a 20% service charge prior to arriving and even tacked on a 20% service charge to our wine pairing which seemed excessive. Normally this would be fine but you'd expect the service to live up to that standard. While we thoroughly enjoyed the food, we were severely disappointed by the experience/service which honestly is what Alinea is more about. Having eaten at other 3 Michelin star restaurants (we live in NYC) this is the worst one thus far and I doubt we'll be returning here again.

Fantastic presentation of courses for my hubby and I last night.  Wine pairings were well-matched.  Didn't eat the Foie Gras, personal preference.  Edible helium balloon was a lot of fun.  My husband requested a cookbook and thought he had already paid for it online when securing the reservations but we were informed he wasn't charged for it and so we opted out of the purchase. Dessert finale was yummy-on a clear glass over artwork  (artist is a friend of the owner's).

Four words. Art, Science, Memories, Incredible. Absolutely loved the food, the service, the drinks, the presentation, everything! I just wish Michelin star restaurants were in prettier locations like facing the lake or something. Oh yes, they also custom made our food since we are vegetarian. The best part is that they also let you take pictures of their food and check out their kitchen. Who doesn't want to see a Michelin star kitchen!

The experience is certainly unique and filled with surprises!  The staff is top notch, courteous and really takes hospitality to a new level.  Unfortunately, I was disappointed with the dishes.  The dishes were  creative and exotic however did not excite my taste buds.  I was entertained with each dish as they are presented tastefully and even fun at times. I really felt that Alinea did not meet my expectations, because of all the hype behind it, I just simply expected more!  Overall, great service, Great experience, mediocre food at best.

OK, to start with, my review is of the "old Alinea" since I am catching up with all the places I've eaten at over the last few years. If you need a review of the most recent iteration of Alinea you can skip mine and go on to the next one. But I think my observations will still have merit since as far as I can tell the aim of the restaurant hasn't changed -- and that is to serve a meal that is literally a work of art. We were served eighteen courses that progressed from savory to sweet. The size of the circle on the menu indicated the size of the portion from a single bite to a larger plate. Some were Alinea classics (Black Truffle Explosion, and Hot potato-Cold  potato with black truffle), others were seasonal and unique to out visit. Alinea was a bit pretentious and kind of "full of itself" but this didn't negate the creativity and flavor of the food. Servers and sommelier were arrogant and not interested in engaging in any conversation about the food or wine, but yet they were highly professional and efficient. The wine pairing was very good but I've had better at a couple of other highly rated restaurants.  Still, all in all, Alinea was one of the most significant dining experiences of my life. Was it the best food or service ever? Probably not. Was it the most creative and artistic meal I've ever eaten? Without a doubt the answer is yes.

I do not give out 5 stars that often but with this Resturant I really wanted to give it 6 stars. The service was excellent,innovative and provided surprising dishes appealing to both the eyes and taste buds.  I would have to say this was more of an amazing experience than a Resturant. The wine pairings were incredible   The chef was very  accommodating to various dietary restrictions or personal choices.  As one of the people said as they were leaving the Resturant "this was one of the best meals/experiences I've ever had.  It was to die for!!!!"  Don't want to give away too much about specific dishes as the surprise is part of the experience. This should be on everyone's bucket list as it is a must do!!!!!  Reservations are a must but it is well worth the wait. I will definitely be back. AWESOME!!!!!!!!!

For years I've been dreaming of the day I would finally get a reservation to Alinea. It would be the pinnacle of my dining experience. If all these other fine dining places I've been to like Sixteen, Tru, Morimoto,etc... were amazing, I couldn't imagine how crazy good Alinea was going to be.  First plate started out good, but it just never really took off from there. Many of the dishes were intriguing, with complex, layered and exotic flavor combinations. The ingredients described for each dish sounded great, but each and every time, it was either too tart, too salty or too bland. Don't get me wrong, they were still good, and if you were the type who is very adventurous, would probably enjoy being jostled with every bite. A flavor roller coaster would be a good description of the meal.  BUT, I just did not enjoy the meal, at all. It wasn't bad, it wasn't great. It's almost sooo average it hurts. Yes, service is good (4/5 compared to other fine dining), decor is nice, but food failed. If I had to rate the food alone, I'd say (2/5).  Besides from being uninspired, I also found a few of the plates to be pure gimmick, like the balloon candy and the final "paint" dish. Plain sugar candy blown up with helium. Made for a good laugh but didn't taste like anything other than fruit roll ups. The paint dish was just some fudge, crumbs, a few flavored syrups, nitrogen ice cream all tossed onto a painting in front of you. Great for entertainment, but nothing special taste wise.  I'll sum up my experience to this: If I was given this exact meal for FREE, and all I had to do was come back and spend another 4hrs there to eat it, I would not take the offer. It may be worth the experience to come once, but not worth the time to come back.

Outstanding experience. Very good food, although a couple dishes in the line-up always tend to be a bit weak, while there's usually one or two that are extraordinary.  Go for the experience and brilliant service. The food can be topped at other places in Chicago, but not by many.

I'm pleased to say that the 2016 reinvention of Alinea has been a phenomenal improvement. So much so, in fact, that it now is again a serious contender for best restaurant in the US. First of, the complete redesign of the space has resulted in a comfortable, sedate environment where the food and wine are the focus. The new furnishings are cozy and the ambiance is quiet, with no loud soundtrack. As a result, conversations tend to be muted and the communication with the servers is enhanced. And certainly there are no better servers around than those at Alinea, where everyone is well trained on the components of each complex dish, and the accompanying wine pairings. Best of all, the new menu has placed the focus squarely on the food. While each course is presented in meticulously chosen dinnerware--from gorgeous dishes fashioned of hand crafted ceramic to ephemeral bowls of ice--the spotlight is on the food in those bowls, not gimmicky utensils or serving platforms. The didactic instructions of exactly how to eat each course are gone, and now you are invited to experiment and explore with the flavors on your plate.  In this new incarnation, feedback is actively solicited as they find their way to the favorite dishes. Certainly the first five courses were absolute knockouts, and the wine pairings that accompanied them pure genius. It's a bit hard to count the courses, because the menus is an avant-garde map, and many courses consist of multiple dishes, but trust me, you won't leave hungry, whether you chose the upstairs salon experience or the more elaborate downstairs experiences.  I felt the salon offered more than enough fine dining, and ten great wine pairings, all at a very fair price.  If you haven't been to Alinea for a while, or you are looking for a stellar dining experience in Chicago, there can be no better place to start.

Anyone who considers himself a food aficionado must dine here once. Not a "meal", but an immersive, life altering experience. The kind of place that will forever color any restaurant meal you ever have afterwards.  It's as much a theatrical experience as it is a restaurant, and if you have the means I would absolutely recommend give this a try. As the young'uns say, YOLO. You'll be surprised just how full you can get with one or two bite courses, over a few hours! I recommend doing the wine pairings. Thanks, Grant!

Tickle my senses!  Reservation slots open for every few months at a time and you pay upfront to book your reservation. Our party decided to do pairings with our 11 course dinner, which lasted 5 hours! And I say that in a good way because it was such an amazing experience throughout as we tried all the different courses that played with our senses. We started to feel a little bummed a little over halfway through because we knew the dinner had to come to an end once we got to dessert. The service was fantastic and made our experience even more enjoyable and memorable. They gave us a menu with the list of the food and wines we had for dinner as a keepsake, loved that! Definitely recommend this gem if you have the chance to go. Don't do the pairings and just order a couple bottles of wine to accompany dinner instead, unless you prefer pairings.

Such an amazing experience! We ate here for an anniversary dinner. The service was impeccable and the courses were spot on. Come here with an open mind and an open wallet. You will taste things you've never tasted before. Cheapest tickets and standard wine pairing will cost about $500/person. Definitely worth it.

We were lucky enough to snag a reservation in the Salon the first week they reopened after renovations.  This was the best dining experience of my life.  Food, service, entertainment and ambiance were all top notch.  My husband agreed, easily the best dining experience we have had.  More of the courses will be talked about for years to come than those we had at Le Bernadin and Arzak.  The food and service were both better and more fun that than at Per Se.  And Alinea simply leaves Eleven Madison Park in the dust.  I can't wait to see Alinea's meteoric rise on the list of the 50 best restaurants in the world this year.

At what other restaurant can you blow an edible balloon, have a campfire lit on your table, have your centerpiece turned into a delicious broth, and have an edible piece of art masterfully drawn on your table?  The answer is: nowhere.  My boyfriend and I came here for our graduation dinner after making a reservation a month in advance and the experience was definitely worth the wait!  The experience was truly unforgettable and full of surprises and unique plating unparalleled anywhere. - 1st Dish: Steelhead with english pea and chamomile steam.  It was light, airy and the perfect start to the meal.  - 2nd Dish: The skate with brown butter and lemon, which we ate in one delicious buttery melt-in-your mouth bite.  Again, fresh and perfect for spring. - 3rd Dish: The first surprise of the night: "graffiti" with orange carrot juice "spray painted" onto the dishes, served on a slab of concrete.  I've never had a waiter "spray paint" my plate before! - 4th Dish: Surf clam soup that you drink from a metal straw straight from the plate, surrounded by delicate small bites that paired perfectly with the salty broth. - 5th Dish: Another surprise! We had been marveling at the strange "light" hanging above our table during the first 4 dishes, only to have our waiter take it down and mix it into a delicious darjeeling broth! The broth then was poured on top of egg plant and mustard seeds for a slightly more sour dish. - 6th Dish: Three bites: Blue Crab, Tamarind caramel, and Siam Sunray Ice.  Each was a great refreshing palate cleanser for the middle of the meal. - 7th Dish: Angelfish jaw street food! This was probably my favorite.  It was crispy with a delicious sauce served atop a Chinese newspaper. - 8th Dish: Let there be Fire!  Percebes: Tororo Kombo with smoked foie gras and hamachi to roast over the fire.  The foie gras was rich and the hamachi fresh! Such a fun interactive dish! - 9th Dish: Goose barnacles!  Because... why not? - 10th Dish: Guess what was hidden in the fire? Pork belly and parsnip!  Great grilled flavor and char on both. - 11th Dish: Another one of my favorites: Hot potato, cold potato- with black truffles!  Creamy potatoes with amazing truffle flavor. - 12th Dish: Rabbit with morels served on moss and real California redwood!  - 13th Dish: Beginning of the desserts-- believe it or not: chocolate ice cream in a glass bowl!  So crazy for being completely crystal clear. - 14th Dish: Cheesecake with matcha, berries, and hibiscus.  Great offset of flavors between the matcha and the berries. - 15th Dish: The famous Green Apple Balloon with helium inside.  Delicious, but messy.  But seriously, where else can you eat a balloon? - 16th Dish: The Art.  They brought out all the ingredients in separate little bowls first.  Complete with fresh passionfruit, sauces, and gummies.  But the presentation was the true grand finale.  The waiter created art right on our table with all of the ingredients thrown onto the canvas with flair.  Each were a new bite to try and each person got one of each ingredient so no one was left out.  Overall, amazing presentation, such a fun and exciting and out-of-this-world meal.  Definitely worth going to for the experience. You won't be disappointed.

It's totally worth it! Our servers were each very knowledgeable, the presentation for each coarse was amazing, & the food might have looked different but each one was absolutely wonderful! I looked how each meal was paired up with an art piece!

BEST MEAL OF MY LIFE. It's not just food, it's an experience. Think food + theater + intrigue. I've been to many of the top 100 restaurants, and no one has ever kept me guessing with such multi-sensory excitement paired with top notch flavor and service. I didn't even imagine such a place could exist. Yes, it will break your bank, but if you can afford it, the dollar-to-awesomeness ratio is through the roof.

Food: I did not go with the expectation that the food would blow me away. I am a taco truck kinda girl! I was really more excited about the presentation and the creativity.  I had a lot of fun eating at Alinea- nothing tastes like you expect it to and so every bite is a surprise. My favorite dish was a corn broth. The rest of the dishes were hit or miss. There were a couple of dishes that as a whole I did not like but certain elements were really yummy.  Service: I expected a lot of snobbery but the staff were very approachable and friendly. The sommelier was also friendly. I am not a wine drinker but she picked out a great wine. On a random note I loved all of the different plates and silverware. I almost pocketed an iridescent fork and spoon.  Atmosphere: We had a 930 seating and I would recommend something earlier. I was sitting against the wall and was able to see all of the courses so nothing was really a surprise. The gallery is also very busy with servers and such buzzing around.  So if you are easily distracted try to get an earlier reservation.

I normally wouldn't leave a place like Alinea only 3 stars, however I'm quite disappointed in my experience given that I paid a nice chunk of rent money to eat here. I always thought that a 3-star Michelin restaurant should have amazing food....so my expectations were exactly that: to taste and eat amazing food. Sadly, it was not so. I'm now wondering if this restaurant received all those accolades and stars simply for their theatrical and creative way of presenting dinner rather than the way the food actually tastes?  Of our 10 courses, I only liked -- not loved -- 1 or 2. Nothing truly tasted delicious, or impressed me simply by taste. The ingredients list that the servers recite before each dish was certainly impressive. You don't remember half of what they're saying but they definitely mention some interesting ingredients. However, what does that matter if it doesn't TASTE delicious? Many courses were too salty! My husband agreed. It became inedible but I didn't want to look rude so I forced myself to eat as much as I could. Believe it or not, after awhile I started DREADING the next course!!! That is unbelievable, right? To wonder when the meal would end?!?  And fyi, I had the non-alcoholic drink pairing so maybe I should've gotten the wine pairing? The non-alcoholic pairing consisted of fruit juices that were most of the time too flavorful and overpowering. Again, they made use of unique ingredients like black garlic, but like I said before, cool ingredients do not mean your creation will taste excellent. On a positive note, the service alone could earn 3 Michelin stars (and 5 stars on Yelp). I am now spoiled by the Alinea staff who escorted me to the bathroom EVERY single time I had to pee (and when I'm drinking a new fruit juice with each of my 10 courses, I have to pee a lot)! I will definitely miss being walked to the bathroom when I return to "regular" restaurants....Anyway, every staff member was extremely attentive and polite. Our water was always refreshed and our napkins were replaced each time we left the table. Bottom line: Come to Alinea if you enjoy being pampered like royalty and want to eat art. But don't expect art to necessarily please your taste buds.
