The most amazing meal I will probably ever have.  Completely worth it; Grant Achatz is a genius and creates such an innovative dining experience.  My favorite was the black truffle explosion.

I've had the pleasure to eat at Alinea twice. It is artistry on a plate. The flavors of each course is heaven, but because there are many courses, you do not have much room left in your stomach for dessert.  We had Chef Achatz create our dessert for us - it was amazing to watch a genius at work. I would go back again (for a special occasion, of course).

Note: I was here for a business dinner, meaning I'm reviewing the food and the experience with a minor consideration for the $270 price tag. I hate to say it, but I really have experienced better. There were at least 4 dishes I didn't finish completely because I just didn't like them. Had I known what they were, I would have actively selected other dishes. Hospitality was great and paying for the meal was discreet (they just charged the card I reserved with, which I appreciated in a business setting), but the food was just average, if not worse. The dining experience as a whole was a performance, with food having a minor role. Had I come in expecting a performance instead of a meal, this would be 5 stars for sure. I guess if you're 26, and this is the first expensive meal you're taking your significant other to, I'd suggest going elsewhere. This is good if you've experienced many fine dining restaurants where you can add context as to how this fits in with the greater dining universe.

A futuristic restaurant. Waiters were a little tight and not friendly.  I didn't understand some of the food in terms of how it taste. Ambience was different. Can't explain you have to experience it. The entrance hall was a natural grass!!  Would recommend to friends for the experience.

Holy Flipping Moly!  Every foodie should experience this restaurant in their lives. The entire experience and presentation is world class. The evening started off with a communal course with all the other diners in a central room. The second course was inside the kitchen with custom beverages made by the chef ... Then suddenly we were escorted back into the central room where everyone was seated at their own tables for the remaining of the dining experience. The food combinations are fresh, unique, and exquisite. The servers all have fantastic personality, which is a great separation from the norm of world class dinning. And in the end you will experience dining entertainment production. Chef Achatz nails it.
This place is all about theater, mistaking gimmicks for "creativity". If you are into circus shows, this is a great place for you.

Daniel's View This restaurant is an adventure from the moment you get there.  The building is nondescript.  If you weren't looking, you would never know is is there.  Once entering you follow a long dark red corridor.  It appears to go forever, but then suddenly a door opens to you left and you are in Alinea, one of the best restaurants in the world.  When going to Alinea, you don't get a menu to choose from.   You get what master chef Grant Achatz has planned.  If you go in wanting a true gastronomic experience, and adventure in food, art, and beauty, then you will be in heaven.  Every portion of the dinner experience is a piece of art unto itself, each one fascinating, yet mysterious at the same moment.  We chose to do a wine pairing with each course, and although an (significant) extra cost, we felt the pairing would be well worth it and, anyway, what the hell.  The wine pairings are magnificent.  There was one particular bottle my wife loved so much that she tried to buy some bottles to take home (with no luck, oh well).  I am not describing the individual courses because I do not think I can do them justice.  After our meal, and many fine glasses of wine, our hosts graciously made arrangements at Boca, a neighbor bar/restaurant for more drinking and merrymaking.  They called ahead for us and escorted us over there straight to our table.  I cannot say enough about the amazing experience that is Alinea.  It is one that will stay with me forever. Be advised-  Alinea is reservation ONLY.  And you must make these via the Alinea website ONLY.  Look early and look often, but choice time slots (i.e., Friday at 7 pm) go fast.  We made our reservation about two months in advance.  When you make the reservation you pay most of the full cost up front (over a grand).  Once you've made the reservation it is a done deal.  No canceling, no refunds.  The only thing you could hope to do is actually go to the restaurant or try to 'sell' your reservation.  I recommend committing yourself to going.  You won't regret it.  Truly a culinary masterpiece. Julie's View- The idea alone of going to a top 10 restaurants in the world is fascinating. but once you get to the place you realize the reason behind the fascination. it feels like you are going on a secret society kind of thing as you are taken inside the restauran -walking through the hallway that magically disappears and then right then you know what an amazing night you have ahead.  Julie's Rating 1-10 Atmosphere:  8 Food: 10 service: 8 Price: 7 (considering the quality and all the effort put behind the making your nigh special) Presentation: 9 Staff: very knowledgeable about the actual dish, preparation and wine Note: do not be ashamed of taking pictures even videos, take your time and enjoy the food presented in form of art.  the decor in this restaurant is simplistic/ Chic / functional dressing up is required plus makes for some awesome pictures :) enjoy
An absolutely memorable dining experience!  Words can't express all the amazing food, service and gustatory delights I had at this place!

This was art that you eat.  My husband brought me here for my birthday before we had kids and I'm so glad we got to go.  The food and service were fantastic and we left there a little tipsy because every meal came with a different wine.  It was entertaining to listen to the people around us talking like they either could make that dish or reviewing it like it was an art piece.  Generally everyone talked in a low tone which I found weird.  Anyway I'm glad I went and celebrated this Chicago gem but I don't think we'll be back again.  Now I think of other ways I would want to spend that much money.

My fiancé and I decided to not get each other gifts for our 6th year anniversary, instead we surprised each other with our picks of fine dinning. My fiancé's pick was Sixteen at Trump Tower, so you can guess who pick Alinea.  The restaurant is a bit hidden and hard to fine.  The guy standing outside asking us as we walked by aimlessly looking, if we're looking for Alinea sure helped. Once you walk in it has a very dark and dungeon like feel as you reach the reception. They help you with your coat and check them in, very formal. I can't help but felt it a bit pretentious, didn't come off very inviting. Maybe because instead of asking me if I would like to check in my coat they just gestured me to take off my coat and took it away. Whatever, not a big deal, but when you set high expectations for a place you pay attention to even the little things, can't help it.   The main server we got was not very chatty. We thought he was trained that way because the ambience of the restaurant was quiet, but I think it just depends on who you get, because we looked around and some seemed a bit more friendly with a little small talk here and there. Ours just told us what each course was and left.  Anyhow, there were so many courses to list, and no point in naming them because they change their menus seasonally so it's not like you can come back and order the same thing. Having said that, the food was an experience to be had in a lifetime. Some courses were not as flavorful as others but it plays with texture, your senses and that's pretty neat.  You have to be open and adventurous to try anything they serve you, if you're a picky eater, then it's best for you to stay away.  A couple things I think they don't change is the final dessert presentation at the end on your table and a floating edible helium balloon. That was a cool finish.  We had our final dessert presented by owner Grant Achatz himself, and I must say it was "weird". After our server lined up all the sweets next to our table, Grant came out from the kitchen to our table, he didn't say Hi or anything to acknowledge our presence he just started grabbing each ingredient and stating what they were in monotone before he put them on the table. This awkward presenting of the dessert went on for about 5 mins...until he finally finished as he used a spoon to crack open a chocolate ball open on the table, mumbled something, maybe enjoy? Then left without a word. I looked at my fiancé like, is this part of some culinary art that I'm not getting? 10 mins later he came out to do the same thing for the table beside us and it's funny to watch, because the guy kept trying and didn't get the clue and kept asking Grant questions and Grant would continue to speak in one word, short answers. At least it wasn't something against us.  5 stars is for the presentation of each course. Very creative. 3.5 for service, very subpar for its kind.

When 3-star Michelin Chefs play, this is how theatrical --- and according to New Yorker me, rather tacky --- it could be. They called it 'The Progression'. First I was happy to be booked at Alinea, known for its notorious waiting list where reservations are made months in advance, expecting the 3-star Michelin dinner by Chef Grant Achatz but instead experienced this experimental pop-up version of his famed cutting edge and avant garde molecular gastronomy fare. It wasn't too happy because I had sublime expectations (sadly true!) but at the end of the rather unusual service I have to give it to them for effort.  The Progression Experience It looks like they are experimenting on Asian and Islands flavor. We were brought to 5 different rooms. It started in a tiny art gallery  with unlimited Japanese- inspired amuse-bouche and interactive quick lesson in mixology. The next was in a dining hall where they experimented on different ambience and serving styles (so tacky, I don't want to elaborate anymore). The next was a kitchen tour where we had a few Mexican courses and DIY with the Chefs. Next was the 'forest room', an indoor venue with fresh grass floor and several food stands that were serviced and curated by several Chefs who handed us scientifically-mangled food items. We sat in wooden picnic tables, chat with the staff and other diners while 80s music played. Last rooms was another serving of amuse-bouche in a hall covered with a big graffiti blanket where diners were encouraged to self express. This is a place where you go because you are curious, not for filling up the tummy. I was filled, but not happy.  Looks like I am not a fan of the experimental, at least not this kind.  Only take away: my vocabulary was temporarily enriched by a lot of unfamiliar cooking and preparation techniques that I all forgot the following day.  Wish list: I just want 3-star Michelin Chef Grant Achatz. Where is he? #AlineaTheProgression #Alinea #Aviary #GrantAchatz

This is one these places it's worth checking out, as long as you're up for just about anything.  Food presentation is outstanding and obviously not cheap.  Variety of food is graciously prepared with a flare and creativity.

I really want to give this place a 5 stars, but my experience was not the best.  Went to Chicago for a long weekend trip, and decided to come here to celebrate end of exams. We reserved 2 weeks before and paid in advance online. We were presented with a 14 course meal, some of my favourites included the lobster, black truffle, duck, and milk chocolate. The lobster dish included curry, earl grey, and grapefruit. The duck dish was presented 5 ways including foie gras. The black truffle was presented like a dumpling, and as you bite into it the richness of the truffle and parmesan cheese ooozes out. The milk chocolate finale was a piece of artwork made in front of us, consisting of a centerpiece of chocolate, with splashes of violet puree, hazelnut, and cream on the side. I was not a big fan of the lily bulb, and rhubarb. The lily bulb was way to sour for my taste, I believe it was included as a palette cleanser but nevertheless, I did not enjoy it. The rhubarb consisted of celery root, celery branch, and licorice, and was a miss.  Overall, the presentation, creativity, and attention to detail in all of the dishes are spectacular. Definitely a 5/5 on that end. However, the taste of the plates were a hit or miss. In my opinion, there is definitely a greater emphasis on the presentation of the food versus the actual taste.  The waiters/waitresses that we encountered seemed a bit pretentious. I felt like we were constantly being pushed to finish our dishes so they can serve the next dish, and this definitely detracted from the overall dining experience. Only thing I liked was when we left the restaurant, the doorman called us a cab. I would give the overall service a 2.5/5.  Overall verdict: Superb presentation of the dishes, subpar service. Would not recommend. I'm sure there are comparable restaurants in the Chicago dining scene with better service.

Alinea is on the list of "must eat" places for any "foodie", and I certainly was no different. The restaurant stopped taking reservations over the phone several years ago. Now, they sell "tickets", which go on sale the month prior. Their reasoning was that it was taking two full time employees to answer the phones for reservations, and to make their reservations more "transparent" as anybody could see their schedule. Getting the preferred date and time is somewhat akin to winning the lottery. Some say that getting the earliest reservation possible is the way to go, that way you don't "see what's coming" as servers bring dishes to neighboring tables. The restaurant is located in a non-descript gray building on Halsted. If it weren't for the very small valet parking sign, you would have a hard time finding the restaurant. I was able to reserve a 5:00 PM reservation, the earliest available. After being seated, the noticeable things were the "centerpiece" of rosemary, mint and lemon rind in a pitcher, as well as a lily and shishito pepper hanging from the ceiling. The meal began with an aperitif of a peach "juice ball" with basil on top of some frozen crumbles. We were instructed to just eat the peach ball first. The next "course" used the water pitcher in which prosecco was poured into the pitcher then shaken to remove all of the bubbles. This was poured over the "frozen crumbles", which was actually frozen alcohol. The dish together was somewhat reminiscent of a bellini. The next course consisted of 3 small dishes. The first consisted of bread, Iberico ham and manchego cheese. The bread was pillowy soft, while the ham and cheese added a salty punch. This was a high class ham and cheese sandwich. The second was a gelatin cube with flavors of guindilla de Ibarra (a type of chili pepper), anchovy and olive.  Once again, this dish had a strong salty component to it.  This was not one of my favorites. The last dish consisted of paprika, chili and garlic.  Despite the strong flavor profiles of the ingredients, the taste was somewhat subdued and underwhelming. The next course was a soup. Inside of the bowl, was a fennel tea with tapioca pearls and a gazpacho foam made of tomatoes and strawberries. We were given a metal boba straw to drink the soup. On the rim of the dish was a strawberry, tomato, basil, pumpernickel and burrata cheese. The soup was very refreshing and fun. On the rim of the dish, the tomato tasted like a strawberry, and the strawberry tasted like a tomato. The next dish was served in a bowl that looked like a shell that was sitting in another bowl with dry ice. The dry ice enveloped the shell looking dish with a thick fog which contained Arctic char roe, peas, olive oil and chamomile. The salty theme continued with the roe, but was mellowed with the peas and olive oil. The next dish was a salad served on a slab of concrete. The salad consisted of white and green asparagus, fava beans, black truffles and a carrot dressing that was "spray painted" over the salad. The asparagus and fava beans were nice and firm, the black truffles adding some earthiness while the carrot dressing added a hint of sweetness. This was a nicely balanced, creative and fun. The hanging squash blossom and chile were also brought into play. There was a black kettle and "charcoal" that were set on fire, but this was the beginning of the following course. There were several components to the dish. There corn with uni butter and togarashi; ice fish cracker with smoked Hamachi tartar and kombu seaweed. Lastly, on a piece of driftwood adorned with seaweed were goose barnacles. On the rosemary was unagi with umeboshi (pickled plum), brown sugar and soy glaze. The "charcoal" was yakitori chicken legs wrapped in kombu and nori. Another piece of charcoal was daikon. The shishito pepper had been grilled. The lilly flower was served raw. A dashi was poured over the entire dish, which had been kept warm over the fire. Next was the signature hot potato-cold potato. The dish is served in a wax bowl with a pin holding a black truffle hot potato. By pulling out the pin, the hot potato is dropped into cold truffle and potato soup. The interplay between temperature and texture makes this a simply wonderful, and stunning dish. The next dish brought a large vase filled with olive brances with pieces of oily, cottony fluffy olive bread. The remainder of the dish included black grapes, green and black olives, lamb loin and tenderloin, lamb sausage, greek yogurt sauce and lamb jus. The bread was meant to use to sop up the sauces. The lamb was perfectly cooked with just a hint of gaminess but the brine of the olvies was a little too strong for my taste. The parade of desserts then started.

I bet it's a great place to eat, I tried to make a reservation only to find out I will only be able to if we are in even numbers, It's only me and my two kids so that makes 3 of us, I instead will try to make a reservation for Grace Restaurant in Randolph street, they just emailed me and told me they can take us 3.....now if Alinea will take us 3, I will be so happy to dine there as well between Aug. 2-7, let me know if you can take us and I am willing to just pay for the 3 of us, instead of for 4 people, thanks...................X

During 2015/16 renovations in Chicago, the chef took his entire team to Spain and Miami for "pop-up" experiences in those cities. In Miami the setting was the Faena hotel (new in 2015), next door to Faena house, site of the record-breaking $60M penthouse, and home to many a hedge fund billionaire.  When you consider the concentration of obscene wealth in these structures, the $385 price tag (plus $150 for the lowest tier of wine pairings) is completely proportional, ja?  With service and taxes added on (everything is prepaid), the total of $1,400 is like fast food pricing for a billionaire.  But fast food it is not: this is more theatre than dining - the service is fluid and friendly, and Miami has never seen such talent and professionalism (and after March 31 when Alinea leaves, we may never see it again).  If you're a foodie, you are always looking for that one amazing bite during a meal that will be one to remember. At Alinea, you can sometimes have several of those experiences on a single plate. And when you read about all the steps that each element of each dish requires (one of the Miami dishes was studied in great detail by the New York Times at  mobile.nytimes.com/2016/… ), you understand why the cost of admission is so high.  Worth it? Oh, yes. But it's a "once in a lifetime" for me... unless I win a small lottery.

I attended the pop-up in Miami with my girlfriend. I'm relatively new to the "foodie" world. Over the past two years, I've really taken the opportunity to taste everything I can, learn to distinguish flavours...you know, the skills that differentiate a chain-restaurant frequent flyer from the self-proclaimed foodie who dives a little deeper.  Ok, on to Alinea. It exponentially surpassed any experience I have ever had with flavours, textures and overall consistency. It was my first real molecular gastronomy endeavour. And now my bar is fucking high!  My favourite dishes at the pop-up were the corn soup, the wagyu beef, the truffle ravioli (explodes in your mouth) and the frequently youtube'd dessert, presented to us by Grant himself. Now, you may think you can envision how these dishes are presented (assuming you know what they are before they arrive, which we didn't...all part of the excitement!) Let's just say the staff there were not only extremely friendly, but well-versed in educating you about what is in front of you before you dive in.  When you giggle after each bite, you know you're in the right place. Dining at Alinea is equivalent to being enlightened in life.

This place is amazing! I've heard so many good things about Alinea. I had always had an interest in molecular gastronomy so I knew i had to try it and of course it did not disappoint. It was one of the most memorable dining experiences ever! As they brought each course to our table, we got more and more intrigue about what's going to come next. Every single item they brought to our table was beyond delicious. Teasing your palates with different textures and flavors. Due to the high demands, you have to book your tickets way in advance. I believe i went on a Friday around 6PM and a ticket was $250 for a 16 course tasting. It was worth every penny! The staff was on point and super friendly. . I absolutely love this place! Would definitely come back to see what new creations they put together next.

I should begin by saying this was the Miami pop-up Alinea, not Chicago.  I've struggled with the best way to write this review.  In some ways Alinea was one of the best experiences I've had in life, but maybe not the best dinner I've ever had.  Don't get me wrong,the food was good, the presentation excellent.  I must confess, I'm a meat and potatoes guy and while not a foodie, I do enjoy great meals.  This was a $250 meal.  We paid $500, and I guess there is my rub.  I also didn't love the upswell to the wine pairing (when asking for a wine list).  We bought it.  Go for the imagination.  Go for the experience.   You may be hungry afterwards.  The service was good but our waiter seemed like he had done his job just a little too long.  As I explained to a friend, yes, it was good, but I'd rather have 5, $100 meals than repeat this experience. I hope I've been able to share what you may expect.  If money is no object and you're a hard core foodie, you will probably agree with the 5-star reviews here.

A culinary adventure from beginning to end.  Course after course of creative food paired with an edgy vibe and great service. // LOCATION // Off the beaten path from the regular tourist frenzy. You will need to cab it here if you are staying downtown.  // SERVICE // Impeccable. A sommelier is brought to your table to make great wine recommendations that were spot on, food allergies were remembered from an email exchange made when booking, and the list goes on. Amazing service without a hint of snootiness.  // FOOD // It was not food, it was art. I will not list out the courses as the menu is ever evolving and the team is currently traveling the world to catch more culinary inspiration.       + At the end of the meal, you are presented with an envelope containing a list of your menu items with a saavy coding system to notate the flavors and size of the dish.  3 Michelin stars well earned, Chef Achatz!

One of the greatest dining experiences I've ever enjoyed and definitely one I'll remember for a lifetime. We got one of the earlier seatings on Sunday around 5pm. Different time slots have different ticket values, this one was one of the cheaper ones, but I think it worked to our benefit as none of the surprises were ruined since we were presented our dishes before everyone else.  The presentation for each course was absolutely amazing, our table was constantly surprised by each and every dish that came out. If I'm being honest, I don't know if this was the best food that I've ever tasted, but it's definitely the most artistic expression of food that I've ever had the pleasure to experience. Every dish was a work of art in itself that played to multiple senses. I won't disclose much about our courses as I think it's best to just go into the experience not knowing what to expect and just have fun with it. If you have the opportunity to go and can afford it, definitely do it. It's worth it to experience at least once.

Absolutely speechless with the experience, presentation, and the food! I would not be extremely honest if I said I loved the food, because the food was okay! However, the service, the mechanics of dish preparation and presentation, and the whole experience was out of this world. I would definitely recommend it to anyone who could afford it and really experience the magic.  I won't disclose any details about the food because it's just part of the whole deal and personally I'd rather not know beforehand. We all know we aren't going there for the food (at least I hope)! And I tried really hard not to peek at other people's tables when they were being served but that's kinda impossible to avoid.  Anyways, as I told my bf that I am kind of addicted to the way I felt when I sat on that chair and anticipated the food and then was completely thrown off when I actually got to see/taste/smell/feel the food on my palate. It was like a roller coaster ride and I loved every minute of it!  It's something one should do JUST ONCE! lol! Definitely worth it!

My experience at this restaurant made clear the fact that I prefer eating over dining. To be fair although I was put off by the "ticket process" ,once I  arrived at the at the out-of-the-way locale I was impressed with the layout and extremely impressed with the quality of service. But as the meal began which I will now refer to as the Bataan  death march, it became obvious to me that I was in for a long long event. The artistry of the event became painfully clear from course one. I opted for the recommended wine pairing   and candidly I did enjoy those, although they ran the bill out to a stargazing level. I like for dinner to be the prelude to an evening as opposed to an evening in itself. This was one long dinner.  And as good as much of it was about halfway through I found myself feeling anxious and counting down the rest of the courses to see when it would be over. Not here to knock the food or the servers , who were terrific, just want to say four or five hour meals, no matter how good, test the limits of my patience. Five stars for food, Five stars for service, one star for making the experience painfully long. I guess that I am just a different kind of eater

There's nothing I can add to what has already been said, except that this was a magical experience. The only thing I would wish for would be more creative drink pairings that go beyond wine. My husband isn't a wine person and did a few beer pairings a la carte. They were just OK. Other than that: sheer magic!!

A sensory experience.  Art in motion. Innovative brilliance and a scientific experiment at the same time. If you are fortunate to  experience Alinea it will be an experience you will never forget!  Sublime.

We were lucky enough to score a reservation on my boyfriend's 30th birthday for four people, and doubly lucky that my best friend and her husband were able to join us. All of us agreed afterward that this dinner is best experienced in a group of friends; it is a social experience, and I can't imagine dining alone. In fact, we couldn't have imagined dining with just the two of us. The service was excellent. I have to apologize to the servers because I was in full banter mode this evening (at one point I told one of the waitstaff that he made me feel like I was in a dentist's office when he spread the napkin over my lap) but they were all just as witty and funny as one could hope for. The food was great, although a bit too much for my tiny stomach to handle - I couldn't eat much of the last few courses until dessert arrived. There were a lot of very rich flavors and interesting combinations; my boyfriend enjoyed everything tremendously and even finished up what I wasn't able to. My best friend is vegetarian, and her selections were amazing as well.  It's hard for me to separate out the actual food from the experience itself; at one point I was laughing hysterically, tears in my eyes, watching my companions trying to break candy balloons with their tongues. Everyone around us seemed to be having a great time, too. I think the dessert course was my favorite - so many different delicious flavors, including a caramelized banana which thrillingly tasted just like a Circus Peanut candy to me (I know I'm weird - I'm one of about twenty people in the world who loves Circus Peanuts; discerning and cultured, my palate is not). Anyway, we were really happy that we came, and very satisfied with our experience. Go with friends if you can; you'll have a lot more fun.

Alinea Review: Our trip to Chicago was made even more memorable by having the pleasure to dine at Alinea. Securing a reservation is a tad stressful, but once made, only excitement follows. We dined in June 2015.  Throughout my varied sampling of Michelin Star establishments, Alinea certainly tops them all for overall experience, yet I have enjoyed the food much more at many other restaurants. We also had an evening of cocktails at their world-renowned sister cocktail bar, The Aviary. (See my review for complete details.) Alinea is a unique, almost theatrical, experience above all else. The surprises throughout made for a very memorable dining adventure, well-deserving of its three Michelin stars. See below for a more complete review.  Reservations: Dining at Alinea does take some advanced planning. "Tickets" must be purchased online ahead of time, meaning that the entire meal is pre-paid (the new trend in more high-caliber restaurants now).  Décor: The unmarked exterior only adds to the mystique of Alinea. You traverse a long, narrow hallway with a red glow. The interior is best described as a modern simplistic design. The seats were quite comfortable.  Libations: With such an extensive meal ahead of us, we chose to sip water throughout the evening.  Food: Unlike my other reviews, I won't detail each course specifically, but will instead highlight those truly note-worthy. Our first course, Surf Clam, was truly a beautiful culinary display. Next came Steelhead Roe, which featured bubbling dry ice and liquid nitrogen-- so exciting. The Skate course was served on a very creative ceramic plate-- one of the most innovative plates I have come across-- very well-done! The campfire-esque course was entirely unexpected and featured many surprises of its own. The Rabbit course presentation was stunning and evoked a geographic transformation. The signature Hot Potato, Cold Potato was a very fun dish to experience, as was Alinea's classic Green Apple Balloon. I wish I could have had two of the balloons-- such a simple, yet exceptionally intriguing dessert-- one of the most creative I have ever seen! Our dinner finished up with the Tropical Fruit dessert prepared by Chef Bagale on our actual table on a large placement!  Service: The entire team consisted of hipster-type men (all men, no women) with beards in sliming black suits. One server was very new- so new in fact that he was still unfamiliar with the restaurant layout and whacked his head on a seemingly invisible glass divider in the dining room! He was fine, but not something you see every day in a restaurant of this caliber. The staff was attentive, yet I wish they had been a tad warmer and amenable to conversation.  Summary: Alinea is the pinnacle of molecular gastronomy. Each dish will heighten all of your senses, continuing to intrigue you in taste, texture, and of course, appearance. The entire dinner is as much an experience and performance as it is nourishment. My Recommendation: Go! Alinea is the most unique dining experience I have had to date. While the food was not exceptional, it was exceedingly innovative. The surprises throughout the meal made for a very memorable dining adventure, well-deserving of its three Michelin stars. I would only return if the menu changed significantly, as it appears to have remained rather stagnant over the years.  N.B. Alinea is presently undergoing extensive renovations-- both aesthetically and gastronomically; "Alinea 2.0" is slated to open early 2016, and I will definitely be returning once it opens!  4 stars  Michelin Stars: Three (2016) San Pellegrino World's Best: #26 (2015); Formerly: #9 (2014), #13 (2013), #7 (2012), #6 (2011)

Experiencing the molecular gastronomy of Grant Achatz is enough for a 5 star rating.  The presentation, taste of the actual food and the service also rates 5 stars (everyone was a culinary professional and just fantastic.  The female Master Sommelier was wonderful) But the thing that really took it over the edge was the star treatment given to my daughter, who was with me as a graduation gift to her after completing the culinary program at the Culinary Institute of America (Chef Achatz's alma mater) and graduating at the top of her class (after getting a BS in business). I had sent an email to the restaurant when I made a reservation letting them know why we were coming . We went on a Saturday night in early December while on a graduation trip to Chicago.  My daughter had done a research paper on Grant Achatz while in school and was dying to go to Alinea. Yes it was expensive, yes we paid for the wine pairings,  but we thought it was worth every cent . It was an experience of a lifetime that we will have together.  The staff went out of their way to come over and congratulate my daughter and give her special attention. Even Chef Achatz came out himself personally and prepared the dessert.  We were so thrilled and tongue tied!  She was allowed to go into the kitchen afterwards for a picture. Could not have been a better night and I thank everyone there for making this a night to remember.

After wanting to eat at Alinea for the longest time, I finally made it to there for my 30th birthday!! I was SUPER excited and soooo happy I was able to get a reservation. (I was literally checking every single day and pretty much gave up!! but I ended up being able to share a table with 2 other lovely ladies, so I was stoked!!). It was also my first time visiting Chicago, which I had heard great things about. Honestly, I probably would have made a trip to Chicago JUST for Alinea, but good thing I didn't. I was NOT impressed. Maybe even disappointed given the hype and excitement. I've eaten at six 3 Michelin-star restaurants (French Laundry, Joel Robuchon, Benu, Jean-Georges, & Grace), and Alinea unfortunately was the only one that truly let me down :'( I'm not going to give restaurants 5 just because everyone else or food critics or whoever thought so. So this is just my honest, humble opinion. 1) Okay, so if I were to rate Alinea for PRESENTATION and CREATIVITY. Sure, it probably is the best of the best, especially if you go back a few years ago, I feel not that many restaurants were on the same level. However, times have changed, other chefs have learned to master the art of presentation and innovative food. 2) Taste of the food was "decent" is all that I can describe. In fact the only dish I really really enjoyed was the potato puree with black truffle. Nothing too crazy, but ooh so flavorful. It left me wanting more. I can't really say that for any of the other things I ate. Uni corn I remember was good too. 3) Maybe this is getting too much into personal taste/preference, but too much use of strong flavored pickled garnishes that took away from the actual taste of the main dish. I thought fresh and good quality ingredients should not be overpowered. At first I tried to eat everything on the plate since I'm pretty sure the chef planned each & every item on there with an intention. But towards the end, I realized it was making my meal less enjoyable so I stopped eating them. 4) I loveeeeeeeeeee dessert, so even after all this, I was still hoping dessert could win me over. It did not. Okay, maybe my own fault for already having seen pictures, but as artistic and fun as it was. I didn't care for the actual eating part of the dessert...now this makes me really really sad. I'm usually the one who's eating me and my dining companion's share of dessert, cleaning off the plate...the dessert was a-okay. Service was great (no complaints). Presentation was mostly wonderful (minus the barnacles and olive oil cake inside the plant I thought was a bit too much lol). Taste was honestly a let down, considering Alinea is supposed to be one of the world's best restaurants. For a hefty $338 per person, I don't want just a food show, I expect all my food to be freaking delicious too!! Maybe my palate just isn't eclectic enough for Alinea??? Maybe they are trying too hard to be weird/different?? Ahhh I don't know...but entire meal no steak/lobster/duck/quail/shrimp/scallops/caviar/foie gras/pasta...felt like something was missing...like a main entree?? haha...me and my bf both felt the meal didn't feel complete. One time experience...okay...but really no need to ever go back. I went to eat at Grace the next day. Honestly, I would pick Grace over Alinea.

I went to Alinea on 10/4/15 and waited this long to write a review because I wasn't sure how I would even do it.  I don't need to expound endlessly on the different food dishes because 1. that might alter the experience of those who haven't gone yet and 2. I couldn't possibly do it justice.  But here we go... Step 1.  Be a Grant Achatz fan girl.  Own the Alinea artbook/cookbook.  Read Grant's book, read reviews, talk to people who have met him. Step 2.  Dream about going to Alinea for years (you read that right) and in the process save up the money for it and come up with a good enough reason to justify the expense. Step 3.  Get married to someone who appreciates culinary experiences as much as you do and will thoroughly enjoy Alinea.  Wedding anniversary is the perfect excuse to book a reservation.   Step 4.  Move back to the Midwest so a trip to Chicago isn't ridiculous.  Check Twitter every day religiously for 3 solid months until they open reservations for the month of October. Step 5.  Plan awesome anniversary trip to Chicago and be so excited about it that you can hardly stand it.  Tell absolutely everyone you know about Alinea and how excited you are to go.   Step 6.  Freak out that you might actually meet Grant Achatz and what will you even do then?!?!  You're not supposed to meet your idols because they might ruin themselves for you, and OMG what if Alinea isn't the great experience that you hope it will be?!?!? Step 7.  How do you even decide what to wear to such a culinary event?  Shouldn't a new dress be purchased for the occasion?  (the answer from the hubby was no, darn.) Step 8.  The day of the Alinea dinner, go to the Art Institute of Chicago so that your mind is prepped for artistic endeavors and you are already primed to appreciate the art that you will experience tonight.  Alinea is called dinner theatre for good reason, treat it as such. Step 9.  Get a fancy Uber to take you there because it's so much easier and part of the experience.   Step 10.  Take a picture outside before you walk in so you can get your fangirlness out before you potentially embarrass yourself. Step 11.  Step inside the door and proceed to experience the most incredible meal of your life with the love of your life sitting across from you.  Enjoy the conversation with the incredibly awesome servers, ask questions about everything, switch between staring into the eyes of your love, to staring at the delicious food in front of you, to staring at the kitchen in front of you that is surprisingly calm, quiet, but still magnificent.   Step 12.  Halfway through the meal, ask the hubby when we can come back.  Float out of the restaurant (mostly because I was suuuper tipsy after all the alcohol that came with the wine pairings) with longing to stay because you don't want to leave this ethereal place that has changed your perspective on food. In short, Alinea was everything that I wanted it to be.  Grant wasn't there so I didn't have anything ruined for me.  Every part of the experience justified the cost for me.  I can still taste some of the dishes that really impacted me.  I can't wait until the renovation is complete so I can plan the next trip.

I'm pretty confident that this was the best meal I have ever had. My wife took me here by surprise for my birthday.  Literally I was blindfolded until I got to the door step. Boy was I happy and I am also happy I never saw the bill (she prepaid). The two of us split one wine pairing which I think was enough.  The food was delicious and I was thrilled with every course of the meal. Be warned that he truffle explosion really can explode. The lady next to us had an absolute disaster when she could not keep the intense power of the truffle explosion within her mouth!!    This was a once in a lifetime event.

My visit was on Sunday March 1st at 5:30 PM and we finished dinner at 8:30 PM. I wanted to wait to write the review because I want to leave a review that was as memorable as the experience. Did it leave me wanting more? Am I still dreaming about it? Was it worth the hefty price tag? I actually started this review over  9 months ago and completely forgot about it. I guess that answers the above questions.  Alinea was definitely a social experience.  Everything was beautifully presented,  served by a great staff, and came with a hefty price tag which I can respect.  The amount of time and dedication that goes into each dish,  which in its own right, is a work of art and mad scientist theatrical performance. Therefore,  why 4 stars and not 5? While there were multiple courses, each course was one bite stretched over 2 hours. Some bites were amazingly delicious, but some bites were a gorgeous work of art, but lacked the depth of flavor for what it was described how it should of taste.

A great experience overall -- starting with a rather hidden door to the infamous balloon of taffy, but I can't say that everything about it was worth venturing out for. My friend and I live on different coasts and used a reservation here as an excuse to meet up, so we expected great things from Alinea. The service and decor were amazing, but I did not enjoy all of the courses as much as I have at other restaurants with the same reviews. My friend did love every part of the restaurant, but this is (what I believe) attributed to her knowledge of the chef's vision for each dish. Based purely on taste, I will not make another trip out for Alinea. The mixture of flavors is usually the best part, but I actually found a lot of the first half of dishes to be quite odd and not really complementary. It was a treat to try since it is supposed to be one of the best restaurants in Chicago, but there are plenty of other restaurants in the world that appeal to me more.

Was given this experience as a gift with my wife. Absolutely the most interesting and best tasting food  I've ever had. Most people have given good reviews, so I'll just add something I like that we did. Our reservation was for the first dinner time, so pretty early, like 6 I think, maybe 7. We got there early and got a drink next door at Boka, a good way to save $ if you don't want to shell out for drinks at Alinea. We were also the first table receiving courses in our room, so since we were ahead of other tables who were seated after us, each dish was a suprise to us and everyone else. It was also fun hearing the "oooos and ahhhhs" about our food as it was brought out.

I don't know what to say that hasn't already been said. Behind those blacked out windows and long hallway, an experience like no other awaits. Inventive, creative, other-wordly. Just go. It's awesome.
Won't say anything that hasn't been said already. The most memorable meal I've ever had. And yes, if you love and are passionate about great food, it's worth every penny.  Will definitely return.

My last review of 2015 and it couldn't be better. Alinea, what more can I say. You amazed me and my mother on her birthday! The reviews describe the restaurant well and we were not disappointed. We got in before the major renovations for January/February. Alinea was, as my mom described, an EXPERIENCE. Walking in, the decor is clean and modern. The servers highly attentive. And the food amazing. My favorites were the hot potato (a classic), the graffiti dish (on custom concrete!), the parsnip (surprisingly amazing and more flavorful than you'd imagine), and the Kombu/unagi/corn (cooked right on a flame on your table!). The signature dessert at the end is also amazing with Chef Achatz himself laying out the dessert! Overall a wonderful experience. :) Tips: the wine pairings can be A LOT of alcohol (plus you start with a cocktail), thus we were more than satisfied with one bottle of Chardonnay between the two of us. Apparently some guests get quite tipsy and have to pass on a dish!

I dined here in March, but didn't remember to tell the world about this amazing experience until reflecting on the good food of 2015. First off, the hubs and I decided to try Alinea since we had a great experimental experience at the now closed WD-50 a year ago. Alinea is known for making dining an experience, and they did not disappoint us. We were "easily" able to get a reservation on a weekday at 9pm during a Chicago winter. I won't spoil it, because each plate deserves to be experienced by you directly. But, I will say this: I loved the taste of some courses, and others were swallowed with difficulty. I wish we got a whole plate of some items, and less of others. But each dish was absolutely wonderful. We were entertained and each plate had a playful mystery to it. The idea of having your tastebuds confused and being surprised at every turn is what makes this restaurant stand out from all others. Definitely the best experience with food for us this year (and we did TFL, which is hard to beat).

An experience.  There were several surprises that made me (literally) squeal and giggle in delight.  The food is top-notch, obviously: unique, thoughtful, fresh... everything you would expect from many restaurants of its caliber.  But, the thing that set it apart to me is the thought that so clearly goes into your total experience.  I just can't even say more without ruining it! The service is worth note, as well.  I expected one of two things: either stuffy and pretentious, or hipster and unapproachable.  Not. Even. Close.  The (very young) staff is a perfect blend of professional, knowledgeable and helpful (they take your jacket, they offer cab service, they know what to do with your napkin when you go to the restroom... everything you expect when you pay this much)... but SOOOOO approachable, down-to-earth and... well... cool.  They will make you laugh, they love food but don't take themselves too seriously. This is worth every penny (if you're into this sort of thing ;-) ).
After eating all over the world - Alinea due to its food, theatre of dishes and outstanding service was the best meal experience of our life!! Thank you Alinea and excited to come back one day

I mean what can i say that hasn't already been said? This was hands down the best meal of my life, better than Per Se, French Laundry, Joel Robuchon, WD50. If you haven't gone...go. If you went and didn't like it...there's something wrong with you. Cant wait to go back after their renovations.

Get the first reservation of the evening (5 pm) so you are surprised by each course and do not read anymore reviews to decide if it is really worth going (it is). Go with no expectations and an open mind.   I don't want to say too much but a few highlights... The service is outstanding. I especially liked how the servers joke around and keep the atmosphere very light.  We had 13 courses. Amazing progression, precision, and execution across the entire menu. Insane variety of tastes, temperatures, and textures. Some were better than others but it is truly impressive how much thought and effort goes into each dish. Go once in your life because it is a such a unique and memorable culinary experience.

We had really high expectations for this meal and it exceeded all of them. I can't say enough good things about the service and food-- it was surprisingly fun. Everyone should do the wine pairings-- the somm was amazing, as was the wine.

Alinea isn't just a dining experience... it's an art show that you admire and then indulge. A pilgrimage of sort that all restauranteurs should experience. My dining experience at Alinea changed my perception of cuisine forever.  After my tremendous 11 course meal, I had the honor of having my dessert artistically thrown on my vinyl covered table by Chef Grant himself. The man is truly on a different dimension and has modernized timeless classics in way that 99.999% of the chefs in the world couldn't even imagine. A true culinary Picasso.  I now I understand why this is one of the most decorated restaurants in the world. Worth every penny.

The experience was fantastic and the food is 5 stars. The problem is they can't accommodate odd numbers so I'll never be able to share that experience with anyone other than my wife and I without paying for a ghost or dining with some random individual during a very expensive meal. I have been to ... well I don't mention that but restaurants far harder to get into than Alinea and none have given me grief over 5 diners, but Alinea has! They say buy 6 and dine with a ghost or let some random eat with you and your family and you'll be good to go. Sad, but true. Maybe Alinea 2.0 will let me eat in privacy with my family!

Context: - Went for dinner on 12/12 with my wife. Paid ~$750 for dinner (including tax and tip) and chose the reserve wine pairing ~$650. Total of $1,300.  - This is our 3rd 3 Michelin star restaurant - Guy Savoy in Paris and Alain Ducasse in London. For these last two, with wine pairing, the cost was closer to $900.  Food: - 5 stars. Everything was perfect. Very innovative dishes, entertaining to eat and in one you will laugh.  - Definitively worth the $750 Other guests (non-controllable for Alinea) - We were seated in a section with 4 other tables. Here is what happened in 3 out of those 4. - Table farthest from us: One guy was reading a book the entire time (ok, whatever) - Table next to us: Older couple did not stop staring at us (ok, whatever) - Table in front of us: Girl passed out drunk! We noticed she was not talking and thought she was looking at her phone but then realized she was passed out. She ended up throwing up in the bathroom and my wife went right after. She had to tell one of the staff to send someone to clean. Reserve Wine Pairing (controllable for Alinea) - I will try to write this without sounding like and alcoholic but the amount you get served is ridiculously little! Not even to the curvature of the glass. During the first pour I honestly thought it was intended for me to try it out - For context, it takes about 4 decent sips to finish the 'glass' - Each wine is served before the dish and there is often a time lag (not an issue) but in two occasions we ended up finishing the 'glass'. - We asked the sommelier if we could have more and he was cool about it. However, we did notice that after that our wines were poured immediately AFTER the dish got served so this "double" thing did not happen again - For $650, not sure it was worth going through the awkwardness of thinking you are doing something wrong by asking for another glass Service (controllable for Alinea) - This is context that you are going to a 3 Michelin star restaurant. The level of service we got is above what any human being needs but not at the level of this rating. - During the service we were never asked if we needed anything else ,changes, etc... During courses 7-8 and 8-10 there is a looong waiting time were you don't get any wine as well. I wanted some more water but no one ever checked on us. - It honestly feels you are part of a production process that will not change, you sit down, eat and get the hell out.

Terribly overpriced for mediocre food. The wait staff was very attentive, maybe too overly attentive. They stand in the dining room waiting for you to take your final bite so they can clear the table for the next course. There were 3-4 people at all times watching us eat. Uncomfortable.

WOW. Just wow. This place was mindblowingly (is that a word?) amazing. There's not much to be said that hasn't already been said in detail on this page except, if you get the opportunity to come here, DO IT. It's a great experience and a fantastic evening. I do agree though that seeing another table getting an item that you haven't gotten yet kind of spoils the surprise, but that's how all restaurants like this work, I just try to do my best to keep my wandering eye on our food :)  Service was impeccable, we had a nice chat with the couple sitting next to us as well. The whole experience was enjoyable! P.s. if you're wearing glasses, make sure to take them off BEFORE popping the balloon. My husband learned that the hard way ;)

For what it's worth Alinea does exactly what you think It amazes .. The food wasn't phenomenal but the presentation and the experience was . To be able to go and enjoy a dinner of such is a blessing .  If you can afford to go without starving for the month then go for it , if your going to eat a good meal then don't do it .  I wouldn't do it again but I definitely cherished the moment when I was there .  The only really memorable and tasty dish was the balloon which is made out of taffy and you have to inhale to eat. It gets a little messy but they bring you hot towels to clean up.

Great food & experience but not as good as the 1st time we dined there (4yrs ago). Alinea always impresses with the fresh and unique food pairings that look like art, impeccable service, perfect wine pairings by John. If you have never been, it is definitely worth splurging once in your life but I am not sure we will go back. This time, the service was just as good as we remembered but the food didn't wow us the same way as the 1st time and surprisingly both my husband and I were hungry a few hours later (and for this price, we thought that shouldn't be the case). Our favorite dish was the dashi & barnacles (unique, beautifully presented and tasty) and 2nd was the lamb dish.

OH MY GOD Yes this is hands down one of the top foods to ever hit my mouth.  I want more... I need more... I can't afford more :(    Seriously, everybody expects the food to be great, and amazing presentation, and a textural tantalization.  I mean what else gets your way too many stars for your wallet to afford?  I want to focus on something else... First, the wine.  My group chose the wine pairings and they were just fantastic.  The staff AND the sommelier both were knowledgable.  Its like they were all trained, not just one person.  They all had opinions too, I really appreciate someone who's willing to say what they like and why, in addition to suggesting what I might like.  The great part is that the pairings just complimented everything quite fantastically.  Nothing I didnt finish without wanting more! But this brings me to more important things... the staff.  I'm not sure what the usual time to spend there is.  We spent nearly 4 hours and closed the place... yes I think we were the absolutely last people to leave.  They did not get make us feel rushed or unwelcome, in fact, it was so very much enjoyable to have the attention of multiple staff members and how fun they were to talk to and laugh with.  I think that the food is obviously good but the staff should get more attention... that kind of staff is hard to come by!

From secret passageways to the spectacular food, the experience of dining at Alinea made me feel like I accidentally stepped into another world for 2 hours. Even the valet was exceptional and made my fiancé and I feel special.  I hate to give away surprises, so I'll keep it vague. The food was delightful in both flavor and presentation. The dining room would often erupt in bouts of laughter when the dishes were brought out or the first bite tasted. This food makes you joyful.  My only criticism is that the dining room will be paced differently, so if you get your plate after another table, the surprise of what's next will be ruined a bit.  Excellent, excellent, excellent. I can't wait to go back.

Alinea was an indescribable culinary experience. Magical perhaps? Presentation, creativity, taste, service - simply flawless. Honestly, Eleven Madison Park has nothing on Alinea. Within a total different league, It's just unfair to compare.  However... Although all the dishes were tasty, there wasn't one that I wished I could pick up my plate to eat every crumb or drop. In addition, I wished there was bread service... It's so hard to give a place 5 stars without free house made bread coming from a carb loving fatty.  Still... Loved every moment of the experience. Our server was beyond attentive - so witty and great sense of humor too!  Overall - deserves every Michelin Star it's been awarded. Will start saving to return for my Chicago visit!

Interesting dinner; wonderful experience.  But the food itself... I went to dinner understanding that this is going to be a "gastronomical experience" but unfortunately, that does not necessarily mean it has to taste of moderate quality. Given that this is a 3 star michelin restaurant (also costing you an arm and a leg), I expected the unique elements to captivate me and leave me curious on how they made it taste like that. But instead, I was left bewildered of the awkward combinations. Maybe just one dish was tasteful, which would be the tiniest circle dish with a needle pin that runs through it. We were most excited about the dessert but the only thing exciting was the glitter they had sprinkled over the table. The "gastronomical" pieces of dessert had no flavor! All you taste is a bland particle which you smear with the syrup, so essentially, all you taste is the syrup.  It is sad to stay that I cannot recommend this place to my close friends and family. I would be evil if I told them to come check this place out.

*** 750th Review, 1st time trying out Michelin 3-star restaurant *** Each foodie has his/her list of "dream" upscale dining restaurants (from the French Laundry in Napa Valley to Eleven Madison Park in New York); however, I never thought this day would actually come ... it is one thing to dream and drool about the list, but it is another thing to pay a total of $338.13 and fly all the way to Chicago just to try it. Overall, Alinea wasn't necessary the best meal, but rather the best dining EXPERIENCE I've ever enjoyed. Alina is one of the two three-star Michelin restaurants in Chicago (as of 2015), ranked No. 26 on 2015 World's 50 Best Restaurants (ranked No. 9 in 2014), and received AAA Five Diamond Award. In addition, Chef Grant Achatz (one of Time Magazine's 100 most influential people in 2011 & winner of James Beard Outstanding Chef in 2008) was diagnosed w/ stage 4 tongue cancer back in 2007, but he's now cancer free. *** Reservation & Dress Code *** Follow Alinea on Twitter and it will send out a tweet when tickets begin to go on sale (typically between 8 AM to 10 AM PST on the 15th of each month) & you can ONLY book a party of 2, 4, or 6. You have about less than 1 to 2 hours before most time slots are filled, so plan accordingly. I would get the earliest reservation time (e.g. 5 PM) so other tables won't ruin the surprises. For men, bring a jacket and no casual wear (e.g. jeans, t-shirts or tennis shoes).  *** Price & Valet Parking *** For Sat 5 PM dinner, it was $338.13 per person ($255 base price + 20% service charge + 10.5% taxes); however, the base price varies depending on date and time (e.g. Sunday is cheaper than Saturday & early 5 PM dinner is cheaper than 7 PM dinner). You'll have to pay separately for wine pairings & $14 for valet parking. *** Tips & Other Information *** Alinea specializes in molecular gastronomy and please expect this 12~14 courses to last 2~4 hours (I finished the entire thing in approximately 2 hours w/ 5 minutes break b/w each course & w/o wine pairings). If you are planning to come here, then don't look at any pictures because they will ruin all the surprises. If you don't care, then keep reading. *** WARNING - SPOILERS AHEAD *** Impeccable service - it starts the moment you step into the Alinea's boundary and the staff will escort you till the very end. I embarrassed myself by taking used fork & knife and putting them back to where I grabbed it. Fancy complimentary volcanic water (Sant Aniol - NOT sparkling) & all my friend did was chugging the water. *** Food *** Apple cider from Norwegian: It was stirred w/ rose stem; tasted very crisp. Peach [basil, murray river salt]: Icy ball sealed w/ peach juice - very interesting texture. Bocadillo [bread, jamon iberico, manchego] & Gilda [guindilla de Ibarra, anchovy, olive] & Patatas Bravas [paprika, chile, garlic]: These three cubes tasted exactly like what I saw in the pictures - talk about food "engineering" at its best. Strawberry [tomato, pumpernickel, burrata]: Soup tasted like dashi w/ weird boba-like texture AND not to mention tomato looked like strawberry, but tasted like tomato (and vise versa). Another interesting visual trick. Brook Trout [uchiki kuri squash, thai banana, blis]: New course and unfortunately I thought it tasted OK. Graffiti [matsutake, maitake, parsley]: Whoa - I actually thought those were actually bricks (those were actually crackers) - delicious melt-in-your-mouth crackers. Daikon [smoke, seawater, ash] & Tororo Kombu [hamachi, ice fish cracker] & Unagi [pickled plum, white sesame] & Corn [miso, nori, togarashi]: Corn was decent, but hamachi tasted delicious and crispy - probably one of the best hamachi I've had. Chicken [shishito, lily, kombu]: Charcoal was used to fire tea kettle and SOMEHOW charcoal turned into chicken w/ a touch of lily and shishito pepper. It was definitely one of a kind presentation. Hot Potato [cold potato, black truffle, butter]: I pulled off the metal stick and ate the entire thing in one attempt. It was cool, but it didn't taste as good as other courses. Olive cake [extra virgin olive oil, black pepper]: I hate olive, but I thought olive cake was pretty good (no strong bitter taste)! Lamb [caper leaf, grapes, olives]: Not very memorable. Parsnip [honey truffle, vanilla, orange]: This had the most complex flavors - the "mouth-feel" from Diet Coke, sourness from sauce, and garlicky flavor all combined into one. Balloon [helium, green apple]: I sucked some of helium and my voice actually changed for few seconds. Think the balloon as green apple flavor bubble gum filled w/ helium. My friend didn't "kiss" the balloon properly and all helium just dissipated to the atmosphere. Tropical Fruit [rum, vanilla, kaffir lime]: Final course and grand finale - one minute of dazzling dessert show.Good frozen coconut and interesting mix of mango, passion fruit, and chocolate sauces. *** Alina is a once-in-a-lifetime experience and that's all there is to it.

The worst Michelin starred experience ever. This is the 36th Michelin Starred restaurant I have been to all around the world. Service was terrible, the wine list was finally given to me after I asked for it three times. We ordered Apple Cider at the beginning and never saw it even after we left. Some dishes were disgusting, notably the Olive cakes, lamb chop, Gilda and patatas bravas. Even the first course, a chocolate shell pop, in comparison with the same dish from other Michelin restaurant, does not meet our expectation. Some dishes brought too much smoke in a closed environment making us extremely uncomfortable. I really don't think the restaurant deserves such a fame across the country, it is actually even worse than most of the Bib Gourmand restaurants in Chicago.

I thoroughly enjoyed my meal but I'm not able to say that everything blew me away. Even though it's considered one of the best restaurants in the world there were a few dishes that let me down and I will have to say that I was left wanting a little more in terms of flare and flashiness.  You walk in to an incredibly dark hallway. Just be cautious and continue on. A set of doors will open to your left when you get far enough. When you walk in, everything seems very stiff yet cordial. Once you get to your table the wait staff is much friendlier.  The waitstaff's friendliness was a delight since the hostesses made the experience seem like it might be quite dull. +1 for the waiters.  As far as the overall dinner goes, it was a great combination of unique dishes, playful presentations and refined service.  I'm not going to write about the dishes here because I feel that half the fun is being surprised by what's going on. The best advice I can give is to stay focused on your own dining experience and try not to look over at other tables to see what they are eating. Or book an earlier time so you are one of the first groups to eat.

What a clever way to getting people to own up to their reservation obligation...pay up front!!! It's simple and you don't have to worry about paying any more once you arrive, unless you get additional drinks or the wine pairing. And the service was great. Despite having a 930pm reservation, I felt a little cautious as from previous experience have shown me that the 2nd or later sitting tends to go faster, since the staff usually wants to go home sooner. In this case, the wait staff were very professional and there were no signs on speeding up the experience. You can however, ask to speed things up. But these guys were great. The show was great. Although it was a good experience for me, this is where you get to at least try it once, and then move on.  To me, the experience wasn't really intimate, romantic or magical. Not that it is a bad thing, but if I'm required to wear a jacket for the experience, then I don't need to have the extra comedy from the staff...but I guess thats what makes this 3 star Michelin restaurant unique in its own way.
My favorite restaurant in the world. It's not even really a restaurant. It's an experience where everything is thought out and meticulously executed. Grant is really a genius and loves his craft.

I'm going to compare Alinea to my most recent pricier dining experiences. Fat Duck in Melbourne in June for AUD 675, Maude last week for AUD 220, and Alinea last night for AUD 400. None of these prices include drinks.  Alinea was definitely more fine dining than Fat Duck. Whilst there was some of the theatre, it was on a much more refined and toned down version than Fat Duck.  Think of Fat Duck as the fun younger sibling to Maude being the oldest and well past being stupid, with Alinea in the middle, grown up yet still able to let loose a little.  The overall food itself was probably better than Fat Duck, but I was disappointed that there wasn't one specific dish (or element of a dish) that I can think of now that makes me drool (Fat Duck had the "blood pudding" with the duck, Maude the Venison, Tagliatelle & the corned wagyu beef). Don't get me wrong, everything was lovely, it was just probably more consistent, or even safe perhaps, than I was hoping for.  I'm not against consistency, I think I just had in my head there'd be more to the "fun" part of the dining than the "fine" part.    (Maybe I've been spoilt with the overall theatrics of Fat Duck, or that venison at Maude)  If you're after good food, in a fine dining setting, with a little fun, definitely check Alinea out.  I like the idea of the pre-purchased tickets, which includes service & tax.  Drinks are extra, and they now have a small liquor list to go along with wines by the glass, bottle, beer, cider & the matching wine option. I opted for a single malt @ $65 (US) for 2 oz (a double / 59ml for those playing around the world).  Fun Fact - the helium balloon was a hoot!

I really really wanted Alinea to be the best dining experience of my life and to be honest it fell a little short. The service, creativity and presentation were out of this world, but what I was most disappointed in was the flavors. There were a few things that blew me away but I was expecting every course to do just that considering the amount of acclaim Alinea has received. Maybe I'm just not fancy enough, but the extravagance of it all was a little much for me and in all honesty I would rather eat a home cooked meal from my mother than go back to Alinea.

Truly amazing experience. I don't usually order exotic dishes but the sweetbreads here was amazing. And the Chocolate explosions was the best dessert i have ever had. Would highly recommend this place.  Changed my rating to a four since "Salt" in Amelia Island was definitely better.

3.5 stars Found flavors and service lacking compared to other Michelin starred restaurants.  Definitely met but did not exceed expectations.  Perhaps too overhyped and most food oriented folks I know have dined there a few years ago and not recently.  I found certain courses too salty or sweet. Going to go against the grain:  as someone else mentioned, a feast for my eyes more than for my tongue.  Alinea is worth the price - you're getting food and theatre in the ticket price.  Very playful food presentations.  Excellent and well prepared food execution and preparation - can you just imagine how long it took to make that tomato and strawberry gelee so lifelike?  Not to mention, I'm sure that flavors can be off and difficult to manipulate when you use scientific v traditional cooking techniques.  My friend mentioned how the menu reminds her of the now defunct WD-50 tasting.  The flavors were good, as I expected it to be, however, I just didn't experience the normal euphoric food high. Highlight was the pastry chef's presentation of the dessert painting on a silicone grey sheet he placed over our dining table. I guess I'm just not a fan of molecular gastro cuisine but you should definitely experience it for yourself.  In addition, if you're a repeat diner, the kitchen is said to send several complimentary dishes which can make first time diners feel underwhelmed. Reservations pretty easy to procure for dining on Wednesday to Friday nights.   Maybe I just got lucky.

Obviously the food is extremely good. The experience was just as good. I've had a quite a few course tasting dining experiences worldwide. This one is tops. The price tag is also tops. We are in Chicago and this is a Michelin 3 star so it's justified. I will not go over item by item. The whole fun of the menu is surprise. My date knew nothing going in and she was giddy during the meal. The presentation is flawless by both food and wine servers. You can tell they are more highly trained here than in Chef Achatz other restaurant Next. The atmosphere is not stuffy which is what my assumption was. Staff is loose and will make jokes. They feed off the energy of the table. It's a fun, delicious 4 hour experience. If you can afford it do it.
Hands down the best eating experience of my life. The food and the service was excellent as well as unique. Completely changed how I think about food.

What can I say one of the most amazing meals and experienced I have ever had.  From the food to the theatre to the service.  My only negative (or warning) is if you request to meet Grant (chef owner) don't expect for him to acknowledge you in any way.  I was a huge fan and put in a request to meet him (one artist to another) and I felt totally snubbed.  I mean I know he probably gets a lot of requests but a hello and a handshake is just common courtesy.

such high expectations...I mean, it's Alinea!  the highlight was the potato soup and the helium taffy balloons, everything else was ok.  The staff was personable and not hoity-toity.  Come prepared to belt out your favorite song when you dig into the helium balloon.  highlight of our night was our friend Ben belting out NWA.

Last night was like THE BEST first date.  It started with a flurry of outfit changes, option after option tossed out until I had settled on something comfortable and low-key (because who wants thirteen courses in a bandage dress and spike heels?).  On my way now, the butterflies begin. I had refrained from Google stalking because I didn't want to know too much. But now, as I get closer to the restaurant, the pleasant tingle of excitement turns into something more like actual nervousness. I should have researched! This is a stupid dress! And what if I don't like the food, and what if my dinner companion and I run out of things to say? The door opens and the hall is dark, long, and empty. Oh god, it's going to be pretentious. I crack a stupid joke about haunted houses. A door at the end of the hall slides open, making me jump.  A kind gentleman is waiting to take our coats. Since I just managed to scare myself in the hallway, I frazzledly shake his hand instead of handing over my coat. He rolls with it. (Bless him.) We are shown to a table in a serene, beige room. A shishito pepper and lily bud fly overhead. We sit down, a bit stiff and expectant. And then the night begins for real, and the nerves dissipate, and everything is wonderful. Some food-objects (what do you call them? courses? not really because there are so many separate elements) land more than others -- but the ones that do, my gosh, I feel in my bones. And other places.  A couple hours move by at an ideal pace. There are fits of uncontrollable giggling, and pleasant banter with the very pleasant staff, who move plates (or concrete slabs/piles of hot cinders/slippery seaweed, etc) with calm ease and are exceptionally well trained in the art of making people feel welcome. The gentleman seated next to us shares sips of his wine with us, which is a bit odd in theory but works well in practice. Well-heeled diners inhale helium and fill the room with the sound of joyful chipmunks, and everyone laughs and cheers.  By the finale of the meal, I am totally relaxed. I am humming Ten Minutes Ago to myself as my friend and I waltz out into the fall night. And the best part is: I know there will be a second date. I don't know when. But I know it will happen.

It is an extraordinary experience for sure, but more for your eyes than for your taste buds. Considering this is a food place after all, maybe they need to rethink their priorities.  Upon entering you are greeted by some very friendly staff, and you get the chance to have a peek into their ginormous kitchen full of cool gadgets that look like they come from a sci-fi movie. I really enjoy being able to have this behind the scenes look and better appreciate how your food is made. The actual dining room is elegant but still simplistic. I don't exactly know how I feel about this - considering the price and fame even if it's gold and marble everywhere it won't be a surprise. I suppose not having over the top decor helps you focus on how pretty they make your food? Then we were asked to choose our drink pairings. My date had the reserved wine pairing, which is a lot of $$$$ but well worth every penny. The wines were high quality and a few of them extremely rare, and the sommelier was very good at explaining the nuances of each. Apparently one of them was from such a mysterious source they can never find anything just like it again.... Hmmmm. Normally I don't like ordering wine and in the back of my head think "oh man I could have gotten this at Binny's for a fraction of the price" but I didn't have the concern here - since clearly normal people can't get their hands on most of Alinea's selection. I don't drink much so I just took sips from his glasses and ordered a root beer. I'm pretty sad that they don't have a pairing for non-alcholic drinks. They have it at Next, and a pairing really brings out a good synergy between the food and the drink. We had about 14 courses (can't remember exactly) and most of them were just one tiny tiny little bite. A lot of very interesting concepts for sure, like chocolate that's completely bleached white?  One of the most impressive dishes was also the one that made me the saddest though. They made a seaside bonfire with seaweed, rocks, a nice little fireplace etc at our table, which was super impressive, FOR ONE TINY BITE OF FISH. I feel like if that dish was worth $100, at least $95 was spent on the decor part..... I'd say the dinner definitely ended very nicely with the dessert. Two dessert chefs make the dessert at your table, on your table cloth. It is quite a masterpiece of different sauces and pieces of fruit, and the chefs go through a very synchronized and dramatic motion to lay down everything for you. Too bad the taste was again not phenomenal... IDK if I'm imagining it, but they have molecular gastronomied the (*&$^% out of all the food that I sometimes imagine tasting chemicals in them.

best birthday I ever had.   If you can't afford it once, put it on your bucket list.  Don't read into the reviews/menus - let it be a surprise - you will enjoy it more!   It certainly is well worth it especially in comparison to alternative expensive experiences - Blackhawks/Bears game, a show, etc. ...

By far the most creative and fun food experience I've ever had. I went in with high expectations and still kept being pleasantly surprised. A collage of wonderful food tastes, puzzles, structures and designs. The experience is as much like witnessing a performance art show as it is like having a dinner. Definitely worth it, if you can afford it. In fact, I'd say  going once a year would be worth it, even if you have to travel.

If your going for a show with no food in your stomach, this is the place for you.  The presentation was very entertaining and the service was very excellent.  At the end of the dinner, I walked out hungry and sad that I spent a lot of money on the dinner.

Alinea is more than a meal it is a dining experience. As soon as you walk in the door you enter another world where art and world come together in perfect unison. A meal at Alinea is one of those rare meals that will inspire your mind and stick with you for a life time. Alinea is best experienced when you know as little as possible so the experience can be truly personal. Avoid spoilers, therefore stop reading if you want to make the best of your night. As soon as you walk in the door the tone for the entire experience is set by a red lit hallway that tappers at the end. As you move down the hall a large sliding door automatically opens, ushering you into another world. You walk in the door and immediately you are greeted by a smiling man in a suit. He welcomes you with instructions to hang out near the glass wall and study the kitchen. You stand there, entranced by the eerily quiet but busy kitchen. The man in the suit says it's time to move to the table. Over the table a shishito pepper and lilly hang, creating a shadow that resembles a hummingbird.
